choices.text: Neuritic plaques made of beta amyloid are found
Nucleus of Meynert is not affected

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about Alzheimer's disease?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nucleus of Meynert is not affected

 

The Nucleus of Meynert (a group of cholinergic neurons in the basal forebrain) is indeed affected in AD, leading to a decrease in acetylcholine, which contributes to the memory deficits seen in this disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Alzheimer's disease (AD) is a progressive neurodegenerative disease that primarily affects the elderly. The key findings in AD are:

 

Option A. Intracellular neurofibrillary tangles are seen: True. These are composed of hyperphosphorylated tau protein.

 

Option B. Neuritic plaques made of beta amyloid are found: True. These plaques are extracellular and are composed of beta-amyloid protein.

 

Option D. Short term memory is affected: True. This is one of the hallmark clinical features of AD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alzheimer's disease is the most common cause of dementia. It is characterized by both intracellular neurofibrillary tangles and extracellular neuritic plaques. Cholinergic deficits, especially from the degeneration of the Nucleus basalis of Meynert, play a significant role in the memory impairments observed in these patients.

choices.text: It acts as an P2 Y12 agonist
It is 10 times less potent than clopidogrel
Omeprazole interferes with metabolism of prasugrel leading to increased risk of bleeding

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about prasugrel? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It is a pro-drug

 

Prasugrel is a prodrug that is metabolized by the liver to its active metabolite, which is an inhibitor of P2Y12 ADP platelet receptors. This active metabolite irreversibly inhibits platelet aggregation, making prasugrel a potent antiplatelet agent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It acts as an P2 Y12 agonist: It acts as an P2 Y12 agonist is incorrect because prasugrel is not a P2Y12 agonist but rather an inhibitor.

 

Option B It is 10 times less potent than clopidogrel: It is 10 times less potent than clopidogrel is incorrect because prasugrel is actually more potent than clopidogrel.

 

Option D. Omeprazole interferes with metabolism of prasugrel leading to increased risk of bleeding: Omeprazole interferes with metabolism of prasugrel leading to increased risk of bleeding is incorrect because omeprazole can interfere with the activation of prasugrel to its active metabolite, reducing its antiplatelet effect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prasugrel is a pro-drug that, upon hepatic metabolism, becomes an active metabolite that irreversibly inhibits the P2Y12 ADP platelet receptors, thus preventing platelet aggregation and making it a potent antiplatelet agent.

questions.text: What is the function of the muscle marked in the image below, at the metacarpophalangeal joint?(NEET PG  2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Flexion

 

  • The primary function of the muscle marked is to facilitate flexion of the finger at the metacarpophalangeal joint. Flexion involves bending the finger, reducing the angle between the metacarpal bone (in the palm) and the proximal phalanx (the first bone of the finger). This muscle contributes to the closing of the fingers into a grip.
  • Muscles Involved are Flexor Digitorum Profundus,  Flexor Digitorum Superficialis, Flexor Pollicis Longus , Flexor Carpi Ulnaris and Flexor Carpi Radialis: These muscles flex the wrist.

 

 

 

  • Lumbricals are the muscles that cause flexion at the metacarpophalangeal joints.
  • The tendons of the flexor digitorum profundus in the palm give rise to the 4 lumbrical (worm-like) muscles.
  • Medial two lumbricals are bipennate and originate from the flexor digitorum profundus tendons associated with the middle and ring fingers and the ring and little fingers, respectively;Supplied by the deep branch of the ulnar nerve
  • Lateral two lumbricals are unipennate muscles, originating from the flexor digitorum profundus tendons associated with index and middle fingers, respectively; Supplied by digital branches of the median nerve
  • The lumbrical muscles have tendons that pass over the outer side of each finger and attach to the extensor hood. They are located in front of the deep transverse metacarpal ligaments.

 

The muscle marked in the image, at the metacarpophalangeal joint, is likely involved in finger movement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Extension (Incorrect): Extension of the finger is the opposite movement of flexion. It involves straightening the finger, increasing the angle between the metacarpal bone and the proximal phalanx. The muscle in question is not primarily responsible for extension. Muscles Involved are Extensor Digitorum, Extensor Pollicis Longus , Extensor Carpi Ulnaris and Extensor Carpi Radialis.

 

Option C. Adduction (Incorrect): Adduction of the finger would involve moving the finger toward the midline or toward adjacent fingers. The muscle in the image is not oriented to perform adduction. Adduction of the fingers typically involves the intrinsic muscles of the hand, which are located within the hand itself

 

Option D. Abduction (Incorrect): Abduction of the finger would involve moving the finger away from the midline or away from adjacent fingers. The muscle in the image is not positioned to perform abduction. The specific muscles responsible for abduction are part of the dorsal interossei and palmar interossei muscle group

 

Educational Objective:

 

The lumbricals are essential for the flexion of the fingers at the metacarpophalangeal joints, contributing significantly to the dexterity and functional complexity of the hand, particularly in actions that require a combination of flexing and extending different joints of the fingers, such as typing or playing certain musical instruments.

questions.text: Which of the following can alter the gene expression by methylation and acetylation but not change the gene sequence? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Epigenetics

 

  • Epigenetics refers to the study of heritable changes in gene expression or cellular phenotype that do not involve alterations to the underlying DNA sequence. Epigenetic mechanisms, such as DNA methylation and histone acetylation, can modify gene expression by adding or removing chemical marks on DNA or histone proteins, thereby influencing how genes are activated or silenced. These changes can be passed from one generation of cells to the next, making them heritable.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mutation: Mutations are changes in the DNA sequence itself. They can result in alterations to the genetic code, potentially leading to changes in gene expression. Mutations are genetic changes and do not fall under the category of epigenetic modifications, which involve changes to gene expression without altering the underlying DNA sequence.

 

Option C. Translocation: Translocation involves the rearrangement of genetic material between non-homologous chromosomes. It can lead to changes in gene positioning but is not primarily associated with epigenetic modifications like methylation and acetylation.

 

Option D. Inversion: Inversion is a type of chromosomal rearrangement where a segment of a chromosome is reversed. Similar to translocation, it can result in changes in gene positioning but is not directly related to epigenetic modifications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Epigenetics has been defined and today is generally accepted as ‘‘the study of changes in gene function that are mitotically and/or meiotically heritable and that do not entail a change in DNA sequence.

 

Epigenetic modification of core histones (acetylation of specific lysine residues) facilitates an open structure and permits access to transcription factors for interaction with DNA. On the other hand, methylation at the CG sequence of the promoters transcriptionally inactivates chromatin.

questions.text: Identify the instrument given in the image below: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Morrison retractor

 

  • The Morrison retractor is a surgical instrument used in abdominal surgery to retract the liver and expose the retroperitoneal space.
  • The instrument consists of two curved blades that are inserted through a small incision in the abdominal wall and positioned over the liver.
  • The blades are then spread apart to provide a clear view of the surgical field.

 

Option A. Deaver's
 

Broad handheld retractor for large abdominal/thoracic incisions.

 

 

Option C. Czerny’s

 

 

Option D. Double Hook

 

 

Educational Objective:


The Morrison retractor is used during abdominal surgeries, specifically to retract the liver and expose the retroperitoneal space.

questions.text: What type of joint is formed between the costal cartilages of the 8th and 9th ribs as they articulate with the 7th rib? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Synovial joint

 

The interchondral joint between the attachment of the 8th and 9th rib with the 7th rib is a synovial joint.

 

  • Synovial joints are characterized by the presence of a synovial cavity containing synovial fluid, which lubricates the joint and allows for a wide range of movement.
  • While costovertebral joints are typically not classified as synovial joints, some costovertebral joints do have a limited degree of synovial joint characteristics, especially in the upper thoracic region.
  • While the costal cartilages themselves are cartilaginous structures, the joints between the 5th to 9th costal cartilages are specifically synovial in nature.
     

Joints in the thoracic cavity are of the following types:

 

  • Synarthrosis- A fibrous band of tissue connects the structures. E.g., 1st sternocostal joint
  • Synchondrosis - primary cartilaginous joints. E.g., costochondral joints
  • Symphysis - secondary cartilaginous joints. E.g., manubriosternal and xiphisternal joints
  • Synovial joints - the presence of these help the thoracic cavity expand during inspiration. E.g.:
    • Interchondral joint
    • Sternocostal joint
    • Costovertebral joint
    • Costotransverse joint

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fibrocartilaginous Joint:

 

  • Fibrocartilaginous joints are characterized by the presence of fibrocartilage, a type of cartilage that contains both fibrous and cartilaginous components.
  • Examples of fibrocartilaginous joints include the intervertebral discs in the spine and the pubic symphysis in the pelvis. These joints allow for limited movement and provide support and shock absorption.

 

Option B. Symphyseal Joint:

 

  • Symphyseal joints are a specific type of cartilaginous joint where two bones are joined by a broad, flat disc of fibrocartilage. These joints are typically immovable or have limited movement.
  • The pubic symphysis, mentioned earlier, is a common example of a symphyseal joint.

 

Option D. Fibrous Joint:

 

  • Fibrous joints are characterized by the presence of fibrous connective tissue between bones. They are immovable or allow for very limited movement.
  • Examples of fibrous joints include the sutures of the skull and the gomphosis joint between the teeth and their sockets.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: The adult form of echinococcus is seen in which of the following? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dog

 

The adult form of echinococcus is seen in dogs and other canis which are its definitive hosts.

 

The larval stage is passed in intermediate hosts such as sheep, cattle, goat, swine, horse, camel, and man.

 

Man acts as an accidental intermediate host (dead end).

 

Human infection follows the ingestion of eggs due to the intimate handling of dogs or by eating raw vegetables or other food contaminated with dog feces.

 

Note: Humans can become accidental definitive hosts, second intermediate hosts, or paratenic hosts for spirometra. These are cestodes belonging to the Diphyllobothriidae family. They cause a condition called sparagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cat: Incorrect, as cats are not typical definitive hosts for Echinococcus species.

 

Option C. Swine: Incorrect, swine serve as one of the intermediate hosts, not as definitive hosts where the adult tapeworms reside.

 

Option D. Sheep: Incorrect, similar to swine, sheep act as intermediate hosts where larval stages develop, not as definitive hosts for the adult form of the tapeworm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dogs are the definitive hosts for the adult form of Echinococcus, underscoring the importance of proper hygiene and preventive measures in areas where these animals are common to minimize the risk of transmission and subsequent human infection.

questions.text: 100-day glaucoma is seen in which of the following conditions? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Central retinal vein occlusion

 

  • Neovascular glaucoma (NVG) is also known as "90-" or "100-day glaucoma" due to its typical development 3 months after the onset of Central Retinal Vein Occlusion (CRVO).
  • NVG results from the occlusion of the central retinal vein, causing significant retinal ischemia and venous stasis.
  • Recurrent hemorrhages are common, and neovascularization of the retina and optic disc develop.
  • The retina undergoes pigmentary and atrophic changes.
  • NVG occurs in three stages:
    1. Pre-glaucomatous stage - stage of rubeosis iridis i.e. neovascularisation on the surface of the iris.
    2. Open-angle glaucoma stage - due to the formation of a pretrabecular neovascular membrane.
    3. Secondary angle closure glaucoma— due to goniosynechiae resulting from contracture of the neovascular membrane (zipper-angle closure).

 

 

  • Treatment of NVG is usually frustrating.
    • Pan-retinal photocoagulation may be carried out to prevent further neovascularization.
    • Medical therapy and conventional filtration surgery are usually not effective in controlling the IOP.
    • Artificial filtration shunt (valved/unvalved) may control the IOP.
  • Serious complications of central retinal vein occlusion are cystoid degeneration of the macula, optic atrophy, and hemorrhagic or neovascular glaucoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Eale’s disease: Eales disease, also known as "primary retinal periphlebitis" or "periphlebitis retinae," is a rare inflammatory disorder that primarily affects the blood vessels in the retina of the eye. It was first described by the British ophthalmologist Henry Eales in 1880, and the condition was subsequently named after him.

 

Eales disease typically occurs in young adults, often males, and is more prevalent in certain regions, including India. The exact cause of Eales disease is not well understood, but it is believed to have an immunological basis. Some theories suggest that it may be related to immune system dysfunction, possibly triggered by an underlying infection or other factors.

 

The main features of Eales disease include:

 

  1. Retinal Vasculitis: Inflammation of the small blood vessels (veins) in the retina. This can lead to retinal hemorrhages, exudates, and swelling, which can affect vision.
  2. Neovascularization: New, abnormal blood vessels may develop as a response to the damaged retinal vessels. These abnormal vessels can be fragile and prone to bleeding, leading to further vision problems.
  3. Vitreous Hemorrhage:
  4. Retinal Detachment: In some cases, Eales disease can lead to tractional retinal detachment.

 

The symptoms of Eales disease can vary and may include blurred vision, floaters, and reduced visual acuity. Diagnosis is typically made through a thorough clinical examination, which may include the use of imaging techniques like fundus fluorescein angiography to visualize the areas of capillary non-perfusion, leakage (suggestive of neovascularisation or macular edema).

 

The treatment of Eales disease aims to control inflammation, prevent or treat complications, and preserve or improve vision. Treatment options may include systemic or local corticosteroids to reduce inflammation and macular edema, intravitreal Anti VEGF injection for macular edema, laser photocoagulation therapy to target abnormal blood vessels, and in some cases, surgical intervention (pars plana vitrectomy) to address complications like retinal detachment and vitreous haemorrhage. The specific treatment plan will depend on the severity of the disease and the individual patient's needs.

 

It's important for individuals with Eales disease to receive ongoing care and follow-up with an ophthalmologist to monitor their condition and manage any potential complications. Causative association with tuberculosis is present and patient needs to be evaluated for TB and AKT may be initiated where indicated.

 

Option C. Central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO) is a medical condition that occurs when the central retinal artery becomes blocked or narrowed. This blockage results in a sudden and severe loss of vision in the affected eye. CRAO is considered a medical emergency because it can lead to permanent vision loss if not treated promptly.

 

Common causes and risk factors of central retinal artery occlusion include:

 

  1. Atherosclerosis: The most common cause of CRAO is atherosclerosis.
  2. Embolism:
  3. Giant cell arteritis: This is a condition in which the arteries, including the central retinal artery, become inflamed. It primarily affects older individuals and can result in CRAO. GCA is an emergency requiring prompt initiation of systemic steroids to prevent the fellow eye from developing CRAO.
  4. Vasculitis: Occlusive inflammation of the blood vessels can lead to occlusion of the central retinal artery.

 

Symptoms of central retinal artery occlusion may include:

 

  1. Sudden, painless, and severe vision loss in one eye.
  2. The affected eye may appear pale or whitened (retinal pallor).
  3. RAPD.
  4. Cherry-red spot: Due to the contrast between the well-oxygenated macula and the poorly oxygenated surrounding retina.

 

Treatment options may include:

 

  1. Ocular massage: to dislodge the embolus causing the blockage.
  2. Hyperbaric oxygen therapy: Breathing pure oxygen in a pressurized chamber can increase oxygen delivery to the retina and may be considered in some cases.
  3. Carbogen inhalation therapy or rebreathing into a paper bag – Resultant hypercarbemia causes vasodilation which may help to dislodge the embolus and restore blood flow.
  4. Reducing intraocular pressure – by means of Anterior Chamber paracentesis or systemic acetazolamide.
  5. Surgical intervention: Optic Nerve Sheath fenestration surgery.
  6. Thrombolytic therapy: In some situations, clot-dissolving medications may be used.

 

Option D. Steroid-induced glaucoma:

 

  • Description: Glaucoma resulting from prolonged use of corticosteroids.
  • Mechanism: Steroids can increase IOP by reducing the outflow of aqueous humor.
  • Symptoms: Gradual loss of peripheral vision, halos around lights, headache, eye pain.
  • Treatment: Reducing or discontinuing steroid use, using IOP-lowering medications.

  • Note: Steroid-induced glaucoma is not associated with neovascularization or termed as 100-day glaucoma.

     

Educational Objective:

 

Neovascular glaucoma, known as "100-day glaucoma," typically develops about three months after the onset of Central Retinal Vein Occlusion (CRVO) due to significant retinal ischemia and venous stasis leading to neovascularization.

questions.text: An example of a bacteriostatic drug is? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Linezolid

 

Linezolid is a drug that acts by inhibiting the protein synthesis by acting on the 50S ribosomal subunit. It is used against VRSA , MRSA. It is a bacteriostatic drug.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Aminoglycoside


Aminoglycosides, such as gentamicin and amikacin, are bactericidal drugs that inhibit protein synthesis by binding to the 30S ribosomal subunit, leading to the misreading of mRNA and subsequent bacterial death.

 

Option B. Vancomycin


Vancomycin is a bactericidal antibiotic that inhibits cell wall synthesis by binding to the D-alanyl-D-alanine terminus of cell wall precursor units. It is effective against gram-positive bacteria.

 

Option C. Metronidazole


Metronidazole is a bactericidal drug that works by disrupting bacterial DNA synthesis. It is effective against anaerobic bacteria and certain protozoa.

 

Educational Objective

 

Linezolid is an example of a bacteriostatic drug that inhibits protein synthesis by targeting the 50S ribosomal subunit. It is particularly useful against resistant gram-positive infections, including MRSA and VRSA.

choices.text: Wide excision of the lactiferous duct.

questions.text: Identify the surgical procedure that involves the removal of a small segment of the lactiferous duct, typically from the breast in which a probe is inserted into the duct from which the discharge is emerging. A tennis racquet incision is made, and the flap is dissected to reach the duct. The duct is then excised. This procedure is known as? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Microdochectomy

 

  • Microdochectomy is a surgical procedure that involves removing a discharging lactiferous duct.
  • The procedure is typically performed on patients with duct papilloma or duct ectasia involving a single duct.
  • During the procedure, a probe or stiff nylon suture is inserted into the duct from which the discharge is emerging.
  • An incision can be made in the shape of a tennis racquet to encompass the entire duct, or a periareolar incision may be used to access the duct by dissecting the nipple flap.
  • The affected duct is then excised or removed, and the tissue is sent for further evaluation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Macrodochectomy: Macrodochectomy refers to the removal of a larger or major segment of the lactiferous duct. This procedure can be undertaken when there are multiple pathologies within the duct, making it necessary to excise a more substantial portion of the duct system.

 

Option C. Cone excision: In breast surgery, it might mean the removal of a cone-shaped segment of tissue which includes a problematic area, such as a localized tumor. The goal is often to ensure that the margins of the removed tissue are clear of any pathological changes.

 

Option D. Wide excision of the lactiferous duct: This procedure involves removing a more extensive portion of the lactiferous duct, typically more than in a microdochectomy. The objective here might be to ensure that the entirety of a problematic duct or surrounding tissue is removed, especially if there is a concern about a larger segment of the duct being involved with a disease process.

 

Educational Objective:


Microdochectomy is the surgical removal of a discharging lactiferous duct, commonly performed for cases of single-duct pathologies like duct papilloma or duct ectasia.

questions.text: Coagulation profile monitoring is needed in therapy with which of the following drugs? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lepirudin

 

Lepirudin is a direct thrombin inhibitor that is used in multiple doses and produces unpredictable effects, that has the most serious side effect of bleeding. Therefore, it requires monitoring by aPTT.

 

Dabigatran is an oral direct thrombin inhibitor, Enoxaparin is a LMWH that acts by inhibiting factor Xa and factor IIa, whereas Fondaparinux acts only by inhibiting factor Xa only.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fondaparinux: Fondaparinux is a selective factor Xa inhibitor that does not usually require routine coagulation monitoring because it has a predictable anticoagulant response when used at standard doses.

 

Option B. Enoxaparin: Enoxaparin is a low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) that primarily inhibits factor Xa and to a lesser extent factor IIa (thrombin). Routine coagulation monitoring is generally not required with enoxaparin due to its predictable pharmacokinetic profile, though monitoring may be considered in certain populations (e.g., renal impairment, extremes of body weight).

 

Option C. Dabigatran: Dabigatran is an oral direct thrombin inhibitor that also does not typically require routine coagulation monitoring due to its predictable pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics. However, in specific clinical situations, such as suspected overdose or emergency surgery, monitoring may be necessary.

 

Educational Objective:

:

Lepirudin, a direct thrombin inhibitor, requires regular monitoring of the activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) due to its potential for unpredictable anticoagulant effects and the risk of serious bleeding.

questions.text: Fimbriectomy is also known as? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Kroner’s procedure

 

Explanation:

 

Fimbriectomy is a method of tubal ligation where the fimbriated end of the Fallopian tube is ligated and excised. This technique is also known as Kroner’s procedure.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Pomeroy technique: In this method, the mid-isthmic portion of the Fallopian tube is elevated and then folded at the midpoint. One or two rapidly absorbable sutures are tied around the double thickness of the tube, and the folded portion is excised sharply.

 

Option B. Uchida's procedure: This involves ligating and excising the midportion of the Fallopian tube. The utero-tubal serosa is then hydro-dissected, and the proximal tubal stump is pulled into the mesosalpinx. The peritoneum is closed over the proximal cut end of the tube.

 

Option D. Irving's procedure: In this method, the midportion of the Fallopian tube is ligated and excised. The proximal tubal stump is inserted into an incision made into the myometrium and securely sutured to bury the proximal stump in the myometrium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fimbriectomy, also known as Kroner's procedure, involves ligation and excision of the fimbriated end of the Fallopian tube.

 

Ref: Page no 497, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

choices.text: Iso-volumetric contraction
Slow filling at end of diastole
End of systole
Start of diastole

questions.text: 'c' wave in JVP is seen in which phase of cardiac cycle? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Iso-volumetric contraction

 

Explanation

 

'c' waves are produced by bulging of the tricuspid valve into the right atrium during the Iso-volumetric contraction of the right ventricle.

 

The isovolumetric contraction phase is characterized by a closed tricuspid valve and a still-closed pulmonary valve, which causes the pressure in the ventricle to rise rapidly without changing its volume.

 

 

Fig: Intra-arterial pressure changes during cardiac cycle. a, c, v= Positive wave x, x1, y= Negative waves

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Slow filling at end of diastole: Incorrect because this phase involves the heart filling with blood, not contracting.

 

Option C. End of systole: Incorrect as this phase corresponds to the onset of ventricular relaxation, not contraction.

 

Option D. Start of diastole: Incorrect because the start of diastole is marked by ventricular relaxation and opening of the atrioventricular valves for ventricular filling, not contraction.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Multifocal non-suppurative osteomyelitis is characterized by:(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Inflammation without purulent discharge

 

MULTIFOCAL NON-SUPPURATIVE OSTEOMYELITIS

 

  • Focal sterile inflammatory disease with prolonged, self-limiting and recurring episodes.
  • It is an auto-inflammatory disorder that causes bone pain due to inflammation in the bones not caused by infection. 
  • It has been associated with SAPHO syndrome (Synovitis, Acne, Pustulosis, palmo-plantar Hyperostosis and Osteitis).
  • Clinical features:
    • Tenderness in affected area
    • Some patients may develop arthritis
    • Fatigue
    • Chronic pain affecting quality of life
    • Delayed growth in some children
    • Night bone pain
    • Regional palpable swelling over bones with little overlying soft tissue
       
  • Despite the local and systemic signs of inflammation, there is no purulent discharge and microbes are seldom isolated. This is a diagnosis of exclusion.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Mildly elevated CRP and ESR
    • Positive ANA and HLA-B27
    • Elevated serum cytokines
    • Mildly elevated serum TNF-alpha and IL-6
       
  • Radiographic findings:
    • X-ray shows lytic bone lesions, sclerosis and hyperostosis.
    • MRI is the investigation of choice
    • Whole body MRI provides information about lesion distribution, soft tissue involvement, and/or possible involvement of additional organs
    • Bone biopsy reveals dense infiltrates of immune cells, bone lysis, fibrosis, and/or normal bone.
       
  • Treatment:
    • NSAIDs are first-line agents for quick symptomatic relief and control inflammation
    • Corticosteroids, DMARDs, anti-TNF agents, and bisphosphonates are effective in some patients

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Multifocal non-suppurative osteomyelitis is characterized by inflammation without any purulent discharge.

choices.text: Size more than 5.5 cm in males

questions.text: Which of the following are indications for surgical intervention in abdominal aortic aneurysms? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. All of the above

 

To summarize, each of the mentioned criteria - size, symptomatic presentation, and rapid growth - are indications for surgical intervention in abdominal aortic aneurysms. Thus, the answer is: D. All of the above.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Size more than 5.5 cm in males:  An abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) that is greater than 5.5 cm in diameter has an increased risk of rupture. The risk of rupture and complications rises significantly as the size of the aneurysm increases. For this reason, surgical intervention is typically recommended when an AAA reaches this size in males.

 

Option B. Patient is experiencing abdominal pain: Abdominal pain can be a sign that the aneurysm is expanding or is about to rupture. If a patient presents with abdominal pain and an AAA, it's often treated as a surgical emergency. The pain might be caused by the aneurysm pressing on surrounding structures or due to impending rupture.

 

Option C. Expansion of >0.5 cm within 6 months: Rapid expansion of an AAA is another indicator of increased rupture risk. An expansion of more than 0.5 cm in 6 months indicates that the aneurysm is growing quickly. Rapid growth can be a sign of structural changes in the aneurysm wall that increase the risk of rupture. Therefore, even if the AAA is smaller than the usual 5.5 cm threshold, if it's growing quickly, surgical intervention is typically considered.

 

Educational Objective:


Abdominal aortic aneurysms require surgical intervention if the size exceeds 5.5 cm in males, the patient presents with abdominal pain, or if there is an expansion of more than 0.5 cm within 6 months.

choices.text: Angiotensin II

questions.text: cGMP is the second messenger of? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. NO (nitric oxide)

 

Explanation

 

Vasodilatory actions of NO are mediated by CGMP.

 

Hormone-receptor complex activates the enzymes of the cell and causes the formation of another substance called the second messenger or intracellular hormonal mediator.

 

Second messenger produces the effects of the hormone inside the cells. Protein hormones and the catecholamines act through second messenger. Most common second messenger is cyclic AMP.

 

NO activates guanylyl cyclase in vascular smooth muscle cells resulting in the conversion of cGTP to cGMP (2nd messenger) which activates cGMP dependent protein kinase, that causes blood vessels to relax.

 

Cyclic GMP is synthesized from the nucleotide GTP using the enzyme guanylyl cyclase. Cyclic GMP serves as the second messenger for

 

  1. atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP)
  2. nitric oxide (NO)
  3. the response of the rods of the retina to light

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Somatostatin: Incorrect because somatostatin typically acts through inhibition of adenylate cyclase, thus reducing cyclic AMP (cAMP) levels, not through cGMP.

 

Option B. Angiotensin II: Incorrect as angiotensin II primarily acts through the phosphatidylinositol signaling pathway and does not utilize cGMP as a second messenger.

 

Option C. ADH: Incorrect because antidiuretic hormone (ADH) primarily utilizes cAMP as its second messenger, particularly in its renal actions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nitric oxide (NO) uses cGMP as its second messenger to mediate vasodilation. NO activates guanylyl cyclase, increasing cGMP levels in vascular smooth muscle cells, leading to vessel relaxation. This highlights cGMP's role in cardiovascular function and its importance in the regulation of blood pressure.

questions.text: A colonoscopy on an 80-year-old patient revealed brownish pigmented lesions, as shown below. He admitted to using laxatives on a regular basis. Which of the following laxatives is most likely to be the source of this problem? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Senna

 

The given image shows the colonoscopy finding of melanosis coli.

 

The use of stimulant purgatives like Senna , Cascara Sagrada and Bisacodyl can lead to the development of melanosis coli. Also they should not be used for more than 10 days due to the risk of developing atonic colon.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bran: Bran is a bulk-forming laxative that increases stool bulk and promotes regular bowel movements. It does not cause melanosis coli.

 

Option B. Psyllium: Psyllium is another bulk-forming laxative that absorbs water into the stool, making it easier to pass. It does not lead to melanosis coli.

 

Option D. Methylcellulose: Methylcellulose is a bulk-forming fiber laxative that works by absorbing water and increasing stool bulk. It is not associated with melanosis coli.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic use of stimulant laxatives like Senna can lead to melanosis coli, characterized by brownish-black pigmentation of the colonic mucosa seen on colonoscopy.

choices.text: Carcinoid tumor
Gastrointestinal stromal tumor

questions.text: Which of the following is an epithelial tumor of the stomach? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Gastric adenocarcinoma

 

Gastric adenocarcinoma is an epithelial tumor of the stomach.

 

Adenocarcinoma is the most common malignancy (90% cases) of the stomach.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Carcinoid tumor: This is a neuroendocrine tumor.

 

Option B. Lymphoma: Represents a type of blood cancer originating from lymphocytes.

 

Option C. Gastrointestinal stromal tumor: A non-epithelial tumor that arises from the interstitial cells of Cajal in the gastrointestinal tract.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Increasing renal blood flow
Increasing afferent arteriole resistance
Increasing GFR
Both B and C

questions.text: Kidney responds to shock by: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Increasing afferent arteriole resistance

 

Explanation

 

Kidney responds to shock by increasing afferent arteriolar resistance.

 

Both afferent and efferent arterioles are constricted, but the efferent vessels are constricted to a greater degree. Increased resistance of afferent arterioles reduces glomerular hydrostatic pressure and decreases GFR. The glomerular filtration rate is reduced, but renal plasma flow is reduced to a larger extent, thus increasing the filtration fraction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increasing renal blood flow: Incorrect because renal blood flow actually decreases as part of the body's effort to conserve blood for vital organs.

 

Option C. Increasing GFR: Incorrect as GFR decreases due to increased afferent arteriolar resistance.

 

Option D. Both B and C: Incorrect because, while increasing afferent arteriole resistance is correct, increasing GFR is not.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During shock, the kidneys respond by increasing afferent arteriole resistance, leading to reduced glomerular hydrostatic pressure and a decrease in GFR. This adaptation helps conserve blood flow and maintain systemic circulation critical for survival in shock conditions.

questions.text: Which of the following muscles functions as a tensor of the vocal cords? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Cricothyroid

 

Cricothyroid is a tensor of vocal cord.

 

The cricothyroid muscle is primarily responsible for lengthening and tensing the vocal cords. When this muscle contracts, it pulls the thyroid cartilage forward and down towards the cricoid cartilage, which results in elongation and tensioning of the vocal cords. This action increases the pitch of the voice. Because of its role in tensioning the vocal cords, the cricothyroid is sometimes referred to as a tensor of the vocal cords.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lateral cricoarytenoid: The lateral cricoarytenoid muscles are responsible for adducting the vocal cords. When these muscles contract, they rotate the arytenoid cartilages medially, which causes the vocal cords to come together. This action is crucial for phonation (production of sound), as the vocal cords must be close together to vibrate against each other. However, the lateral cricoarytenoids do not play a direct role in the tensioning or relaxation of the vocal cords.

 

Option C. Thyroarytenoids: The thyroarytenoids are the primary muscles within the vocal cords themselves. They have two parts: the thyrovocalis (medial) and the thyromuscularis (lateral). The thyrovocalis is involved in the shortening and tensioning of the vocal cords, leading to a decrease in pitch. In contrast, the thyromuscularis aids in relaxing and thickening the cords, which lowers the pitch. Together, they play a critical role in controlling pitch and the quality of the voice.

 

Option D. Posterior cricoarytenoids: The posterior cricoarytenoid muscles are the primary muscles responsible for abducting or opening the vocal cords. They rotate the arytenoid cartilages laterally, which pulls the vocal cords apart. This action is vital for breathing, as the vocal cords must be open for air to flow into the lungs.

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: What is the best contrast agent for the diagnosis of esophageal perforation? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Iohexol

 

Barium contrast is contraindicated in esophageal perforation as it causes mediastinitis.

 

Iodinated contrast is safe for suspected GI perforation or trachea-esophageal fistula where barium is contraindicated. Iohexol (low osmolar) is preferred over Gastrograffin (high-osmolar) as it has a high chance of causing aspiration pneumonitis and pulmonary edema.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gastrograffin: While also iodine-based and water-soluble, Gastrograffin is a high-osmolar contrast agent that can be riskier in cases of perforation due to the potential for causing severe pulmonary complications if aspirated.

 

Option C. Gadolinium: Gadolinium is primarily used in magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and is not suitable for gastrointestinal tract imaging, especially in the context of suspected perforations.

 

Option D. Barium sulphate: Although providing high-quality imaging, barium sulphate is contraindicated in cases of suspected perforations due to its potential to cause severe inflammatory reactions if it escapes into the mediastinal or pleural spaces.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: One basic health worker per 10,000 population
Responsibility of PHCs in malaria eradication

questions.text: The Chadah committee suggested all of the following options except: [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) One PHC for 50,000 population 

 

  • The correct answer, "B. One PHC for 50,000 populations," refers to a recommendation actually made by the Kartar Singh Committee, not the Chadah Committee. 
  • The Chadah Committee was established to assess the necessary arrangements for the Maintenance Phase of the National Malaria Eradication Program (NMEP). 
  • It emphasized integrating vigilance operations of the NMEP within general health services, specifically through PHCs at the block level, and allocating health workers specifically for malaria vigilance, among other public health tasks.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Divalent Metal Transporter 1
Divalent Metal Transporter 2

questions.text: What is the transporter of iron into enterocytes? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Divalent Metal Transporter 1

 

Explanation

 

Iron uptake into enterocytes is primarily facilitated by the Divalent Metal Transporter 1 (DMT1), which actively transports ferrous iron (Fe2+) across the apical membrane of these cells. The process involves several steps:

 

  1. Reduction of Iron: Luminal non-heme iron, predominantly in the ferric (Fe3+) state, must first be reduced to ferrous (Fe2+) iron. This reduction is carried out by ferrireductases like b cytochromes and STEAP3.
  2. Transport via DMT1: Once reduced to Fe2+, iron is transported into the enterocytes through DMT1 located on the apical membrane.
  3. Exit from Enterocytes: After crossing into the enterocyte, Fe2+ destined for the circulation is exported across the basolateral membrane by Ferroportin. This export is coupled with the oxidation of Fe2+ back to Fe3+ by iron oxidases such as hephaestin and ceruloplasmin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ferroportin 1: Incorrect as Ferroportin is responsible for the export of iron from enterocytes into the blood, not for iron uptake into enterocytes.

 

Option B. Hephaestin: Incorrect because hephaestin is involved in the oxidation of Fe2+ to Fe3+ during iron export from enterocytes, not in the uptake.

 

Option D. Divalent Metal Transporter 2: Incorrect as DMT2 is not the primary transporter involved in the uptake of iron into enterocytes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Divalent Metal Transporter 1 (DMT1) is critical for the uptake of ferrous iron (Fe2+) into enterocytes from the intestinal lumen, functioning in conjunction with enzymes that reduce ferric (Fe3+) to ferrous (Fe2+) iron.

choices.text: Can occur in association with diabetes
Associated with sclerodactyly and Raynaud’s phenomenon
The dermis is 3-4 times thicker than normal
Erythema and peau d'orange appearance of the skin can be seen

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding scleredema?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Associated with sclerodactyly or Raynaud’s phenomenon.

 

Sclerodactyly and Raynaud’s Phenomenon are associated with Scleroderma (NOT with scleredema).

 

Scleredema & Scleroderma are different diseases.

 

 

Scleredema is not associated with sclerodactyly, Raynaud’s phenomenon, nail fold capillary changes or serum autoantibodies.

 

Scleredema:

Synonyms - Scleredema adultorum of Buschke, Scleredema Diabeticorum.

 

  • Scleredema results in taut skin with noticeable symmetrical, diffuse progressive, non-pitting induration. This is because the dermis has expanded, mucin has been deposited, and the subcutaneous fat has been replaced by coarse collagen fibers.
  • It commonly presents with erythema and induration on the posterior neck and back, along with a peau d'orange appearance of the skin. Interestingly, the hands and feet remain unaffected.
  • The condition is characterized by a 3-4 times thicker dermis than usual, caused by dysfunctional fibroblasts leading to increased type 1 collagen synthesis, but without fibroblast proliferation.

 

The most prevalent type of this condition is associated with diabetes mellitus, and it is more commonly found in men compared to other forms that are more frequently seen in women. The accumulation of collagen is attributed to irreversible glycosylation of collagen and its resistance to degradation by collagenase.

 

 

  • Against an erythematous backdrop, the image depicts scleredema in a diabetic patient with firm, non-pitting edema with induration on the upper back, neck, and shoulders.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Can occur in association with diabetes: True, as scleredema is commonly associated with diabetes, where the glycosylation of collagen contributes to the pathology.

 

Option C. The dermis is 3-4 times thicker than normal: True, reflecting the histological changes in scleredema, including mucin deposition and increased type 1 collagen synthesis.

 

Option D. Erythema and peau d'orange appearance of the skin can be seen: True, these are characteristic cutaneous manifestations of scleredema, indicating the skin's texture and appearance changes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference: Bolognia 4th edition, chapter 46, page no 870

Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 59 page no 59.09 - 59.11.

Question Level – HARD

Question Id-7440 Unique Key-Q1728345

questions.text: What is the odor of a mummified body? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Odorless

 

A mummified body is characterized by the absence of moisture, leading to its preservation. This process results in the body becoming dry and leathery, which eliminates the conditions necessary for the growth of bacteria responsible for producing foul odors.

 

Mummification:

 

  • Odor: Mummified bodies are odorless due to the absence of moisture, which inhibits bacterial growth and decomposition.
  • Appearance: The body becomes dry and leathery, preserving it in a desiccated state.

 

Comparison with Other Types of Decomposition:

 

  • Adipocere Formation:
    • Odor: An adipocere body has a foul, rancid smell similar to decomposing fats.
    • Formation: Adipocere, also known as "grave wax," forms when body fat undergoes a chemical transformation into a waxy substance, typically in moist environments.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pungent: This odor is might be present in cases of certain chemical exposures or other types of decomposition.

 

Option C. Putrid: This odor is characteristic of bodies undergoing typical decomposition, where bacterial activity produces foul-smelling gases.

 

Option D. Offensive: Similar to putrid, this term describes the unpleasant odors produced during the normal decomposition process.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A mummified body is odorless due to its dry and preserved state, an adipocere body which has foul rancid smell (like decomposing fats)

questions.text:
A 16-year-old girl with primary amenorrhea has the following features. What is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2018)

 

  • Normal stature
  • Thelarche - absent
  • FSH, LH - high
  • Karyotype - 46 XX
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gonadal dysgenesis

 

Explanation:

 

The probable diagnosis in this case is pure gonadal dysgenesis. Primary amenorrhea with absent secondary sexual characteristics (thelarche) and high levels of FSH and LH indicate hypergonadotropic hypogonadism, which suggests an ovarian cause. The karyotype 46 XX confirms gonadal dysgenesis.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Testicular feminizing syndrome/Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome

 

  • This condition occurs in individuals with a 46 XY karyotype.
  • Individuals with this syndrome have absent uterus and ovaries and exhibit secondary sexual development, especially breast development, due to peripheral production of estrogens.

 

Option C. Kallmann Syndrome

 

  • This is a cause of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism leading to primary amenorrhea.
  • It is associated with anosmia and absent secondary sexual characteristics.
  • FSH and LH levels are low in this condition.

 

Option D. Turner Syndrome

 

  • Characterized by a 45 XO karyotype.
  • Individuals have streak ovaries leading to low estrogen levels and absent secondary sexual characteristics.
  • FSH and LH levels are high.
  • A very important feature is short stature, which is not seen in the patient described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary amenorrhea with high FSH and LH levels and a 46 XX karyotype indicates gonadal dysgenesis.

 

Ref: Page no 454, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

choices.text: 200-400 ml of ORS to be given in the first four hours.
400-700 ml of ORS to be given in the first four hours.
700-900 ml of ORS to be given in the first 4 hours.
In addition to the usual fluid intake, 100-200 ml should be given after each loose stool.

questions.text: What is the recommended treatment for a 9-month-old baby with diarrhea, who is feeding adequately, thirsty, and exhibits skin that returns to normal after a pinch within 2 seconds? [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) 400-700 ml of ORS to be given in the first four hours. 

 

  • According to the IMNCI classification, the baby has some dehydration and comes under Plan B. The amount of ORS given is 75ml/kg body weight.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a 9-month-old baby showing signs of some dehydration due to diarrhea, it is crucial to administer 400-700 ml of ORS over the first four hours, adhering to IMNCI guidelines. This approach ensures effective initial rehydration and sets the stage for ongoing recovery and feeding.

questions.text: Which of the options is considered the most peripheral center under the Revised National Tuberculosis Control Programme? [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Designated Microscopy Centre 

 

  • Among the given options, the most peripheral center under the Revised National Tuberculosis Control Programme organization structure is the Designated Microscopy Centre (DMC). This remains same for the new National TB Elimination Program 2020 too.
  • The DMC is the first point of contact for patients seeking diagnosis and treatment for tuberculosis (TB) and is responsible for collecting sputum samples and conducting smear microscopy to detect the presence of TB bacteria. The DMCs are established at the periphery level of the healthcare system, such as at the level of Primary Health Centers or Community Health Centers, to ensure that TB diagnosis and treatment services are accessible to people in their own communities.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. District TB Centre: This option is higher up in the hierarchy than the DMC. It is responsible for the supervision and monitoring of TB control activities within the district, making it central but not the most peripheral.
 

Option B. Intermediate Reference Laboratory:  The IRL provides quality assurance for TB diagnosis and conducts drug susceptibility testing. It is a specialized facility that supports the network by confirming diagnoses and resistance patterns, placed higher in the organizational hierarchy than DMCs.
 

Option C. Tuberculosis Unit:  While the Tuberculosis Unit is responsible for providing treatment and care to TB patients, it is not as peripheral as the DMC. The TU operates within a more integrated role in patient management and care continuum than the DMC, which is strictly focused on initial diagnostics.

 

Educational Objective:  

 

The Designated Microscopy Centre (DMC) remains a foundational component in the RNTCP for its role in accessible, community-level TB diagnosis and initial management. Its position as the most peripheral center in the hierarchy underscores its critical function in early TB detection and intervention.

questions.text: Stellate granuloma is seen in: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cat scratch disease

 

Stellate granuloma is seen in cat-scratch disease. It is also called as subacute regional lymphadenitis.

 

It is a bacterial infection caused by Bartonella henselae. Acquired following contact with infected animals (commonly cats).

 

Regional lymph nodes demonstrate:

 

  • Follicular hyperplasia with circumscribed central stellate necrosis with neutrophils
  • Surrounded by palisading histiocytes (suppurative granulomas)
  • Sinuses packed with monocytoid B cells
  • Usually, there are no perifollicular and intrafollicular epithelioid cells

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following nerves is preferred in anesthesia to monitor neuromuscular blockade? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ulnar Nerve

 

  • The ulnar nerve is the most commonly used nerve for monitoring neuromuscular blockade in the clinical setting.
  • By stimulating this nerve, we can observe the twitch response of the adductor pollicis muscle in the hand, which is representative of deeper muscles like the diaphragm and laryngeal muscles.
  • The ulnar nerve is easily accessible and provides consistent responses.

 

Why it's preferred:

 

  • Neuromuscular monitoring aims to ensure that patients have adequate muscle paralysis during surgery and complete recovery from paralysis before waking up.
  • The ulnar nerve-adductor pollicis muscle combination has a similar sensitivity to neuromuscular blocking drugs as the diaphragm and laryngeal muscles, which are critical for breathing and airway protection.
  • Using a Train of Four monitor or peripheral nerve stimulator, the ulnar nerve is stimulated to observe the twitch response, allowing anesthesiologists to gauge the depth of neuromuscular blockade and adjust drug dosages accordingly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Median Nerve: The median nerve is less commonly used for neuromuscular monitoring because it does not provide as consistent or reliable a response as the ulnar nerve. The muscle response to stimulation of the median nerve may not accurately reflect the status of deeper muscles.

 

Option C. Radial Nerve: The radial nerve innervates muscles that primarily affect the extension of the wrist and fingers. While it can be used for monitoring, it is not the preferred choice because it is less sensitive to neuromuscular blocking agents compared to the ulnar nerve.

 

Option D. Mandibular Nerve: The mandibular nerve is not used for monitoring neuromuscular blockade in the clinical setting. It is part of the trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V) and does not provide a useful twitch response for assessing neuromuscular blockade.

 

Educational Objective :

 

  • The ulnar nerve is the preferred nerve for monitoring neuromuscular blockade in anesthesia due to its accessibility and reliable twitch response of the adductor pollicis muscle, which reflects the status of critical muscles like the diaphragm and laryngeal muscles.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 834

questions.text: A newborn baby refuses breast milk since the 2nd day of birth but accepts glucose water. He develops vomiting and severe jaundice by the 5th day. Benedict's test was positive for urine and blood glucose was low. The most likely cause is due to the deficiency of?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase

 

  • Deficiency of GALT is the primary cause of classic galactosemia, which results in the accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate in the body and leads to the symptoms described.

 

Classical Galactosemia:

 

  • It is an autosomal recessive in born error of metabolism due to deficiency of enzyme galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase.

 

 

  • Due to the block in this enzyme, galactose-1- phosphate will accumulate in liver. This will inhibit galactokinase as well as glycogen phosphorylase. Hypoglycemia is the result.
  • Bilirubin uptake is less and bilirubin conjugation is reduced; so unconjugated bilirubin level is increased in blood.
  • There is enlargement of liver, jaundice and severe mental retardation.
  • Free galactose accumulates, leading to galactosemia. It is partly excreted in urine (galactosuria).
  • Galactose is reduced to dulcitol. The accumulation of dulcitol in the lens results in cataract due to its osmotic effect. This is called congenital cataract and is a very characteristic feature of galactosemia.
  • Galactose-1-phosphate may get deposited in renal tubules, producing tubular damage leading to generalized amino aciduria.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Clinical manifestation including congenital cataract and presence of galactose in urine (positive benedicts test) as well as elevated blood galactose levels will help in the diagnosis.
    • Collection of fetal cells by amniocentesis may be useful in prenatal diagnosis. Heterozygous parents could be detected by elevated galactose level in blood after a galactose load.
  • Treatment: 
    • If lactose is withdrawn from the diet, most of the symptoms recede. But mental retardation, when established, will not improve. Hence early detection is most important. For affected infant lactose-free diet is given. Such special diets may be withdrawn after 4 years, when galactose-1-phosphate pyro phosphorylase becomes active.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aldose reductase: Aldose reductase is not directly related to galactose metabolism and is not the cause of galactosemia.

 

Option B. Galactokinase: Galactokinase deficiency leads to another form of galactosemia known as Type II Galactosemia, which is characterized by elevated levels of galactose and galactitol in the blood and tissues. It does not typically present with the same symptoms as described in the case.

 

Option D. UDP galactose-4-epimerase: UDP galactose-4-epimerase deficiency leads to another form of galactosemia known as Type III Galactosemia, which is characterized by elevated levels of galactose-1-phosphate and UDP-galactose. It does not typically present with the same symptoms as described in the case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase deficiency, or classic galactosemia, is a severe metabolic disorder marked by an inability to metabolize galactose properly, leading to serious systemic symptoms including jaundice, hypoglycemia, and liver dysfunction. Early diagnosis and management through dietary adjustments are crucial for preventing long-term complications.

questions.text: What levels of prolactin are definitely suggestive of prolactinoma? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. > 200 ug/L

 

Prolactin levels greater than 200 ug/L are definitely suggestive of a prolactinoma. This level typically indicates the presence of a prolactin-secreting pituitary adenoma. The significant elevation in prolactin can cause clinical symptoms such as galactorrhea and amenorrhea in women, or hypogonadism in men. The diagnosis is further supported by imaging studies such as MRI, which can visualize the adenoma.

 

Additional Information

 

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Kills the sperms in the cervical canal

questions.text: Which of the following is not the mechanism of action of progesterone only pills? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Kills the sperms in the cervical canal

 

Explanation:

 

Progesterone only pills (POPs), also known as mini pills, act through several mechanisms to prevent pregnancy, but they do not kill sperms in the cervical canal.

 

Incorrect. Progesterone only pills do not have a spermicidal effect. They do not kill sperm; instead, they work by altering the cervical mucus and preventing ovulation.

 

The mechanisms of action include:

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thickening the cervical mucus: This makes it difficult for sperm to enter the uterus and fertilize an egg.

 

Option B. Preventing ovulation: Although not as consistently as combined oral contraceptives, POPs can inhibit ovulation in some women.

 

Option D. Inhibiting penetration of sperm: By thickening the cervical mucus and affecting the endometrial lining, POPs inhibit the sperm’s ability to penetrate and fertilize an egg.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Progesterone only pills prevent pregnancy by thickening cervical mucus, inhibiting ovulation, and preventing sperm penetration, but they do not kill sperm in the cervical canal.

 

Ref: Page no 323, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

choices.text: The extent does not cross the wound margins
Wide excision of the keloid scar prevents recurrence
Histopathology of a keloid scar shows reduced collagen and increased vascularity
A keloid scar forms due to increase in the level of growth factors

questions.text: A patient visits the clinic and presents with a raised and firm scar on their chest, which is larger than the original wound. The physician suspects a keloid scar and begins to explain the diagnosis and potential treatment options. Which of the following statements are true with regards to a keloid scar?  (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. A keloid scar forms due to increase in the level of growth factors

 

A keloid scar forms due to an increase in the level of growth factors: This statement is true. Keloid scars are thought to develop due to an overproduction of growth factors, such as transforming growth factor-beta (TGF-beta), which stimulate the production of collagen and other extracellular matrix components. This abnormal healing response results in the excessive growth of scar tissue beyond the original wound margin.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The extent does not cross the wound margins: This statement is not true. Keloid scars are characterized by an excessive growth of fibrous tissue beyond the original wound margin. They tend to be larger, more raised, and thicker than the original wound.

 

Option B. Wide excision of the keloid scar prevents recurrence: This statement is also not entirely true. While surgical removal of keloid scars can be effective, the risk of recurrence is high, and the scar may actually grow larger than the original one.

 

Option C. Histopathology of a keloid scar shows reduced collagen and increased vascularity: This statement is not true. Keloid scars are characterized by an overproduction of collagen, which leads to the thick and raised appearance of the scar. There may also be increased vascularity within the scar.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Keloid scars are caused by an overproduction of growth factors like TGF-β, leading to excessive collagen formation and scar tissue that extends beyond the wound margins.

questions.text: What is the most common extra-articular manifestation of rheumatoid arthritis? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Subcutaneous nodules

 

Subcutaneous nodules are the most common extra-articular manifestation of rheumatoid arthritis (RA), occurring in 20-30% of cases, usually in seropositive patients. These nodules often appear on extensor surfaces, such as the elbows, or in other areas subject to pressure, and they can also manifest in internal organs like the lungs and heart. Their presence correlates with a more severe disease course and is associated with specific RA antibodies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sjogren's syndrome: While Sjogren's syndrome (secondary to RA) can occur and manifests as keratoconjunctivitis sicca, it is less common than subcutaneous nodules as an extra-articular feature.

 

Option C. Felty's syndrome: This is a rare complication of long-standing RA, characterized by neutropenia and splenomegaly, and occurs in about 1% of patients.

 

Option D. Vasculitis: Cutaneous vasculitis may present in RA but is less frequently observed compared to subcutaneous nodules. It includes symptoms like ulcers and purpura.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Additional Information Deformities

 

1. Pseudo Deformities

 

 

2. True Deformities

 

 

Reference - Pocket Medicine 8E/2022

questions.text: The Gold's criteria for very severe COPD is: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 < 30%

 

Option A:

 

According to the GOLD (Global Initiative for Chronic Obstructive Lung Disease) criteria for staging chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), very severe COPD is classified as Stage IV. This stage is defined by a FEV1/FVC ratio (forced expiratory volume in one second/forced vital capacity) less than 0.7, which indicates the presence of airflow limitation, and a FEV1 less than 30% of the predicted value. This level of FEV1 signifies a very severe reduction in lung function and typically corresponds with significant symptoms and health status impairment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Note:

 

  • Currently Class C+D have been combined and called Class E
  • Classification of types have been updated.

 

Reference: GOLD 2023 guidelines

questions.text: Viral infection causing transient aplastic anemia is: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Parvovirus B-19

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Parvovirus B19 infection targets erythroid cell lines, particularly the pronormoblast stage, and is known to cause transient aplastic anemia, particularly in patients with underlying hemolytic disorders, as well as other clinical manifestations such as erythema infectiosum, arthritis, and non-immune fetal hydrops.

questions.text: What is the proportion of disease occurrence among those who were exposed compared to those who were not exposed? [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Relative risk 

 

The ratio of incidence of disease or death among exposed to that among the non-exposed is called relative risk (RR).

 

 

Interpretation of RR

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Attributable risk (AR):  is the difference in the risk of disease between the exposed and non-exposed groups, and represents the proportion of disease that can be attributed to the exposure.

 

Option B. Odds ratio (OR):  is the ratio of the odds of disease in the exposed group to the odds of disease in the non-exposed group.

 

Option D. Population attributable risk (PAR):  is the proportion of disease cases in the population that can be reduced if risk factor is modified or eliminated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Relative Risk (RISK RATIO) is used to estimate risk of disease (calculated as incidence of that disease) with exposure to a factor
  • Relative risk (RR) IS A BETTER ESTIMATE of strength of association than Attributable risk (AR)
  • Strength of association:
    • Relative risk (cohort study)
    • Odds ratio (case control study)

choices.text: Abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis
Abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis longus
Abductor pollicis brevis and extensor pollicis longus
Abductor pollicis brevis and extensor pollicis brevis

questions.text: de-Quervain’s tenosynovitis involves tendon sheath of which two muscles? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis

 

DE QUERVAIN’S TENOSYNOVITIS

 

  • The abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis tendons may become inflamed beneath the retinacular pulley at the radial styloid within the first extensor compartment.
  • Finkelstein’s test is pathognomonic. The examiner places patient’s thumb across the palm in full flexion, and then holding the patient’s hand firmly, turns the wrist sharply into adduction. In positive test this is acutely painful; repeating the movement with the opposite thumb is relatively painless.

 

 

Finkelstein’s test – de Quervain’s tenosynovitis

 

  • Differential diagnosis: 
    • Scaphoid non-union
    • Arthritis at the base of thumb
    • Intersection syndrome
       
  • Treatment includes NSAIDs with splint. If it fails, then steroid injection into tendon sheath and if not relieved then treatment consists of splitting the thickened tendon sheath.

 

Educational Objective:

 

De Quervain’s tenosynovitis is the inflammation of the tendons of abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis.

questions.text: Which of the following acts by causing both decreased bone resorption and increased bone formation? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Strontium ranelate

 

Strontium ranelate is a unique agent used in the treatment of osteoporosis. It has a dual mode of action: it decreases bone resorption and simultaneously increases bone formation. This dual effect is beneficial in managing osteoporosis, as it helps to improve bone density and strength by promoting a balanced bone remodeling process.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ibandronate: Ibandronate is a bisphosphonate that primarily acts by reducing bone resorption. It inhibits osteoclast activity, leading to decreased bone turnover and increased bone mineral density.

 

Option C. Teriparatide: Teriparatide is a recombinant form of parathyroid hormone (PTH) that primarily stimulates bone formation. It acts on osteoblasts, increasing their activity and promoting new bone formation.

 

Option D. Calcitonin: Calcitonin decreases bone resorption by inhibiting osteoclast activity. It is used in the treatment of conditions like osteoporosis and Paget's disease but does not significantly promote bone formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Strontium ranelate is unique among osteoporosis treatments in that it both decreases bone resorption and increases bone formation, making it a valuable option for improving bone health in patients with osteoporosis. Other drugs like ibandronate and calcitonin primarily focus on reducing bone resorption, while teriparatide promotes bone formation.

choices.text: Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria
Chediak-Higashi syndrome
Essential thrombocythemia

questions.text: CD-59 is involved in: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria

 

CD-59 is involved in paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH).

 

PNH is an acquired red cell membrane disorder characterized by chronic intravascular hemolysis. The absence of two proteins, decay accelerating factor (DAF, CD55) and membrane inhibitor of reactive lysis (MIRL, CD59), makes RBCs overly sensitive to complement's lytic effect.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Chediak-Higashi syndrome: This is a genetic disorder affecting the immune and nervous systems, characterized by abnormalities in lysosomal trafficking, leading to abnormal neutrophil function and albinism.

 

Option C. Essential thrombocythemia: A myeloproliferative disorder characterized by the excessive production of platelets without a known cause.

 

Option D. Primary myelofibrosis: Another myeloproliferative disorder where the bone marrow is progressively replaced with fibrous tissue.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CD-59 deficiency is specific to PNH and does not play a role in Chediak-Higashi syndrome, essential thrombocythemia, or primary myelofibrosis.

choices.text: It is involved in the creation of Okazaki fragments
It is the primary enzyme of DNA synthesis

questions.text: Which of the following is true about DNA polymerase I? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It is found in prokaryotes

 

This statement is correct. DNA polymerase I is primarily found in prokaryotic organisms, including bacteria. In prokaryotes, it plays a crucial role in DNA replication and repair.

 

Additional Information –

 

DNA polymerase I (Kornberg’s enzyme) from Escherichia coli (prokaryote). It is a repair  enzyme. It has both 3′ to 5′ and 5′ to 3′ exonuclease activities. When 5′ to 3′ exonuclease domain is removed, the remaining fragment retains the polymerization and proofreading activities; it is then called Klenow fragment. It is widely used in recombinant DNA technology.

 

DNA polymerases I, II, and III are prokaryotic polymerases.

 

DNA polymerase II: DNA proofreading and repair.

 

DNA polymerase III: Main replication enzyme in bacteria

 

In mammalian cells (eukaryotic), there are 5 DNA polymerases (DNAPs) named as α, β, γ, δ and ε.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is involved in the creation of Okazaki fragments: DNA polymerase I main function is to remove RNA primers from Okazaki fragments and fill the gaps with DNA nucleotides. The synthesis of Okazaki fragments is primarily carried out by DNA polymerase III in prokaryotes.

 

Option C. It synthesizes RNA primers: DNA polymerase I does not synthesize RNA primers. Instead, it removes RNA primers by its 5' to 3' exonuclease activity as part of the primer removal process during DNA replication.

 

Option D. It is the primary enzyme of DNA synthesis: This statement is not true. While DNA polymerase I is involved in DNA replication, it is not the primary enzyme responsible for DNA synthesis. In prokaryotes, DNA polymerase III is the primary enzyme responsible for DNA synthesis during replication.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DNA polymerase I is a critical enzyme found in prokaryotes, involved in DNA replication and repair. While it plays key roles, including the removal of RNA primers from Okazaki fragments, DNA polymerase III is the primary enzyme for DNA synthesis in these organisms

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents to the clinic with symptoms of acute bacterial prostatitis, including fever, chills, dysuria, and perineal pain. A urine sample is taken, and a culture is performed, which reveals the presence of a common organism associated with acute bacterial prostatitis. Identify the organism?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. E. coli

 

Escherichia coli, commonly known as E. coli, is a gram-negative bacillus and is part of the normal flora of the gastrointestinal tract. E. coli is the most common cause of acute bacterial prostatitis, accounting for the vast majority of cases. It's also a very common cause of urinary tract infections in general.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Enterococcus: Enterococcus species are gram-positive cocci that are part of the normal gut flora. They are an infrequent cause of acute bacterial prostatitis.

 

Option B. Proteus: Proteus species are gram-negative bacilli. They can cause a variety of infections, including urinary tract infections and, less commonly, prostatitis. A characteristic of Proteus infections is the production of urease, which splits urea into ammonia and leads to an alkaline urine that can cause struvite stone formation.

 

Option C. Streptococcus Agalactiae: Also known as Group B Streptococcus (GBS), Streptococcus agalactiae is a gram-positive coccus. While it's a leading cause of neonatal infections, it's an infrequent cause of urinary tract infections in adults and an even rarer cause of prostatitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Escherichia coli (E. coli) is the most common cause of acute bacterial prostatitis, accounting for the majority of cases and is frequently found in urinary tract infections.

questions.text: Addison's disease can present with symptoms similar to which of the following disorders? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Depression

 

Addison's disease, or primary adrenal insufficiency, is a condition where the adrenal glands do not produce sufficient steroid hormones, specifically cortisol and aldosterone. Symptoms of Addison's disease include fatigue, muscle weakness, weight loss, low blood pressure, and skin hyperpigmentation. These symptoms, especially fatigue, muscle weakness, and weight loss, can overlap with the symptoms of depression.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Generalized anxiety disorder primarily involves excessive, uncontrollable worry about everyday events. It is not usually seen in Addison’s disease.

 

Option C. Bipolar disorder is characterized by mood episodes, including mania (or hypomania) and depression. It may be seen in Addison’s disease, but it is rare.

 

Option D. Panic disorder is characterized by recurrent unexpected panic attacks, which are sudden periods of intense fear or discomfort. It is not usually seen in Addison’s disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Addison's disease is due to hypofunctioning of the adrenocortical system. It can mimic depression due to overlapping symptoms such as fatigue, weight loss, and low mood. It is essential to consider medical conditions that can present similarly to psychiatric disorders to ensure accurate diagnosis and treatment.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Comprehensive Textbook of Psychiatry, 10th edition, Page No 682.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient arrives at the hospital emergency department presenting with gastrointestinal distress. The patient complains of severe abdominal pain, frequent vomiting, and watery diarrhea. During the physical examination, the medical team observes that the patient's stools emit an unusual faint glow. The patient appears disoriented and fatigued. The medical history reveals that the patient attended a local festival the previous day and consumed various food items there. The following exposures might be contributing to which substance toxication? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Phosphorus

 

The vomitus and stools turn luminescent in acute phosphorus poisoning.

 

The stools also release mild fumes and this is called ‘smoky stool syndrome’.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mercury: Symptoms: Tremors, memory loss, gingivitis, and gastrointestinal distress.

 

Option B. Cadmium: Symptoms: Nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, and renal damage.

 

Option D. Calcium: Symptoms: Hypercalcemia, muscle weakness, confusion, and abdominal pain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Comparison of Poisoning Types:

questions.text: A patient with loin pain underwent retrograde ureter pyelogram to determine the cause of the pain. What is the likely cause of the pain as shown in the image below? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Hydronephrosis

 

The presence of dilated clubbed calyces and a stricture at the left ureteropelvic junction in the given image is indicative of hydronephrosis, which is caused by a partial or complete blockage of urinary flow in the pelvicalyceal system. This condition can arise when there's an obstruction preventing urine from draining out of the kidney and down the ureter. Over time, this causes the kidney to swell and its internal structures, like the calyces, to dilate. Retrograde ureteropyelogram can reveal the classic signs of hydronephrosis such as dilated and clubbed calyces, and any blockage, for instance, at the ureteropelvic junction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Duplex kidney: A duplex kidney is a congenital anomaly where the kidney has two collecting systems. This means there are two ureters draining a single kidney, although sometimes the two ureters can fuse before entering the bladder. A retrograde ureteropyelogram can identify a duplex system by visualizing the two separate collecting systems and ureters. However, this option isn't the described condition causing the pain based on the information provided.

 

Option C. Renal carcinoma: Patients with renal carcinoma are likely to present with gross hematuria, while pain is late feature. While a retrograde ureteropyelogram can show filling defects, irregularities, or obstructions in the renal collecting system which could be caused by a tumor, it isn't the primary tool used for diagnosing renal carcinoma. Imaging methods like CT scans or MRIs are more commonly used for visualizing renal masses.

 

Option D. Renal stone: Kidney stones (renal calculi) present with flank pain and hematuria. On a retrograde ureteropyelogram, a kidney stone might show up as a filling defect or blockage. The location, size, and shape of the stone can often be identified. However, based on the information provided, the image indicates hydronephrosis and not a stone.

 

Educational Objective:


Hydronephrosis is characterized by the dilation of the renal pelvis and calyces due to an obstruction in urine flow, leading to swelling of the kidney and pain, typically visualized via imaging like a retrograde ureteropyelogram.

questions.text: Which is the drug used for refractory intractable rheumatic chorea? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sodium valproate

 

Sodium valproate is the drug used for refractory intractable rheumatic chorea. It's an anticonvulsant medication that has proven effective in managing the involuntary movements associated with this condition.
