It works primarily by enhancing the effects of gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) in the brain, which helps reduce abnormal electrical activity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Probenecid: Probenecid is a medication used primarily to treat gout by reducing the levels of uric acid in the blood. It is not used for the treatment of rheumatic chorea.

 

Option B. Diazepam: Diazepam is a benzodiazepine used to treat anxiety, muscle spasms, and seizures. While it can provide muscle relaxation and sedation, it is not the drug of choice for managing refractory rheumatic chorea.

 

Option C. Haloperidol: Haloperidol is an antipsychotic medication that can be used in some movement disorders. While it has been used in chorea, it is not considered the optimal treatment for refractory intractable rheumatic chorea due to its side effect profile and efficacy compared to sodium valproate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sodium valproate is the preferred drug for treating refractory intractable rheumatic chorea due to its efficacy in reducing involuntary movements by enhancing inhibitory neurotransmission in the brain. It has a better side effect profile for long-term management of this condition compared to other options.

questions.text: A pregnant woman presents with obstructed labor and is grossly dehydrated. Investigations reveal fetal demise. What will be the management? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cesarean section

 

Explanation:

 

  • Obstructed labor is a direct indication for an emergency cesarean section
  • Obstructed labor happens when despite good uterine contractions, labor does not progress due to problems in the maternal pelvis/ fetus or a mechanical obstruction
  • Features of Obstructed Labor:
  • Maternal exhaustion and dehydration
  • Abdominal examination
    • Upper segment is tonically contracted with no relaxation The wall becomes thicker
    • Lower segment becomes distended and thinned out
    • Fetal parts not easily felt
    • Round ligaments taut and tender
    • Bandl’s ring is felt (Retraction ring)
    • Fetal heart rate absent
  • Vaginal exam
    • Vagina feels hot and dry
    • Cervix hangs loosely like a curtain
    • Caput +++
    • Moulding +++
    • Head feels jammed in the pelvis
  • The mainstay of management will be to start IV fluids and broad-spectrum antibiotics.
  • Emergency LSCS is the rule in Obstructed labor even in a dead fetus

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Craniotomy: This is a destructive fetal operation which is not preferred anymore even in a non-viable fetus/ dead fetus. It can be done if ffacilities for immediate cesarean are not available.  The main indications for fetal craniotomy are:

 

  • Cephalic presentation with obstructed labour
  • Hydrocephalus in a living fetus
  • Interlocking head of twins
  • Aftercoming head of breech

 

Option B. Decapitation: It is severing of the fetal head from the trunk. It is a destructive operation and again is not preferred unless facilities for emergency LSCS are not available or in exceptional circumstances. Indications are

 

  • Neglected shoulder with a dead fetus
  • Locked twins

 

Option D. Forceps extraction: Instrumental delivery is contra-indicated in obstructed labor. CPD should be ruled out prior to applying an instrument (Forceps or vacuum)

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of obstructed labor, an emergency cesarean section is the recommended management, even if the fetus is deceased.

 

Ref: Page no 421, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

questions.text: What is the most effective circuit for anesthesia under spontaneous breathing in adults? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mapleson A

 

Most effective Mapleson circuit for adults:

 

  • Spontaneous breathing = Mapleson A or Magill's circuit
  • Controlled breathing = Mapleson D or Bain's circuit

 

Most effective Mapleson circuit for pediatrics – Mapleson F circuit

 

 

Educational Objective :

 

Most effective circuit for anesthesia under spontaneous breathing in adults is Mapleson A.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 613

questions.text: What is the most common site for an extragonadal germ cell tumor? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mediastinum

 

Extragonadal germ cell tumor is most commonly seen in mediastinum.

 

Extragonadal germinal cell tumors (EGGCTs) are rare tumors that predominantly affect young males.

 

These tumors are particularly significant because they mimic the normal germ cell tumors but appear in unusual locations, making them a critical diagnostic challenge. The prevalence of EGGCTs in the mediastinum indicates the importance of considering this location when evaluating patients with symptoms suggestive of germ cell tumors but without testicular or ovarian masses.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pineal gland: While EGGCTs can occur here, they represent only about 5% of cases.

 

Option B. Retroperitoneum: This site accounts for 30-40% of EGGCT cases, making it the second most common site.

 

Option C. Sacrococcygeal region: This is the least common site.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Common sites of extragonadal germ cell tumor –

 

  • Mediastinum (50-70%)
  • Retroperitoneum (30-40%)
  • Pineal gland (5%)
  • Sacrococcygeal area (less than 5%)

choices.text: Hemophilia A
Hemophilia B
Von Willebrand disease

questions.text: Prolonged bleeding time is seen in? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Von Willebrand disease

 

Von Willebrand disease (VWD) is characterized by prolonged bleeding time due to a qualitative or quantitative deficiency of von Willebrand factor (VWF), a critical protein in platelet adhesion and aggregation processes. Prolonged APTT (Activated Partial Thromboplastin Time) is also seen in this condition because VWF stabilizes factor VIII, an essential clotting factor. The deficiency or dysfunction of VWF thus impacts both primary hemostasis (bleeding time) and secondary hemostasis (APTT).

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. Hemophilia A and B. Hemophilia B: These conditions involve deficiencies in clotting factors VIII and IX, respectively, which primarily affect the intrinsic coagulation pathway but not typically the bleeding time.

 

Option D. Hemophilia C: Known as a deficiency in factor XI, this condition also typically affects the intrinsic pathway and APTT but not bleeding time.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prolonged bleeding time and prolonged APTT is seen in Von Willebrand disease.

choices.text: Children under 14 years of age must not be employed in factories
A child of 16 years can be employed only between 6 AM and 8 PM
The maximum working hours for an adult is 72 hours per week
A child of 16 years can work till 5 hours per day

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes the Factories Act? [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Children under 14 years of age must not be employed in factories 

 

  • The Factories Act, established in 1948, specifically prohibits the employment of children under 14 years of age in factories. 
  • This legislation was enacted to ensure the protection of children from labor exploitation and to promote their welfare by restricting their employment in industrial environments.

 

FACTORIES ACT:

 

  • Established to include all the factories except Defense, Mining, Railways and Eateries.
  • Per capita space: more than 500/ft3
  • One Safety officer for more than 1000 workers.
  • Children between 14-18 years can be employed only in certain industries and work only between 6 AM-7PM. They should not be made to work for more than four and a half hours per day.
  • The maximum working hours for adults should be less than 48hrs per week or less than 9hrs per day.
  • With overtime being included, it should not be more than 60 hours per week.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Factories Act of 1948 critically mandates that children under the age of 14 must not be employed in factories, reflecting the law's strong stance on child labor and its emphasis on the health and safety of young individuals.

questions.text: Quadruple testing is done during? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 15-20 weeks

 

Explanation:

 

Quadruple testing, also known as the quadruple screen or quad screen, is typically performed between 15-20 weeks of pregnancy, with the most accurate results obtained between 16-18 weeks. The test measures four serum analytes:

 

  • Maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (MSAFP)
  • Unconjugated estriol (uE3)
  • Free Beta-hCG
  • Inhibin-A

 

This test helps assess the risk of certain chromosomal abnormalities such as Down syndrome (trisomy 21) and trisomy 18, as well as neural tube defects. The quad screen has a lower sensitivity compared to the first trimester combined screening (which includes nuchal translucency and dual marker screening), making it particularly useful for women who present for prenatal care later in pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 9-11 weeks: This timeframe is generally used for first trimester screening tests, such as the combined screening, which includes nuchal translucency and the dual marker test (free β-hCG and PAPP-A).

 

Option B. 12-14 weeks: This period is also used for the combined first trimester screening but is not appropriate for the quad screen.

 

Option D. 22-28 weeks: This period is outside the recommended timeframe for the quad screen. Tests in this period are more focused on gestational diabetes screening and routine ultrasounds.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The quadruple test is performed between 15-20 weeks of pregnancy to screen for chromosomal abnormalities and neural tube defects.

 

 

Easy to remember: In Down Syndrome, Beta hCG and Inhibin A are increases (B – Big; B in Beta hCG, B in Inhibin A)

 

*King Edward Abdicated his throne so all levels are decreased

questions.text: Pseudo P pulmonale is seen in which electrolyte abnormality? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Hypokalemia

 

Pseudo P pulmonale, characterized by exaggerated amplitude in the P wave, can be observed on an ECG in the context of hypokalemia. This electrolyte disturbance affects cardiac electrophysiology, leading to various changes including prolonged QT interval, presence of U waves, T wave flattening or inversion, and sometimes pseudo-infarction patterns, which can mimic myocardial infarction.

 

Hypokalemia can result in these distinct ECG changes due to its influence on cellular membrane potentials in cardiac cells, which alters the normal propagation of electrical impulses through the myocardium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hyponatremia: Does not typically cause prominent P wave changes; its ECG manifestations are less specific and often involve general effects on conduction and contractility.

 

Note - Hyponatremia is usually silent on the ECG

 

Option C. Hypocalcemia: Associated with prolonged QT interval due to an elongation of the ST segment but not with pseudo P pulmonale.

 

Option D. Hypercalcemia: Typically presents with a shortened QT interval and shortened ST segment, differing significantly from the changes seen in hypokalemia.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient with a history of peripheral artery disease presents with symptoms of intermittent claudication and ischemic rest pain in the lower extremities. Further evaluation reveals a significant stenosis in the femoropopliteal artery. The patient is scheduled for a femoropopliteal bypass procedure, and the surgeon must choose the appropriate graft material for the procedure. Which is the best graft for a femoropopliteal bypass?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Great saphenous vein

 

The great saphenous vein, an autologous vein graft, is considered the gold standard for femoropopliteal bypass, especially for below-knee procedures. The great saphenous vein has superior patency rates and fewer complications compared to synthetic grafts in this setting. When available and of good quality, the GSV is the preferred choice for femoropopliteal bypass. The great saphenous vein is the best as it lasts longer than polytetrafluoroethylene, Dacron and human umbilical vein as a graft in a femoropopliteal bypass.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dacron: Dacron is a brand name for a type of polyester fiber. It has been used as vascular graft material for several years. Dacron grafts are synthetic and durable, and they are primarily used for larger vessel grafts such as aortoiliac or aortofemoral bypass procedures. However, for femoropopliteal bypass, especially for below-the-knee grafts, Dacron is associated with lower patency rates compared to autologous vein grafts.

 

Option C. Polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE): Polytetrafluoroethylene (often known by the brand name Teflon) is a synthetic material used as a vascular graft. PTFE grafts are most commonly used when a suitable autologous vein is not available. PTFE has acceptable patency rates, especially for above-the-knee femoropopliteal bypasses. However, for below-the-knee grafts, the GSV usually outperforms PTFE in terms of long-term patency.

 

Option D. Short Saphenous Vein: The short saphenous vein runs along the back of the calf and drains into the popliteal vein. While it can be used as a graft for femoropopliteal bypass, it is not as commonly chosen as the great saphenous vein. The GSV is generally longer, more superficial, and easier to harvest, making it the preferred autologous graft.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The great saphenous vein is the preferred graft material for femoropopliteal bypass due to its superior patency rates and longevity compared to synthetic grafts like Dacron or polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE).

choices.text: Acute coronary syndrome with low EF

questions.text: Automatic implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (AICD) implantation is done for which of the following conditions? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. All of the above

 

An Automatic Implantable Cardioverter-Defibrillator (AICD) is used for the prevention of sudden cardiac death in patients with various cardiac conditions that predispose them to life-threatening arrhythmias. The indications include:

 

Option A. Brugada syndrome: A genetic disorder that can lead to dangerous ventricular arrhythmias.

 

Option B. Ventricular fibrillation (VF): A life-threatening heart rhythm that results in rapid, inadequate heartbeats.

 

Option C. Acute coronary syndrome (ACS) with low ejection fraction (EF): After a myocardial infarction, patients with significantly reduced EF are at higher risk for ventricular arrhythmias.

 

The device is particularly beneficial in patients with structural heart disease, prior myocardial infarction, and those who have experienced syncope due to undetermined reasons but are found to have inducible ventricular tachycardia or fibrillation during electrophysiological studies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Class I Indications for AICD implantation:

 

  1. LV dysfunction with ejection fraction less than or equal to 35% and NYHA II/III symptoms.
  2. LV dysfunction with ejection fraction less than or equal to 35% due to previous Myocardial Infarction (MI) or at least 40 days post-MI and NYHA II/III symptoms.
  3. LV dysfunction with ejection fraction less than or equal to 30% due to previous Myocardial Infarction (MI) or at least 40 days post-MI.
  4. LV dysfunction with ejection fraction less than or equal to 40% due to previous Myocardial Infarction (MI) or at least 40 days post-MI and inducible VT/VF on EP study (EPS).
  5. Syncope of unknown etiology and inducible VT/ VF on EPS.
  6. Sustained VT in the presence of structural heart disease.
  7. Brugada syndrome.
  8. HCM with > 1 risk factor for SCD.

 

Reference - Harrison 21/Ventricular Arrhythmias/Chapter 252

questions.text: What is the most common cause of agranulocytosis? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Drug toxicity

 

Drug toxicity is the most common cause of agranulocytosis. Agranulocytosis is a condition in which there is a severe decrease in the number of white blood cells called granulocytes, which are responsible for fighting bacterial infections. Certain medications, such as chemotherapy drugs, antibiotics, antipsychotics, and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), can cause agranulocytosis as a side effect.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Marrow infiltration: While it can cause agranulocytosis, it is less common than drug-induced cases.

 

Option B. Autoimmune: Can lead to agranulocytosis through immune-mediated destruction of neutrophils but is also less frequent than drug toxicity.

 

Option D. Radiation exposure: Can suppress bone marrow but typically in the context of higher and prolonged exposures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Causes of agranulocytosis include:

 

  • Inadequate or ineffective granulopoiesis
  • Suppression of hematopoietic stem cells - aplastic anemia, infiltrative marrow disorders
  • Suppression of committed granulocytic precursors
  • Ineffective hematopoiesis - megaloblastic anemia, myelodysplastic syndromes
  • Congenital conditions - Kostmann syndrome
  • Increased destruction or sequestration of neutrophils -
  • Immunological injury to neutrophils - idiopathic, systemic lupus erythematosus, drug exposure
  • Increased peripheral utilization - bacterial, fungal, or rickettsial infections
  • Splenomegaly

questions.text: What is Edmond Locard known for? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Theory of exchange

 

Edmond Locard discovered two principles:

 

  1. Locard's Exchange Principle It states that whenever two bodies come in contact with each other, there is exchange of material between the two and so a criminal can be linked to crime
  2. Poroscopy: It is a method of identification through the comparison of the impressions of pores of sweat glands (present on palmar and plantar surfaces).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Study of fingerprints: Sir Francis Galton, developed the first classification system for fingerprints.

 

Option C. Stature estimation: This field involves estimating an individual's height from skeletal remains.

 

Option D. Forensic ballistics: This deals with the examination of firearms, bullets, and bullet impacts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Edmond Locard is best known for Locard's Exchange Principle, which states that whenever two bodies come into contact, there is an exchange of materials, thereby linking criminals to crime scenes.

questions.text: At what BMI value is considered 'fatal' for men? [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) <13 

 

  • A body mass index (BMI) of less than 13 in men is considered critically low and potentially fatal. 
  • This threshold indicates extreme undernutrition and can lead to severe health complications, potentially resulting in life-threatening conditions due to vital organ function impairment and failure. 
  • BMI is a measure of body fat based on height and weight that applies to adult men and women, and values significantly below normal can indicate serious health risks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An individual with a body mass index (BMI) of 13 or lower is deemed fatal for males. Nonetheless, females can endure with a BMI as low as 11 or even lower.

questions.text:
To achieve the demographic target of NRR=1, what level should the rate of couple protection exceed? [NEET PG 2018]

 

(NRR: Net reproduction rate)
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) 60% 

 

The Net Reproduction Rate (NRR) is a measure of the average number of daughters a woman would have if she passed through her lifetime conforming to the age-specific fertility and mortality rates of a given year. An NRR of 1 means that each woman is, on average, having one daughter who survives to reproductive age, thereby replacing herself without population growth or decline.

 

To achieve the demographic target of NRR=1, the couple protection rate (CPR) must exceed 60%. This aligns with the scenario where every couple has two children.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To achieve the demographic target of NRR=1, the rate of couple protection should exceed 60%. This level of contraceptive use helps in maintaining a stable population by ensuring that each woman, on average, has one daughter who survives to reproductive age.

questions.text: What is the approximate time interval between HIV infection & manifestation of AIDS? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 10 years

 

The typical time interval from HIV infection to the manifestation of AIDS, in the absence of antiretroviral therapy, is approximately 10 years. This period is often referred to as the latency period, during which the virus is actively replicating in the body, but the immune system has not yet deteriorated to the point of clinical AIDS. This period can vary based on several factors, including the individual's genetic predisposition, co-infections, and overall health.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mean interval b/w infection to AIDS is due to prolonged latency period (~10- years).

 

Reference - Harrison/HIV/Chap 201

choices.text: Development of cardiac failure within 5 months of delivery

questions.text: All are true regarding peripartum cardiomyopathy except? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Left ventricular diastolic dysfunction

 

Explanation:

 

Peripartum cardiomyopathy (PPCM) is a form of heart failure that occurs during the last month of pregnancy or within five months postpartum. It is characterized by left ventricular systolic dysfunction, rather than diastolic dysfunction. The diagnostic criteria for PPCM include:

 

  • Cardiac failure developing in the last month of pregnancy or within five months after delivery.
  • Absence of an identifiable cause for the cardiac failure.
  • Absence of recognizable heart disease prior to the last month of pregnancy.
  • Echocardiographic evidence of left ventricular systolic dysfunction (ejection fraction <45% or fractional shortening <30%) along with a dilated left ventricle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Development of cardiac failure within 5 months of delivery: Correct. PPCM develops within five months of delivery.

 

Option C. Absence of identifiable cause: Correct. PPCM is diagnosed in the absence of an identifiable cause for cardiac failure.

 

Option D. Dilated left ventricle: Correct. PPCM is associated with a dilated left ventricle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Peripartum cardiomyopathy is characterized by left ventricular systolic dysfunction and occurs within the last month of pregnancy or up to five months postpartum, in the absence of an identifiable cause for cardiac failure.

 

Ref: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK482185/

questions.text: Which chromosome is involved in myotonic dystrophy? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chromosome 19

 

Myotonic dystrophy is an inherited genetic disorder that affects muscle function. It is caused by an abnormal expansion of nucleotide repeats in the DMPK gene on chromosome 19.

 

Myotonic dystrophy (DM) is a type of muscular dystrophy, a group of genetic disorders that cause progressive muscle loss and weakness. In DM, muscles are often unable to relax after contraction. Other manifestations may include cataracts, intellectual disability and heart conduction problems. In men, there may be early balding and an inability to father children. While myotonic dystrophy can occur at any age, onset is typically in the 20s and 30s.

 

There is no cure. Treatments may include braces or wheelchairs, pacemakers and non-invasive positive pressure ventilation. The medications mexiletine or carbamazepine can help relax muscles. Pain, if it occurs, may be treated with tricyclic antidepressants and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Chromosome 20, Option C. Chromosome 21 and Option D. Chromosome 22: These chromosomes are not associated with the mutation causing myotonic dystrophy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myotonic dystrophy is linked to a mutation in the DMPK gene on chromosome 19, leading to diverse symptoms including muscle dysfunction, cataracts, and cardiac issues.

questions.text: The best type of anesthesia for pre-eclampsia is? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Epidural anesthesia

 

The best type of anesthesia for pre-eclampsia is Epidural anesthesia (Option B).

 

Epidural anesthesia involves the injection of anesthetic agents into the epidural space of the spine. It can be titrated to the desired level of anesthesia/analgesia and can be maintained for longer periods. 

 

  • Key Advantages in the context of pre-eclampsia:
    • Avoidance of airway manipulation: As mentioned, pregnancy can present with airway challenges due to edema, short neck, and increased breast size.
    • Preservation of Airway Reflexes: There's no risk of aspiration, which is a concern in pregnant patients due to delayed gastric emptying.
    • Decreased drug passage to fetus: Fewer systemic drugs are used, which reduces the risk of placental transfer and potential neonatal depression.
    • Pain management: Effective pain control can help in reducing catecholamine levels, which can otherwise increase blood pressure further in pre-eclamptic patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Spinal anesthesia:

 

While it provides rapid and effective anesthesia for surgeries below the abdomen, it may cause a significant drop in blood pressure, which can be concerning in patients with pre-eclampsia.

 

Option C. General anesthesia:

 

In pregnant patients, especially with conditions like pre-eclampsia, general anesthesia presents multiple challenges:

 

Airway difficulties

 

Risk of aspiration: Pregnant patients are at an increased risk of aspiration during induction and intubation due to delayed gastric emptying.

 

Drug transfer to fetus: Many anesthetic agents can cross the placenta, potentially affecting the fetus.

 

Option D. Caudal block:

 

A caudal block is a type of epidural where the anesthetic is administered at the sacral hiatus. It's typically used in pediatric patients . While it can provide good analgesia, it's not the primary choice for managing pre-eclampsia in obstetric procedures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Epidural anesthesia is preferred for pre-eclampsia due to its ability to provide effective pain relief, avoid airway manipulation, and minimize drug passage to the fetus.

choices.text: Pituitary gland

questions.text: IGF-I is synthesized by which of the following organ? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Liver

 

Explanation

 

The predominant organ producing insulin-like growth factor I (IGF-I) is the liver. IGF-I is produced in response to stimulation by growth hormone (GH), which is primarily secreted by the pituitary gland. However, while GH stimulates IGF-I production, it is the liver that is responsible for producing the majority of circulating IGF-I in the body.

 

Growth hormone acts on the liver to form small proteins called "somatomedins"

 

  • Somatomedins increases bone growth in all aspect
  • Also called as insulin-like growth factor (IGF) as effects are similar to insulin
  • Four types are present - Most important is somatomedin C, specifically referred to as "insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1)
  • Binds to carrier protein in blood
  • Half-life - about 20 Hrs
  • Blood concentration of IGF-1, follows the levels of growth hormone.
  • Growth effects of GH are mostly attributed to somatomedin (rather than its direct effect on bones & peripheral tissues)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pituitary gland: Incorrect because while the pituitary gland secretes growth hormone that stimulates IGF-I production, it does not synthesize IGF-I itself.

 

Option C. Pancreas: Incorrect because the pancreas is involved in the production of insulin and other digestive enzymes, not IGF-I.

 

Option D. Adrenal glands: Incorrect because the adrenal glands produce corticosteroids and catecholamines, not IGF-I.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The liver is the primary organ responsible for the synthesis of insulin-like growth factor I (IGF-I), which is stimulated by growth hormone secreted from the pituitary gland.

 

Ref– Textbook of Medical physiology Guyton and Hall, 11th edition, page no. 924

questions.text: Which of the options below does not result in water hardness? [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Calcium carbonate

 

Hardness of water is caused by the presence of dissolved minerals, particularly calcium and magnesium ions. These minerals can come from various sources, such as natural deposits in soil and rocks, or from industrial and domestic activities.

 

There are two types of hardness of water:

 

Temporary (carbonate) hardness is due to bicarbonates of calcium and magnesium.

 

Permanent (non-carbonate) hardness is due to sulphates, chlorides and nitrates.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hardness of water is defined as the ‘soap destroying power of water’
  • Hardness of water is expressed in terms of: milliequivalents per litre (mEq/litre) of CALCIUM CARBONATE (CaCO3)
  • 1 mEq/litre hardness = 50 mg CaCO3 (50 ppm) per litre of water
  • Softening of water is recommended at level of hardness > 3 mEq/litre (>150 mg/litre of Calcium carbonate)
  • Temporary hardness of water is due to Ca++ and Mg++ Bicarbonates
  • Permanent hardness (Non-Carbonate hardness) is due to Calcium & Magnesium salts of Sulfates, Chlorides, Nitrates
  • Four main compounds causing Hardness: Calcium bicarbonates, Magnesium bicarbonates, Calcium sulfates, Magnesium sulfates.

questions.text: Which of the following is Burkholderia cepacia resistant to? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cefotetan

 

Burkholderia cepacia complex is known for its intrinsic resistance to various antimicrobial agents, including cefotetan.

 

B. Cepacia complex strains are intrinsically resistant to:

 

  • Aminoglycosides
  • Polymixin
  • First and second-generation cephalosporins
  • Carboxypenicillins

 

B. Cepacia can cause severe necrotizing pneumonia in patients with chronic granulomatous disease. It can lead to fatal septicemia in patients with cystic fibrosis.

 

Antimicrobial agents that are effective against B. cepacia complex include:

 

  • Meropenem
  • Ceftazidime
  • Piperacillin
  • Temocillin
  • Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Ceftazidime: Incorrect because ceftazidime is actually among the antimicrobials that are effective against B. cepacia complex, suggesting it can bypass the bacterium’s resistance mechanisms.

 

Option B. Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole: Incorrect, as this combination is also effective against B. cepacia, demonstrating its capability to treat infections caused by this pathogen.

 

Option C. Temocillin: Incorrect, as temocillin is listed as effective against B. cepacia complex, indicating its efficacy in combating this resistant bacterium.

 

Educational Objective

 

Burkholderia cepacia exhibits resistance to several antibiotic classes, including second-generation cephalosporins like cefotetan.

questions.text: The following instrument is used for: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Myringotomy

 

Myringotomy is done by a sharp myringotome as shown in the image. Myringotome is a surgical knife used for paracentesis of the eardrum.

 

Myringotomy is most commonly done for serous otitis media in the anteroinferior quadrant radially. Sometimes, grommet insertion is done through the opening made by myringotome in the tympanic membrane.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Septoplasty: This procedure corrects a deviated nasal septum, involving different instruments primarily for reshaping the nasal structure, not for ear-related surgeries.

 

Option B. Myringoplasty: This is a procedure to repair a perforation of the tympanic membrane but does not typically use a myringotome; instead, it uses tools for patching or grafting the membrane.

 

Option D. Adenoidectomy: This surgery involves the removal of the adenoids located in the upper part of the throat behind the nose, using different instruments like curettes or microdebriders, not a myringotome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The myringotome is crucial for performing a myringotomy, allowing for precise incisions in the tympanic membrane to address issues such as serous otitis media. The instrument's design facilitates targeted, clean cuts to insert grommets if needed.

questions.text: Which article in the Indian Constitution grants the Right to Life to the individuals of India? [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Article 21 

 

Article 21 of the Indian Constitution guarantees the Right to Life and personal liberty to all its citizens. This article is pivotal as it ensures that no person is deprived of their life or personal liberty except according to the procedure established by law. This right is comprehensive, covering a range of aspects that ensure not just mere survival but a life with dignity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  Article 11: Defines the right of the parliament to regulate the right of citizenship by law.

 

Option C. Article 23: Defines the prohibition of traffic in human beings and forced labor.

 

Option D. Article 25: Defines the freedom of conscience and free profession, practice, and propagation of religion. While it pertains to personal liberties, it specifically addresses religious freedoms and not the general Right to Life.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Article 21 of the Indian Constitution is critical as it enshrines the Right to Life and personal liberty, ensuring that every individual's life and personal freedoms are protected under the law.

questions.text: The ureteric bud arises from which of the following embryological structures? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Mesonephric duct

 

The ureteric bud arises from the mesonephric (or Wolffian) duct. The mesonephric duct is one of the primary structures in the early embryonic development of the urinary and reproductive systems. The ureteric bud's growth is stimulated by signals from the adjacent metanephrogenic blastema. The ureteric bud undergoes repeated branching to form the ureter, renal pelvis, calyces, and the collecting tubules of the kidneys.

 

  • The intermediate mesoderm is a specific type of mesoderm that is located between the paraxial mesoderm and lateral plate.
  • During development, it plays a crucial role in the formation of both the urogenital system and the reproductive system. It divides into two structures known as the genital ridge and nephrogenic cord.
  • The nephrogenic cord goes on to form three distinct structures - the pronephros, mesonephros, and metanephros. From the mesonephros, the ureteric bud develops and eventually fuses with the mesonephric duct.
  • The metanephros then proliferates around the ureteric bud, forming what is called the metanephric blastema. This ultimately gives rise to the definitive kidneys.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Metanephros: The metanephros is the embryological structure that develops into the permanent kidney in humans. The metanephrogenic blastema (or metanephrogenic mesenchyme) is the tissue that surrounds the tip of the ureteric bud and interacts with it. Signals from the ureteric bud stimulate the metanephrogenic blastema to differentiate into the nephron components of the kidney (like the glomerulus, proximal tubule, loop of Henle, etc.). The metanephros is not the origin of the ureteric bud but rather interacts with it.

 

Option C. Pronephros: The pronephros is the most primitive of the three embryonic kidneys. It appears early in embryonic development but quickly degenerates and is non-functional in mammals. Its duct, the pronephric duct, eventually becomes the mesonephric duct when the mesonephros starts to develop. The pronephros itself does not give rise to the ureteric bud.

 

Option D. Genital sinus: The genital sinus is involved in the development of the lower parts of the reproductive system and parts of the urinary system. In females, it contributes to parts of the vagina, and in males, it contributes to parts of the urethra. It does not give rise to the ureteric bud.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

A. Dorsal views of the bladder showing the relation of the ureters and mesonephric ducts during development. Initially the ureters are formed by an outgrowth of the mesonephric duct

 

B-D. with time they assume a separate entrance into the urinary bladder

 

C and D. Note the trigone of the bladder formed by incorporation of the mesonephric ducts

questions.text: Which factor is associated with the Leiden mutation? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) V

 

Leiden mutation is a single nucleotide mutation that occurs in factor V.

 

Factor V Leiden (FVL) is a point mutation of factor V resulting in an elimination of the cleavage site in factor V and factor Va. Activated protein C, a natural anticoagulant cannot bind and inactivate factor V as there is a mutation in the binding site on factor V for activated protein C. Therefore, as factor V is not inactivated it continues to be active and increases thrombosis risk.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. VIII: Factor VIII is involved in the intrinsic pathway of the coagulation cascade and is affected in conditions like hemophilia A. 

 

Option C. I: Factor I, also known as fibrinogen, is a protein involved in the final step of the clotting process, forming fibrin clots.

 

Option D. X: Factor X, part of both the intrinsic and extrinsic pathways, is crucial for the conversion of prothrombin to thrombin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Leiden mutation specifically affects factor V, rendering it resistant to inactivation by activated protein C, unlike factors VIII, I, or X.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with AV block? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Hypothyroidism

 

Hypothyroidism can lead to various cardiac manifestations, including bradycardia and atrioventricular (AV) block. This is due to the metabolic effects of low thyroid hormone levels, which slow down the heart rate and can increase the risk of heart block. This type of AV block is generally reversible and often improves with appropriate thyroid hormone replacement therapy, such as levothyroxine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cushing's syndrome: Typically associated with other cardiovascular issues such as hypertension due to excessive cortisol levels, but not commonly with AV block.

 

Option C. Hyperthyroidism: Usually results in symptoms opposite to those of hypothyroidism, like tachycardia or atrial fibrillation, rather than AV block.

 

Option D. Pheochromocytoma: This condition, characterized by excess production of catecholamines, typically presents with episodic hypertension and tachycardia, not AV block.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypothyroidism causes reversible AV Block that improves with LT4 supplementation.

choices.text: ﻿﻿﻿Bandage and padding of the eye

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient who had undergone an uneventful cataract surgery with intraocular lens implantation, presents with complaints of pain and visual disturbance in the operated eye, 36 hours post operatively. His eye is as shown below. What is the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Intravitreal antibiotics

 

The given image shows an inflamed eye with the presence hypopyon, which along with the history of a recent cataract surgery is suggestive of endophthalmitis.

 

Endophthalmitis is an inflammation of the inner structures of the eyeball associated with exudate pouring in the vitreous cavity, anterior chamber, and posterior chamber.

 

Modes of infection:

 

  1. Exogenous: following perforating injuries, perforation of infected corneal ulcers, or postoperative infections.
  2. Endogenous or metastatic endophthalmitis: occurs rarely through the bloodstream from some infected focus.
  3. Secondary infections from surrounding structures: rare.
  • Bacterial endophthalmitis: most frequent pathogens are gram-positive cocci, such as staphylococcus epidermidis and staphylococcus aureus.
  • Fungal endophthalmitis: comparatively rare, caused by aspergillus, fusarium, candida, etc.
  • Cardinal features: Pain, lid swelling, and decreased vision. Inflammation of the eye, corneal edema, and hypopyon may also occur.
  • Treatment:
    • Intraocular fluid from anterior chamber or vitreous biopsy is sent for gram staining, KOH mount and culture.
    • Intravitreal injection of antibiotics is the primary therapy. Patient needs to be monitored daily to assess for resolution of clinical symptoms and repeat intravitreal antibiotic injections may be given as required.
    • Topical broadspectrum antibiotics, cycloplegics are also given simultaneously.
    • Oral steroids may be given.
    • Systemic antibiotics have no role in the management of endophthalmitis..

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intravenous steroids: Not the primary treatment for endophthalmitis. Steroids may be used to reduce inflammation but not as the main intervention.

 

Option B. Intravenous antibiotics: Systemic antibiotics have limited effectiveness due to poor penetration into the eye.

 

Option C. Bandage and padding of the eye: Provides no therapeutic benefit for endophthalmitis and delays appropriate treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Intravitreal antibiotics are the primary treatment for endophthalmitis, a severe postoperative complication characterized by inflammation and hypopyon. Early and aggressive treatment is crucial to prevent vision loss.

questions.text: The vertical and horizontal fracture of nasal septum is: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chevallet and Jarjaway fracture

 

  • Chevallet fracture - Fracture line runs vertically from the anterior nasal spine upwards to the junction of the bony and cartilaginous dorsum of the nose.

 

 

  • Jarjaway fracture - Fracture line starts just above the anterior nasal spine and runs horizontally backward just above the junction of septal cartilage with the vomer.

 

 

Tripod fracture – is zygomatic fracture. Zygoma is separated into three processes. Fracture line passes through zygomaticofrontal suture, orbital floor, infraorbital margin and foramen, anterior wall of maxillary sinus and the zygomaticotemporal suture

 

 

Other Options:
 

Option B. Citelli fracture - This does not pertain to the nasal septum but rather involves other cranial structures.

 

Option C. Tripod fracture - This is a zygomatic fracture where the zygoma is separated into three processes. The fracture line passes through the zygomaticofrontal suture, orbital floor, infraorbital margin and foramen, anterior wall of the maxillary sinus, and the zygomaticotemporal suture, unrelated to the nasal septum fractures.

 

Educational Objective:


The Chevallet and Jarjaway fractures are important classifications in the context of nasal injuries, describing vertical and horizontal fractures of the nasal septum respectively. Understanding these fracture types aids in accurate diagnosis and management of nasal trauma.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 166

questions.text: What alternative drug would you use for cardiac arrest if epinephrine is not effective? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Amiodarone

 

Epinephrine and amiodarone are the two main drugs approved by the American Heart Association for the resuscitation of a cardiac arrest patient.
Dose of epinephrine = 1 mg every 3-5 min IV
Dose of Amiodarone = 300 mg IV bolus dose

 

  • Amiodarone is an antiarrhythmic drug that is used to treat and prevent various types of arrhythmias.
  • For cardiac arrest, amiodarone is particularly recommended for ventricular fibrillation (VF) and pulseless ventricular tachycardia (VT) when initial defibrillation attempts have failed.
  • It acts by prolonging the action potential and refractory period in myocardial tissue, and it also has vasodilatory effects.
  • The initial recommended dose for cardiac arrest is 300 mg IV push.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vasopressin: Vasopressin is a synthetic peptide that stimulates V1 receptors, leading to vasoconstriction. It was once considered as an alternative to epinephrine for cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR), but more recent guidelines from organizations like the American Heart Association (AHA) have moved away from recommending its routine use in cardiac arrest. This is due to a lack of evidence showing a significant improvement in survival to hospital discharge.

 

Option B. Atropine: Atropine is an anticholinergic drug that blocks the effects of the vagus nerve on the heart. It increases the heart rate and was previously used in the treatment of asystole and pulseless electrical activity (PEA) cardiac arrest. However, more recent AHA guidelines no longer recommend atropine for routine use in these situations due to lack of evidence for its effectiveness.

 

Option D. Adenosine: Adenosine is a drug that is primarily used to treat certain types of supraventricular tachycardias (SVT). It works by slowing down the electrical activity in the heart, which can temporarily stop the heart, allowing it to "reset" itself to a normal rhythm. While adenosine can be very effective for its indicated uses, it's not typically used in the setting of cardiac arrest.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Amiodarone is an effective alternative drug for cardiac arrest, particularly for ventricular fibrillation and pulseless ventricular tachycardia when initial defibrillation attempts have failed.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man came with complaints of dark-colored stools to the OPD. After undergoing endoscopy, the patient was diagnosed with an upper GI bleed. Which of the following structures is used as a demarcation point to differentiate it from a lower GI bleed?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Ligament of Treitz

 

The ligament of Treitz is used as the demarcation point to differentiate between upper gastrointestinal bleeding and lower gastrointestinal bleeding. It is a part of the duodenojejunal junction.

 

Upper GI bleeding refers to bleeding proximal to the ligament of Treitz, and lower Gl bleeding refers to bleeding distal to the ligament of Treitz.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ampulla of Vater: The ampulla of Vater is the point where the pancreatic duct and common bile duct converge and enter the second part of the duodenum. It is an essential structure for the drainage of both bile and pancreatic enzymes into the duodenum. It is not used as a demarcation point for differentiating between upper and lower gastrointestinal bleeding.

 

Option C. Superior duodenal flexure: The superior duodenal flexure is the bend in the duodenum as it transitions from the first part (horizontal) to the second part (descending).

 

Option D. Ileocecal junction: The ileocecal junction is the point where the ileum meets the cecum. The ileocecal valve is present here, preventing the reflux of colonic contents into the ileum. While it's an important anatomical landmark in the gastrointestinal tract, it's not used as the demarcation point for differentiating between upper and lower gastrointestinal bleeding.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ligament of Treitz is the anatomical demarcation point used to differentiate upper gastrointestinal bleeding (proximal to the ligament) from lower gastrointestinal bleeding (distal to the ligament).

questions.text: A middle aged man from West Bengal presents with paraesthesia of hands and feet, hyperkeratosis, lines in the nails and rain drop pigmentation in the hands. The most likely causative toxin for the above mentioned symptoms is: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Arsenic

 

The symptoms mentioned in the question are classic features of chronic arsenic poisoning.

 

Chronic Arsenic poisoning: It is insidious in nature. The onset of symptoms usually  occurs  after 2–8  weeks of exposure.  Chronic  poisoning  may  occur among persons engaged in smelting and refining of ores and in the subliming of arsenic in the manufacture of weed killers, dyes etc.

 

Clinical Features of Chronic Arsenic poisoning:

 

  1. GIT symptoms: loss of weight, malaise, loss of appetite, salivation, colicky pain, diarrhoea and vomiting.
  2. Liver: Hepatomegaly, jaundice, cirrhosis
  3. Skin symptoms: usually begin with a persistent erythematous flush leading to hyperkeratotic skin and desquamation. Hyperkeratosis is most prominent in the distal parts of the body. Pigmentation is patchy (‘raindrops pigmentation). Skin cancer (Squamous cell carcinoma and basal cell carcinoma) also occurs.
  4. Nails: Aldrich Mees lines (transverse  white  striae  of  the fingernails) may also be seen.
  5. Hairs: Alopecia occurs
  6. Hematological: Anemia, leukopenia, Thrombocytopenia and Bone marrow hypoplasia are  seen.  Anemia is normocytic and normochromic
  7.  Peripheral neuropathy: Sensory  and  motor  polyneuritis (sensory  symptoms  usually  predominate)  manifesting  as numbness and tingling in a ‘stocking glove’ distribution.
  8. Blackfoot disease: Due to platelet activation and hypercoagulability of blood in peripheral arteries.
  9. Encephalopathy
  10. Nephritis

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lead: Symptoms Abdominal pain, anemia, neurological deficits, but not specifically hyperkeratosis, Mees lines, or raindrop pigmentation.

 

Option C. Thallium: Symptoms Gastrointestinal disturbances, alopecia, peripheral neuropathy, but lacks the specific skin changes and nail lines associated with arsenic.

 

Option D. Mercury: Symptoms: Tremors, memory loss, gingivitis, and neurological symptoms, but does not cause hyperkeratosis or Mees lines.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic arsenic poisoning presents with distinctive symptoms such as paraesthesia, hyperkeratosis, Aldrich Mees lines, and raindrop pigmentation, making it the most likely cause of the described symptoms.

questions.text: When is dilatation and curettage contraindicated? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pelvic inflammatory disease

 

Explanation:

 

Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) includes endometritis, salpingitis, oophoritis, and parametritis. Any interventions like dilatation and curettage (D&C) are contraindicated in active PID due to the risk of exacerbating the infection and causing further complications.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Ectopic pregnancy: D&C is not contraindicated in ectopic pregnancy; however, it is not typically performed in its management as it does not provide any benefit for this condition.

 

Option C. Menstrual irregularities: D&C can be performed to obtain an endometrial biopsy in peri-menopausal women with abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB) if there are no other identifiable causes and if endometrial hyperplasia or malignancy is suspected.

 

Option D. Endometriosis: D&C is not usually performed solely for endometriosis unless there is an associated AUB that needs to be evaluated or treated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dilatation and curettage (D&C) is contraindicated in active pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) due to the risk of spreading the infection

 

Ref: Page 168, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

questions.text: A 50-year-old emmetropic man is no longer able to read with the presbyopic glasses he had made 5 years ago. The power of his new prescription glasses should be:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. +2D

 

Since, the question asks for the new prescription, the answer should be +2.00D.

 

Had the question asked us to estimate the power of his old glasses, it would have been +1.5 DS.

 

The power of the prescription glasses for a 50-year-old man should be +2D.

 

This condition of falling near vision due to age-related decrease in the amplitude of accommodation or increase in punctum proximum is called presbyopia.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Emmetropic Man: The patient has no refractive error for distance vision but is experiencing difficulty with near vision due to presbyopia.
  • Current Glasses: If the patient had glasses made 5 years ago (when he was around 45), those glasses were likely around +1.5 D.
  • New Prescription: As presbyopia progresses, the strength of the glasses needs to be increased to +2.0 D to accommodate the further decline in near vision.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Roughly, the power of prescription glasses age-wise is as follows:

questions.text: Which of the following is most potent stimulators of aldosterone secretion? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Hyperkalemia

 

Explanation

 

  • Hyperkalemia and activation of renin-angiotensin system are the most potent stimulators of aldosterone secretion.
  • Aldosterone, secreted by the zona glomerulosa cells of the adrenal cortex, is an important regulator of sodium reabsorption and potassium secretion by the renal tubules.
  • The primary site of aldosterone action is on the principal cells of the cortical collecting tubule.
  • Aldosterone increases sodium reabsorption while at the same time increasing potassium secretion is by stimulating the sodium-potassium ATPase pump on the basolateral side of the cortical collecting tubule membrane.
  • Aldosterone also increases the sodium permeability of the luminal side of the membrane.
  • Minimal levels of aldosterone not affect sodium balance but greatly impairs the regulation of renal potassium excretion and potassium concentration of the body fluids. Thus, aldosterone is even more important as a regulator of potassium concentration than it is for sodium concentration.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. АСТН: Incorrect as ACTH (Adrenocorticotropic hormone) has a minor role in aldosterone secretion compared to the renin-angiotensin system or serum potassium levels.

 

Option C. Hypernatremia: Incorrect because hypernatremia would typically suppress aldosterone secretion as the body would seek to excrete excess sodium.

 

Option D. Exogenous steroid: Incorrect as exogenous steroids, depending on their nature, usually suppress endogenous steroid hormone production including aldosterone through feedback mechanisms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hyperkalemia is a potent stimulator of aldosterone secretion as aldosterone functions primarily to regulate potassium levels in the body, promoting its excretion through the kidneys while enhancing sodium reabsorption, crucial for maintaining electrolyte balance and blood pressure.

questions.text: What is the prevalence of a disease with an incidence of a disease of 4 cases per 1000 individuals in the population and an average duration of 2 years? [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) 8/1000

 

Prevalence represents the total number of cases of a disease in a population at a given time. It can be calculated using the relationship between incidence (the rate of new cases) and the average duration of the disease.

 

Given that the incidence of the disease is 4 per 1000 of the population, and the average duration of the disease is 2 years, we can calculate the prevalence as follows:

 

Prevalence = 4/1000 x 2 = 8/1000 or 0.8%

 

Educational Objective:

 

The prevalence can be calculated using the formula:

 

Prevalence = Incidence x Duration.

choices.text: Causes the enzyme to work faster only

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding an allosteric modifier?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Participates in feedback regulation

 

This statement is generally true. Allosteric modifiers can play a role in feedback regulation, where the products of enzymatic reactions can act as allosteric modifiers to regulate the activity of enzymes in the same metabolic pathway. This helps maintain homeostasis in cellular processes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Desaturates the enzyme: This statement is not true. Allosteric modifiers do not desaturate enzymes. Instead, they can either activate or inhibit enzyme activity by binding to specific allosteric sites.

 

Option B. Causes the enzyme to work faster only: This statement is not entirely accurate. Allosteric modifiers can have both activating and inhibitory effects on enzyme activity. Some can enhance enzyme activity (activate), while others can decrease it (inhibit).

 

Option C. Binds to the catalytic site: This statement is not true for allosteric modifiers. Allosteric modifiers bind to allosteric sites, which are distinct from the catalytic site. The binding of an allosteric modifier at these sites can lead to conformational changes in the enzyme that affect its activity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Allosteric Regulation
 

  1. Allosteric enzyme has one catalytic site where the substrate binds and another separate allosteric site where the modifier binds (allo = other).
  2. Allosteric and substrate binding sites may or may not be physically adjacent.
  3. The binding of the regulatory molecule can either enhance the activity of the enzyme (allosteric activation), or inhibit the activity of the enzyme (allosteric inhibition).
  4. In the former case, the regulatory molecule is known as the positive modifier and in the latter case as the negative modifier.
  5. The binding of substrate to one of the subunits of the enzyme may enhance substrate binding by other subunits. This effect is said to be positive cooperativity. If the binding of substrate to one of the subunits decreases the avidity of substrate binding by other sites, the effect is called negative cooperativity.
  6. In feedback mechanism, one of the intermediates or products will go back and bind to the allosteric site of one of the enzymes involved in the series of reactions, thereby either inhibiting or activating the enzyme.

choices.text: Decreased acetylcholine release at the nerve endings
Decreased synaptic transmission at the myoneural junction

questions.text: Myasthenia gravis is associated with: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Decreased synaptic transmission at the myoneural junction

 

Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune disorder where antibodies target and destroy acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction. This impairs the ability of the neurotransmitter acetylcholine to stimulate muscle contractions, leading to decreased synaptic transmission. The disease is characterized by muscle weakness and fatigue, particularly worsening with activity and improving with rest.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decreased myosin: This option is not related to myasthenia gravis, which primarily affects the neurotransmitter receptors, not the muscle fiber proteins like myosin.

 

Option B. Decreased acetylcholine release at the nerve endings: While decreased acetylcholine release can affect neuromuscular function, in myasthenia gravis, the principal issue is the reduced effectiveness of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction due to antibody-mediated receptor damage, not a reduction in its release. Occurs with pre-synaptic blockers like bungarotoxin of krait causing reduced release of Ach rendering neostigmine ineffective.

 

Option C. Absence of troponin C: This is unrelated to the pathophysiology of myasthenia gravis. Troponin C is involved in the regulation of muscle contraction in skeletal and cardiac muscle, not neurotransmitter release or receptor function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myasthenia Gravis is an autoimmune disease characterized by Ab to postsynaptic acetylcholine receptors. Hence, treated with steroids and immunomodulators.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms causes scombroid fish poisoning? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pseudomonas aeruginosa

 

Scombroid fish poisoning is associated with Pseudomonas aeruginosa. It follows the consumption of both scombroid (mackerel-like) fish and nonscombroid fish that has not been refrigerated properly. The musculature of these dark- or red-fleshed fish undergoes decomposition by Morganella morganii, Escherichia coli, Proteus species, Klebsiella species, and Pseudomonas aeruginosa with consequent decarboxylation of the amino acid L-histidine to form histamine.

 

Symptoms develop within 15-90 min of ingestion. Most cases are mild, with tingling of lips and mouth, mild abdominal discomfort, and nausea. The more severe and commonly described presentation includes flushing, conjunctival hyperemia, pruritus, urticaria, and angioedema. Without treatment, the symptoms generally resolve within 8-12 h.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Salmonella: Incorrect because Salmonella is not typically involved in the histamine production leading to scombroid fish poisoning.

 

Option B. Staphylococcus: Incorrect as Staphylococcus does not contribute to histamine production in fish, which is the primary cause of scombroid poisoning.

 

Option D. Peptostreptococcus: Incorrect because Peptostreptococcus is not associated with the decomposition of fish that leads to histamine production and subsequent scombroid fish poisoning.

 

Educational Objective

 

Scombroid fish poisoning is primarily caused by the decarboxylation of L-histidine into histamine by bacteria such as Pseudomonas aeruginosa in improperly stored fish, leading to a range of symptoms from mild gastrointestinal discomfort to severe allergic reactions.

questions.text: Which among the following is the most common presentation of postpartum nerve injury? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Foot drop

 

Explanation:

 

The most common postpartum nerve injury is an injury to the peroneal nerve, which results in foot drop. This type of injury often occurs during deliveries where the lithotomy position is used for an extended period. The lithotomy position can cause prolonged pressure on the peroneal nerve, which is located near the fibular head, leading to nerve damage.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Peroneal nerve injury: The peroneal nerve is susceptible to compression, especially when the legs are positioned in stirrups for prolonged periods, as is common in the lithotomy position during childbirth.
  • Foot drop: This condition is characterized by an inability to dorsiflex the foot, leading to a dragging foot while walking.
  • Symptoms: Patients may present with weakness in lifting the front part of the foot and toes, a high-stepping gait to prevent the foot from dragging, and numbness or tingling over the top of the foot and the outer part of the upper leg.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Facial palsy: This is not commonly associated with postpartum nerve injuries.

 

Option B. Wrist drop: This condition results from a radial nerve injury and is not a common presentation of postpartum nerve injuries.

 

Option D. Claw hand: This is associated with ulnar nerve injury and is also not a common presentation of postpartum nerve injuries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common postpartum nerve injury is peroneal nerve injury, leading to foot drop, often associated with the lithotomy position used during childbirth.

questions.text: In which of the following devices is Murphy's eye seen? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Endotracheal tube

 

Murphy's eye is a characteristic feature seen in many endotracheal tubes:

 

 

  • Murphy's eye is a hole located on the side of the distal end of an endotracheal tube. It acts as a safety feature.
  • The primary purpose of Murphy's eye is to provide an alternate route for ventilation in case the main lumen of the tube becomes obstructed, either by being pressed against the tracheal wall or by accumulated secretions or blood.
  • In addition to ensuring continued ventilation, Murphy's eye also reduces the risk of trauma to the tracheal mucosa by reducing suction against the tracheal wall when the main tip is occluded.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nasopharyngeal airway: This device does not have a Murphy's eye. It is a simple tube inserted into the nasal passage to maintain an open airway.

 

Option B. Laryngoscope: This is a tool used for visualizing the larynx during intubation and does not have a Murphy's eye.

 

Option C. Bronchoscope: This is an instrument used for visualizing the inside of the airways and does not have a Murphy's eye.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Murphy's eye is an important safety feature found in endotracheal tubes, providing an alternative pathway for ventilation and reducing the risk of mucosal trauma.

questions.text: What is altered in thyroid profile throughout pregnancy? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Total T3 level

 

Explanation:

 

During pregnancy, the thyroid profile undergoes several changes due to physiological adaptations. One significant change is the increase in total T3 and T4 levels. This occurs because of the elevated levels of thyroid-binding globulin (TBG), which increases the amount of bound thyroid hormones. Despite this increase, the levels of free T3 and free T4 remain relatively unchanged.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Thyroid-binding globulin (TBG): The production of TBG increases during pregnancy due to elevated estrogen levels. This leads to higher levels of total T3 and total T4.
  • Free T3 and Free T4: Despite the increase in total hormone levels, the free (unbound) hormone levels remain relatively stable. This is why free T3 and free T4 are preferred for thyroid function testing during pregnancy.
  • TSH: The levels of TSH may decrease slightly in the first trimester due to the thyrotropic effects of hCG (human chorionic gonadotropin), but they generally stabilize in the second and third trimesters.
  • Iodine requirement: Pregnancy increases the body's requirement for iodine by about 50%, due to increased renal clearance and fetal iodine needs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Free T3 level: This remains relatively unchanged during pregnancy.

 

Option B. Free T4 level: This also remains relatively unchanged during pregnancy.

 

Option D. TSH level: While TSH levels can decrease slightly in the first trimester, they typically stabilize throughout the rest of the pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In pregnancy, total T3 and T4 levels increase due to elevated thyroid-binding globulin, while free T3 and T4 levels remain unchanged.

 

Ref: Page no 57, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th edition

questions.text: The X Ray of the skull as shown in the image given below is seen in: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Hyperparathyroidism

 

The given image is the X-ray of the skull is salt and pepper appearance which shows multiple tiny radiolucent lytic lesions due to resorption of the bone by PTH, seen in hyperparathyroidism. There is also a loss of definition between the skull's inner and outer tables.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Multiple myeloma: Multiple myeloma could also show lytic lesions; however, these are typically larger "punched-out" lesions rather than the fine stippling seen in hyperparathyroidism.

 

Option C. Hyperthyroidism: Hyperthyroidism primarily affects soft tissue and can lead to osteoporosis but does not typically show the "salt and pepper" skull appearance.

 

Option D. Paget's disease: Paget's disease of the bone leads to enlarged and misshapen bones due to excessive breakdown and formation of bone. X-rays might show thickening of the bones rather than the fine stippling of hyperparathyroidism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Radiological skull features of hyperparathyroidism are:

questions.text: A elderly patient presents with cutaneous vasculitis, glomerulonephritis, and peripheral neuropathy. Which investigation should be performed next to help you diagnose the condition? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. ANCA

 

The clinical features of cutaneous vasculitis, glomerulonephritis, and peripheral neuropathy are suggestive of a systemic vasculitis affecting small vessels. Anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA) are associated with certain types of small vessel vasculitis, making ANCA testing the next appropriate step in the diagnostic process. The presence of ANCA, depending on its pattern—c-ANCA typically associated with granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly Wegener’s granulomatosis) and p-ANCA with microscopic polyangiitis and Churg-Strauss syndrome—helps in confirming the diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. RA factor: Although rheumatoid factor (RA factor) can be elevated in conditions like mixed cryoglobulinemia, which might present similarly, it is less specific for diagnosing small vessel vasculitis compared to ANCA.

 

Option C. HbsAg: Hepatitis B surface antigen (HbsAg) could be relevant if considering hepatitis B associated vasculitis, but given the clinical presentation, it is less likely the cause of these symptoms.

 

Option D. DIF (Direct Immunofluorescence): While useful in diagnosing immune complex deposition diseases such as immune-complex mediated vasculitis, it is not as directly diagnostic of ANCA-associated vasculitis as ANCA testing itself.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Features are suggestive of small vessel vasculitis.

 

 

Reference - Harrison/Vasculitis syndrome/Chap 363

questions.text: A child presents with left to right shunt and high output cardiac failure. The following is his MRI. What is the diagnosis?  (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Vein of Galen malformation

 

The MRI shown is suggestive of Vein of Galen Malformation (VOGM).

 

VOGM:

 

 

  • C/F: Newborn with high output cardiac failure with intracranial bruit
  • Type of A-V fistula
  • Doppler - Large midline vessel seen
  • MRI – Large flow void.
  • CT angiography – Giant vein of galen draining into straight sinus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dandy-walker malformation: This is a developmental malformation involving the cerebellum and the fluid spaces around it, characterized by an enlarged posterior cranial fossa. It is not associated with the imaging features seen in the provided MRI, which do not show the typical cerebellar and fourth ventricle abnormalities.

 

 

Option C. Pneumocephalus: This condition involves the presence of air within the cranial cavity, typically seen as areas of radiolucency (dark areas) on imaging, which are not present in the provided MRI.

 

Option D. Venous sinus thrombosis: This condition involves a clot within the dural venous sinuses, which would show different imaging characteristics, such as sinus obstruction or evidence of venous congestion, not observed here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vein of Galen malformation is a critical diagnosis to consider in infants presenting with signs of high-output cardiac failure, and it can be identified with specific imaging findings such as large flow voids on MRI indicative of abnormal vascular connections.

questions.text: The following cells seen in the lymph node are indicative of: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Measles

 

The pathognomonic slide for measles is presented. A Warthin-Finkeldey giant cell with sizable clusters of inclusion bodies that resemble grapes may be seen on this image of a lymph node biopsy.

 

The Warthin-Finkeldey cells, which are randomly distributed multinucleate giant cells with eosinophilic nuclear and cytoplasmic inclusion bodies, massive germinal centres, and noticeable follicular hyperplasia are typical features of lymphoid organs.

 

These are pathognomonic of measles and are also found in the lung and sputum. Kimura illness, measles, lymph nodes in HIV+ people, and other disorders are frequently associated with Warthin-Finkeldey type polykaryocytes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Infectious Mononucleosis: This condition typically shows atypical lymphocytes, not multinucleate giant cells with inclusion bodies.

 

Option C. CMV infection: CMV infections lead to the formation of "owl's eye" inclusion bodies predominantly in cells, different from the grape-like clusters seen in measles.

 

Option D. Influenza: Influenza primarily affects the respiratory epithelium and does not lead to the formation of multinucleate giant cells in lymph nodes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of Warthin-Finkeldey giant cells with eosinophilic inclusion bodies resembling grape clusters in a lymph node biopsy is pathognomonic of measles.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman complains of fatigue, weight gain, and increased sensitivity to cold. On physical examination, she has noticeable swelling in her neck the histological image is shown below. Additionally, an ultrasound examination shows that her thyroid gland is diffusely enlarged and has an uneven texture. Which of the following conditions is most likely the cause of her symptoms? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Hashimoto’s thyroiditis

 

The given findings are suggestive of diffuse goitre with clinical hypothyroidism, suggestive of Hashimoto’s thyroiditis.

 

Hashimoto's thyroiditis, also known as chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis, is an autoimmune disorder that results in the destruction of the thyroid gland. Patients often present with hypothyroidism symptoms, such as fatigue, weight gain, and cold sensitivity. As for the histological findings, Hashimoto's thyroiditis is characterized by:

 

  1. Lymphocytic infiltration with germinal centers.
  2. Follicular cell damage.
  3. Reduced colloid and increased fibrous tissue.
  4. Presence of Hurthle cells (or Askanazy cells) which are oxyphilic cells with a granular cytoplasm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Medullary carcinoma: Medullary thyroid carcinoma originates from parafollicular C cells in the thyroid gland. These cells produce calcitonin, and the carcinoma often increases levels of this hormone. The tumor can appear as a firm mass in the neck. Histologically, it contains nests or sheets of cells in an amyloid stroma. It doesn't show the typical lymphocytic infiltration seen in Hashimoto's thyroiditis. Clinical hypothyroidism is not a feature.

 

Option B. Non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma: Rarely, the thyroid gland can be affected by primary thyroid lymphoma, which often arises in the setting of Hashimoto's thyroiditis. However, it would be differentiated by its histological appearance, with large numbers of lymphoid cells but lacking the characteristic features of Hashimoto's, such as Hurthle cells. Hypothyroidism is not a feature.

 

Option C. Grave's disease: Grave's disease is the most common cause of hyperthyroidism. It is an autoimmune disorder where antibodies stimulate the thyroid gland, leading to overproduction of thyroid hormones. Symptoms might include weight loss, increased heart rate, tremors, and exophthalmos (bulging eyes). The histology of Grave's disease is characterized by tall, columnar epithelial cells and scalloped colloid, which is different from the described histological findings.

 

Educational Objective:


Hashimoto's thyroiditis is an autoimmune disorder characterized by lymphocytic infiltration of the thyroid gland, leading to hypothyroidism with symptoms such as fatigue, weight gain, and increased sensitivity to cold.

questions.text: The Bragg peak effect is pronounced in: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Proton

 

The Bragg peak effect is a phenomenon seen with proton therapy, where there is a sharp increase in radiation dose deposition at a specific depth, followed by a rapid decrease. This makes proton therapy particularly effective for targeting tumors with minimal damage to surrounding tissues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. X-ray: X-rays do not exhibit the Bragg peak; they deposit radiation relatively uniformly along their path, leading to more widespread tissue damage.

 

Option C. Neutron: Neutrons, while used in certain types of radiation therapy, do not exhibit a Bragg peak. Their interactions are different, primarily involving nuclear reactions.

 

Option D. Electron: Electrons do have a distinct depth-dose distribution, which includes a peak dose at a certain depth, but it is not as sharp or pronounced as the Bragg peak seen with protons.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Proton beam therapy characteristics:

 

  • It has marked effect with increased depth in the soft tissues.
  • Bragg's peak is their peculiar feature.
  • Ideal agents for treating deep seated tumors.
  • Agent of choice for treatment of clival chordomas.

questions.text: Identify the article in the constitution that is not related to pediatrics? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 42

 

Article 42 says that the state shall make provision for securing just and humane conditions of work and maternity relief. It is not directly related to pediatrics but rather focuses on the welfare of workers and maternity benefits.

 

Other Options:

 

Articles in constitution related to children:

 

Option A. Article 21 A: Right to free and compulsory elementary education in the 6 -14-year age group.

 

Option B. Article 24: Right to be protected from any hazardous employment till 14 years of age.

 

Option C. Article 39 E: Right to be protected from being abused.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Article 42 is not related to pediatrics, as it focuses on working conditions and maternity relief, unlike Articles 21A, 24, and 39E, which are specifically aimed at the rights and protection of children.

questions.text: Which one of these is not used for body fat evaluation? [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Breslow index 

 

  • The Breslow index is a measurement used specifically in dermatology to determine the depth of melanoma, a type of skin cancer. 
  • It measures the thickness of the tumor and is critical for staging the cancer and determining treatment and prognosis. Therefore, it is not related to the assessment of body fat or overall body composition.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Quetelet's index:  This is another name for the Body Mass Index (BMI), which is widely used to estimate body fat based on an individual's weight and height. It provides a useful general indicator of health risks associated with body fat levels.
 

Option B. Total body potassium: This measure is used to estimate body cell mass and, indirectly, muscle mass, since potassium is primarily found in muscle tissue. Total body potassium can be an indicator of body composition, including body fat.
 

Option C. Total body water: This is used to assess hydration status and body composition. The amount of water in the body can be indicative of muscle mass (which holds a high water content) compared to fat (which holds less), thus providing insights into body fat levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Breslow index assesses the depth of melanoma skin cancer. It is crucial to recognize that this index serves a specific purpose in clinical dermatology and oncology, unrelated to nutritional or fitness assessments.

 

Obesity indices are –

 

  • Broca’s Index: Ideal Body Weight (kg) = Height (cm) – 100
  • Quetelet’s Index (Body Mass Index /BMI): BMI = Weight (kg) / Height (m)2
  • Corpulence Index (CI) = Actual weight/Desirable weight
  • Ponderal Index (PI)

choices.text: Sickle cell anemia
Von Willebrand disease type 1

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy complains of multiple episodes of acute severe pain in his fingers and toes which resolves on its own for the past 1 year. Which of the following conditions is he most likely suffering from? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Sickle cell anemia

 

The symptoms described in the question—acute severe pain episodes in the fingers and toes—are characteristic of vaso-occlusive crises, which are a hallmark of sickle cell anemia. These episodes are caused by sickle-shaped red blood cells that obstruct blood flow in small blood vessels, leading to ischemic pain.
