This condition results from a mutation leading to the production of hemoglobin S, which polymerizes under low oxygen conditions, distorting the red blood cells into a sickle shape.

 

 

  • HbF, ↑ WBC, LDH is predictive of clinical severity.
  • Target Hb < 10g/dL (To minimize risk of Sickling episodes due to high viscosity).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alpha-thalassemia: This condition involves a deficiency in the production of alpha globin chains but does not typically manifest with acute pain episodes like sickle cell anemia.

 

Option B. Beta-thalassemia: Like alpha-thalassemia, this involves a problem with globin chain production (beta chains in this case) and also does not typically present with acute pain episodes.

 

Option D. Von Willebrand disease type 1: This is a bleeding disorder, not a hemoglobinopathy, characterized by a qualitative or quantitative deficiency of von Willebrand factor, which helps with blood clotting. It would more commonly present with symptoms related to bleeding rather than ischemic pain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sickle cell anemia should be suspected in patients who present with episodic acute pain in the extremities, a symptom commonly resulting from vaso-occlusive crises due to abnormal sickle-shaped red blood cells blocking blood flow.

 

Reference - Harrison 21 /Hemoglobinopathies/Chapter 98

questions.text: What is the recommended time gap between the application of two live vaccines? [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) 4 weeks

 

  • According to the guidelines of the World Health Organization (WHO), there should be a minimum interval of 4 weeks (28 days) between the administration of two live vaccines.
  • This is to ensure that the immune system has enough time to respond to each vaccine and generate an adequate immune response without interference from the other vaccine.
  • Two live vaccines otherwise can be given together on the same day

 

Educational Objective:

 

General rules for multiple vaccine administration: –

 

  • 2 live vaccines can be given together
  • Live and killed vaccines can be given together
  • Cholera vaccine and Yellow fever vaccine cannot be given together
  • OPV is a live vaccine where single dose is not sufficient for immunization
  • 2 live vaccines can be administered simultaneously at different sites (or at an interval of 4 weeks)

questions.text: Apixaban belongs to which of the following class of drugs? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Factor Xa inhibitor

 

Apixaban is an oral direct factor Xa inhibitor. Other examples of this class of drug includes Rivaroxaban and Edoxaban.

 

It is the DOC for the treatment and prophylaxis of DVT, also for prophylaxis of thrombosis in monovalvular atrial fibrillation (except for severe mitral stenosis where Warfarin is used).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Antifibrinolytic: Antifibrinolytics, such as tranexamic acid, work by inhibiting the breakdown of fibrin, stabilizing clots. Apixaban does not belong to this class.

 

Option C. Oral direct thrombin inhibitor: Oral direct thrombin inhibitors, such as dabigatran, directly inhibit thrombin (Factor IIa). Apixaban does not inhibit thrombin directly; it inhibits Factor Xa.

 

Option D. Parenteral direct thrombin inhibitor: Parenteral direct thrombin inhibitors, such as argatroban and bivalirudin, are administered intravenously and inhibit thrombin directly. Apixaban is not administered parenterally and does not directly inhibit thrombin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Apixaban is an oral direct Factor Xa inhibitor used for the prevention and treatment of thromboembolic events, including deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and thromboembolism in nonvalvular atrial fibrillation.

questions.text: Which of the following nerves is responsible for referred otalgia from tonsillitis? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Glossopharyngeal nerve

 

Since the tonsils and tonsillar fossa are supplied by the glossopharyngeal nerve, any irritation or pain can be referred to the ear along the tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal (Jacobson's) nerve.

 

 

Referred causes of otalgia. Pain is referred via CN V (teeth, oral cavity, TM joint, anterior two-thirds of tongue), C2,3 (cervical spine), CN IX (tonsil, base of tongue, elongated styloid process) and CN X (vallecula, pyriform fossa or larynx).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Facial nerve - This nerve primarily deals with facial expressions and some sensory functions of the face, not typically involved in referred pain from tonsillitis to the ear.

 

Option C. Trigeminal nerve - While it is a significant sensory nerve for the face, it is more commonly associated with referred pain from the teeth, oral cavity, TM joint, and anterior two-thirds of the tongue (via CN V).

 

Option D. Vagus nerve - Involved in sensory functions from the base of the tongue, vallecula, pyriform fossa, and larynx, not directly involved in referred otalgia from tonsillitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Referred otalgia from tonsillitis is most commonly mediated through the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX), highlighting the importance of the nerve's role in sensory transmission from the tonsils and tonsillar fossa to the ear.

 

Ref - Source Dhingra 7th edition pg 143, 144

questions.text: Basiocciput fuses with basisphenoid at what age? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 18-22 years

 

The fusion of the basiocciput with the basisphenoid occurs at around 18-22 years of age. This process is part of the normal skeletal development during late adolescence and early adulthood.

 

Fusion Age: The fusion of these bones is a significant event in the maturation of the cranial base, occurring between the ages of 18 and 22 years. This fusion helps in the formation of a solid and stable base for the skull.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fusion of Basiocciput with basisphenoid is seen around 18-22 years.

questions.text: What is the vector for the condition diagnosed by the image shown below? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sandfly

 

The image shown is of the Leishman-Donovan bodies whose presence are diagnostic of Kala Azar. The vector of Kala Azar is a sandfly.

 

Leishman-Donovan bodies are amastigotes with a double dot appearance containing a nucleus and small rodlike kinetoplast. They are present inside the macrophage.

 

The sandfly serves as the vector for Leishmania parasites. When a sandfly bites a human, it can transmit the parasites which then proliferate within the host's macrophages.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anopheles mosquito: Incorrect, as this mosquito is the vector for malaria, not Kala Azar.

 

Option B. Ixodes Tick: Incorrect, this tick is a vector for diseases like Lyme disease and not for Kala Azar.

 

Option D. Tsetse fly: Incorrect, as Tsetse flies transmit trypanosomes that cause sleeping sickness, not Leishmaniasis.

 

Educational Objective:
 

The presence of Leishman-Donovan bodies inside macrophages is indicative of Kala Azar, a severe form of leishmaniasis transmitted by the bite of infected sandflies. Effective prevention and control are critical in endemic regions to reduce the transmission and impact of this disease.

choices.text: It is associated with facial angiofibroma
They are  associated with a neurocutaneous syndrome

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the given image? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It is associated with facial angiofibroma 

 

The given image shows discrete nodules over the iris, which are referred to as Lisch nodules, and are commonly seen in patients with neurofibromatosis-1 (NF-1). Lisch nodules can present as slightly elevated pigmented areas to distinct ball-like nodules over the iris. Facial angiofibroma (adenoma sebaceum) is a feature of tuberous sclerosis and not neurofibromatosis.

 

NF1 is clinically diagnosed when any 2 of the following 7 features are present:

 

 

Note:

 

Lisch nodules are seen in NF-1; however, it can also be seen in NF-2 sometimes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of Lisch nodules on the iris is associated with Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF1) and is not associated with facial angiofibroma, which is seen in Tuberous Sclerosis Complex, not NF1.

choices.text: Conservative management is the mainstay therapy
Posture of finger is in extension
Pain on passive extension of finger

questions.text: True about acute tenosynovitis is:(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pain on passive extension of finger

 

ACUTE SUPPURATIVE TENOSYNOVITIS

 

  • It is purulent infection of synovial flexor sheath.
  • It may be the result of the spread of adjacent pulp infections or puncture wounds in the flexor creases.

 

 

  • Although the flexor sheath is usually involved, the radial and ulnar bursae may be involved as well.
  • Most common organism – Staphylococcus aureus
  • Most common digits involved – Ring, middle and index fingers
  • Kanavel’s sign:
    • Rigid positioning of finger in flexion
    • Tenderness over tendon sheath (most significant)
    • Severe pain on passive extension of involved digit
    • Fusiform swelling of involved digit

 

 

  • Treatment
    • Immediate treatment with antibiotics and splinting may abort spread of the infection, if symptoms present for less than 48 hours.
    • Established pyogenic tenosynovitis is a surgical emergency – prompt surgical drainage along with antibiotics.
    • If drainage is required, an open or closed irrigation technique can be used.
    • If an open technique is used, healing and rehabilitation are prolonged, and full motion may not be regained.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Conservative management is the mainstay therapy. This statement is false. They gold standard treatment is irrigation and debridement of the flexor sheath.

 

Option B. More commonly involves thumb. This is statement is incorrect. The index, middle and ring fingers are more commonly involved.

 

Option C. Posture of finger is in extension. This statement is incorrect. The affected finger remains in flexion. There is pain on active or passive extension of the finger.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute suppurative tenosynovitis of the finger is a purulent infection of the flexor tendon sheath of the finger.

choices.text: Mixed cellar type
Nodular sclerosis
Lymphocyte predominant
Classical Hodgkin Lymphoma

questions.text: L & H type Reed-Sternberg (RS) cell is seen in: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lymphocyte predominant

 

In lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin lymphoma, L and H type Reed-Sternberg cells are seen.

 

It is distinguished by the presence of lymphohistiocytic (L&H) variant RS cells, also known as LP cells, with a delicate multilobed, puffy nucleus that resembles popped corn (popcorn cell). Other reactive cells, such as eosinophils, are scarce or absent, and RS cells are uncommon.

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. Mixed cell type, B. Nodular sclerosis and D. Classical Hodgkin Lymphoma: These categories of Hodgkin lymphoma typically feature classical RS cells which express CD15 and CD30 and do not have the popcorn-like appearance of the L&H variant.

 

Educational Objective:

 

L & H type Reed-Sternberg cells, displaying a popcorn-like appearance and expressing B-cell markers, are a hallmark of lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin lymphoma.

questions.text: Which section of IPC defines McNaughten's rule? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Section 84 of IPC

 

Section 84 IPC: Act of a person of unsound mind

 

Nothing is an offence which is done by a person who, at the time of doing it, by reason of unsoundness of mind, is incapable of knowing the nature of the act, or that he is doing what is either wrong or contrary to law.

 

Other Options

 

Other 3 options are not related to the McNaughten Rule

 

Educational Objective

 

Section 84 of IPC defines the act of a person of unsound mind and is derived from the McNaughten Rule, providing a legal defense for individuals who commit crimes due to their mental incapacity.

questions.text: Which of the following types of renal stones are produced by laxative abuse? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Ammonium urate

 

Ammonium urate stones are most likely to be seen in patients with laxative abuse.

 

Ammonium urate stones are composed of a combination of ammonia and uric acid. When laxatives are abused, they cause metabolic alkalosis. This alkaline environment can lead to the formation of ammonium urate stones, as ammonium is more soluble in alkaline urine than in acidic urine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Uric acid: Uric acid stones form when the urine is persistently acidic, which can occur in conditions like gout or diseases that cause rapid cell turnover like tumor lysis syndrome. A diet high in purines, certain types of medications, and some genetic factors can contribute to uric acid stone formation. However, these stones are not typically associated with laxative abuse.

 

Option C. Struvite: Struvite stones, also known as infection stones, are associated with urinary tract infections caused by certain bacteria. These bacteria can produce urease, which splits urea in to ammonia, that makes the urine more alkaline, which can lead to struvite stone formation. They are not directly associated with laxative abuse.

 

Option D. Calcium oxalate: Calcium oxalate stones are the most common type of kidney stone. Factors that increase the urine concentration of these constituents can contribute to stone formation. The absorption of oxalate might increase with chronic diarrhea (a potential consequence of laxative abuse), which can contribute to the formation of calcium oxalate stones, however this is not a common feature.

 

Educational Objective:


Laxative abuse can lead to metabolic alkalosis, which creates an alkaline urinary environment, predisposing to the formation of ammonium urate stones.

choices.text: A patient who died during transportation to the hospital
A patient who died after failed resuscitation after reaching the hospital
A patient who was brought dead to the hospital
A patient who is awaiting death in the hospital

questions.text: Which of the following patients comes under the category III non-heart-beating donor? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. A patient who is awaiting death in the hospital

 

Non-heart beating donor = Donation after circulatory death (DCD)

 

Category III non-heart-beating donors, also known as Donation after Circulatory Death (DCD), specifically refers to patients who are anticipated to have an imminent cardiac arrest, usually while in the hospital. These patients are often on ventilator support, and the decision to withdraw life-sustaining treatment is made due to irreversible medical conditions. The donation process is planned, and organs are procured once circulatory death is confirmed following the withdrawal of support.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A patient who died during transportation to the hospital: This would typically fall under Category I (Dead on Arrival) if they arrive with irreversible cardiac arrest.

 

Option B. A patient who died after failed resuscitation after reaching the hospital: This falls under Category II, which involves unsuccessful resuscitation efforts in the emergency room.

 

Option C. A patient who was brought dead to the hospital: Similar to option A, this is classified under Category I.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Modified Maastricht Classification categorizes DCD:

 

 

Reference - Harrison 21/Renal transplantation/Table 313-1.

questions.text: Sacubitril is a new drug approved for chronic heart failure. The mechanism of action of Sacubitril is? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Neutral endopeptidase inhibitor

 

Sacubitril is a Neprilysin inhibitor (Neutral Endopeptidase inhibitor). Neprilysin is the enzyme that metabolizes Atrial Natriuretic Peptide, Substance P, Bradykinin, Adrenomedullin and Angiotensin II. It is used in a 1:1 ratio with Valsartan (Angiotensin Receptor Blocker), thereby increasing the levels of the other substances which helps in decreasing the blood pressure in a patient of chronic heart failure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Angiotensin II inhibitor: Sacubitril does not directly inhibit angiotensin II. However, valsartan, which is combined with sacubitril in the fixed-dose combination, blocks the effects of angiotensin II at its receptor.

 

Option B. ACE inhibitor: Sacubitril is not an ACE inhibitor. ACE inhibitors work by inhibiting the angiotensin-converting enzyme, which decreases the production of angiotensin II. Sacubitril, on the other hand, inhibits neprilysin.

 

Option C. Renin inhibitor: Sacubitril is not a renin inhibitor. Renin inhibitors, such as aliskiren, work by directly inhibiting renin, an enzyme involved in the RAAS pathway.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sacubitril is a neprilysin (neutral endopeptidase) inhibitor used in combination with valsartan to treat chronic heart failure. By inhibiting neprilysin, sacubitril increases the levels of natriuretic peptides and other vasoactive substances, leading to beneficial cardiovascular effects.

questions.text: Vanillyl mandelic acid is excreted in urine in which of the following conditions?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pheochromocytoma

 

Pheochromocytoma is a tumor of the adrenal glands that can produce excess catecholamines, such as adrenaline and noradrenaline. These catecholamines are metabolized in the body, and one of the metabolites is vanillyl mandelic acid (VMA). Elevated levels of VMA in urine can be indicative of pheochromocytoma. This is because the tumor's excessive catecholamine production leads to increased VMA excretion in the urine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Alkaptonuria: Alkaptonuria is a rare genetic disorder characterized by the accumulation of homogentisic acid in the body, not VMA. Therefore, VMA is not excreted in the urine in this condition.

 

Option C. Carcinoid syndrome: Carcinoid syndrome is associated with neuroendocrine tumors called carcinoids. While carcinoid tumors can produce serotonin and other substances, VMA is not a typical marker for this syndrome.

 

Option D. Diabetic ketoacidosis: Diabetic ketoacidosis is a complication of diabetes characterized by high blood sugar and the production of ketones. It does not involve the excretion of VMA in the urine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The half-life of epinephrine is very short, only 2-5 minutes. Epinephrine is catabolized in tissues, by catechol-O-methyl transferase (COMT) to metanephrines.

 

It is then acted upon by monoamine oxidase (MAO). MAO will oxidatively deaminate compounds having the amino group attached to the terminal carbon atom. The major end product is 3-hydroxy-4-methoxy mandelic acid or vanillyl mandelic acid (VMA).

 

Normal level of excretion of VMA is 2–6 mg/24 h. It is increased in pheochromocytoma (epinephrine excess) and in neuroblastoma (norepinephrine excess).

choices.text: Contralateral loss of joint sense and position
Contralateral loss of pain sensation
Ipsilateral loss of complete sensory functions
Contralateral motor functions

questions.text: Which is the characteristic pattern seen in Brown-Sequard syndrome? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Contralateral loss of pain sensation

 

Brown Sequard syndrome is produced due to lateral hemi-section of spinal cord.

 

Clinical features include:

 

  1. Ipsilateral weakness +
  2. Ipsilateral loss of joint position and vibratory sense +
  3. Contralateral loss of pain & temperature sense one or two levels below lesion +
  4. Ipsilateral segmental signs like radicular pain, muscle atrophy, or loss of tendon reflex

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Contralateral loss of joint sense and position: Incorrect, as joint sense and position loss occur ipsilaterally due to dorsal column damage.

 

Option C. Ipsilateral loss of complete sensory functions: Incorrect, sensory loss is not complete and is dissociated; pain and temperature sensations are lost contralaterally while proprioception and vibration are lost ipsilaterally.

 

Option D. Contralateral motor functions: Incorrect, motor function loss (weakness or paralysis) occurs ipsilaterally below the level of the lesion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Brown-Sequard syndrome, the characteristic neurological pattern includes ipsilateral motor weakness and proprioceptive loss, alongside contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation, due to a lateral hemisection of the spinal cord.

choices.text: Competitively blocking the binding of ACh to its receptors
Repetitive stimulation of ACh receptors on muscle endplate
Inhibiting the calcium channels on presynaptic membrane

questions.text: Mechanism of action of the curare group of muscle relaxants is?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Competitively blocking the binding of ACh to its receptors 

 

  • The curare group of muscle relaxants are non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agents.
  • These drugs act by binding to the acetylcholine (ACh) receptors at the neuromuscular junction without activating them.
  • This competitive inhibition prevents acetylcholine from binding to its receptors, thereby inhibiting the action of acetylcholine and leading to muscle paralysis.
  • This prevents the muscle from contracting, resulting in muscle relaxation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Persistently depolarizing at neuromuscular junction: This describes depolarizing muscle relaxants, such as succinylcholine, which bind to and open the acetylcholine receptors on the muscle endplate. This causes a prolonged depolarization and prevents the muscle from repolarizing, thereby causing paralysis.

 

Option C. Repetitive stimulation of ACh receptors on muscle endplate: This does not describe the mechanism of any muscle relaxant. Persistent or repetitive stimulation would cause sustained depolarization leading to muscle paralysis, but this is not how the curare group works.

 

Option D. Inhibiting the calcium channels on presynaptic membrane: Some drugs inhibit calcium channels, preventing the release of neurotransmitters, including acetylcholine. However, this is not the mechanism of action of the curare group of muscle relaxants.

 

Educational Objective :

 

  • The curare group of muscle relaxants work by competitively blocking the binding of acetylcholine to its receptors at the neuromuscular junction, leading to muscle paralysis.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 779

questions.text: Where is the electrode placed in cochlear implant procedures? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Scala tympani

 

The electrode of a cochlear implant is placed in the Scala tympani.

 

A cochlear implant works by producing meaningful electrical stimulation of the auditory nerve where degeneration of the hair cells in the cochlea has progressed to a point such that amplification provided by hearing aids is no longer effective.

 

The principle of cochlear implant surgery is to place the electrode array within the scala tympani of the cochlea. This allows the electrodes to be in close proximity to the spiral ganglion cells and their dendrites (that lie in the modiolus and osseous spiral lamina of the cochlea, respectively).

 

There are broadly two surgical techniques to approach the cochlea for implantation:

 

  1. The facial recess approach where a simple cortical mastoidectomy is done. The facial recess is opened by performing a posterior tympanotomy. The stapes, promontory and round window niche are identified. Cochleostomy is then performed anteroinferior to the round window membrane to a diameter of 1.0 - 1.6 mm depending on the electrode to be used.
  2. The pericanal techniques where a tympanomeatal flap is elevated to perform a cochleostomy either by endaural or postaural approach. In the pericanal techniques a bony tunnel is drilled along the external canal towards the middle ear. The examples of pericanal techniques include the Veria and suprameatal recess approach.

 

The following criteria help define candidacy for cochlear implantation:

 

  1. Bilateral severe to profound sensorineural hearing loss.
  2. Little or no benefit from hearing aids.
  3. No medical contraindication for surgery.
  4. Realistic expectation.
  5. Good family and social support toward habilitation.
  6. Adequate cognitive function to be able to use the device.

 

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Round window - Not typically the site for electrode placement in cochlear implants.

 

Option B. Oval window - Also not used for electrode placement; this structure connects the middle ear to the inner ear.

 

Option C. Scala vestibuli - Another perilymph-filled cavity in the cochlea, but not the preferred location for electrode placement due to its anatomy and relation to the auditory pathways.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The scala tympani is the preferred site for electrode placement in cochlear implant surgery to ensure optimal auditory nerve stimulation, highlighting the importance of precision in surgical approaches to maximize the benefits of the implant.

choices.text: Lunate at place while others dislocate
Lunate is displaced while other are at place
Lunate is displaced volarly while carpus dislocate dorsally

questions.text: Perilunate dislocation is defined as:(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lunate at place while others dislocate

 

WRIST DISLOCATION

 

 

A. Normal; B. Lunate dislocation; C. Perilunate dislocation; D. Normal

 

1. Lunate dislocation

 

  • Lunate dislocates anteriorly but the rest of the carpals remain in position

 

 

A. Pie sign; B. Spilled tea pot sign

 

2. Perilunate dislocation

 

  • Lunate remains in position and the rest of the carpals dislocate dorsally.
  • Perilunate dislocation is more common
  • Most common type: Trans-scaphoid perilunate fracture dislocation
  • Complications: AVN, osteoarthritis and median nerve injury
  • Median nerve is most commonly injured nerve
  • The most commonly used method for closed reduction is Tavernier’s maneuver.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Lunate is displaced while other are at place. This occurs in lunate dislocation.

 

Option C. Capitate dislocates volarly. This is rarely seen. There is dislocation of distal end of capitate at the capitate-metacarpal joint. It involves disruption of the joint and the intercarpal ligaments of the distal carpal row and minimally displaced fracture of trapezoid. This type of injury can be missed during the evaluation.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

Perilunate dislocation is defined as the dislocation of all carpal bones except for the lunate, which remains at its place.

questions.text: Which of the following cranial nerve develops from second brachial arch? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Facial nerve

 

Branchial arches are also known as pharyngeal arches
 

The facial nerve is the nerve of the 2nd pharyngeal arch.

 

The facial nerve (seventh cranial nerve) is responsible for the motor innervation of the muscles of facial expression. Additionally, it provides taste sensation for the anterior two-thirds of the tongue and supplies parasympathetic fibers to the submandibular, sublingual, and lacrimal glands. The facial nerve is associated with the second brachial (or pharyngeal) arch.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glossopharyngeal nerve: The glossopharyngeal nerve is the ninth cranial nerve (CN IX) arising from the medulla oblongata and is associated with the third brachial (or pharyngeal) arch. It supplies sensation to the posterior third of the tongue, the upper pharynx, and the tonsil. It also has motor functions for the stylopharyngeus muscle and provides parasympathetic fibers to the parotid gland.

 

Option B. Trigeminal nerve: The trigeminal nerve is the fifth cranial nerve (CN V) and is primarily a sensory nerve for the face, with a smaller motor component for the muscles of mastication. The nerve develops in association with the first brachial (or pharyngeal) arch. It divides into three primary branches: the ophthalmic, maxillary, and mandibular nerves.

 

Option D. Vagal nerve: The vagus nerve is the tenth cranial nerve (CN X). It has a wide distribution and serves multiple functions in the body. Its functions include supplying motor innervation to the muscles of the pharynx and larynx, providing sensory information from the external ear and parts of the pharynx, and carrying parasympathetic fibers to thoracic and abdominal viscera. The vagus nerve is associated with the fourth (and a contribution from the sixth) brachial (or pharyngeal) arch.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 25-year-old male having pain and deformity of the tibia as shown in X-ray. He had history of trauma 2 years back. What is the most probable diagnosis?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chronic osteomyelitis

 

CHRONIC OSTEOMYELITIS

 

  • Usually a sequela of inadequately treated acute osteomyelitis.
  • Causative organism: staphylococcus aureus
  • Presenting Complaints:
    • A chronic discharging sinus is the commonest presenting symptom.
    • The onset of sinus may be traced back to an episode of acute osteomyelitis during childhood.
    • Often sinuses heal for short periods, only to reappear with each acute exacerbation.
    • Discharge: Quality of discharge varies from seropurulent to thick pus.
    • There may be a history of extrusion of small bone fragments from the sinus.
    • Pain: Pain is usually minimal but may become aggravated during acute exacerbations.
    • Generalized symptoms of infection such as fever etc., are present only during acute exacerbations.
       
  • Radiological Features:
    • Thickening and irregularity of the cortices
    • Patchy sclerosis
    • Bone cavity: This is seen as an area of rarefaction surrounded by sclerosis.
    • Sequestrum: It is a piece of dead bone, surrounded by infected granulation tissue. It is pathognomic of chronic osteomyelitis. This appears denser than the surrounding normal bone because the decalcification which occurs in normal bone, does not occur in dead bone. Granulation tissue surrounding the sequestrum gives rise to a radiolucent zone around it. A sequestrum may be visible in soft tissues. It acts as nidus of infection and is the most common cause of non-healing sinus in chronic osteomyelitis. A chronic persistent neutrophilic discharge may be seen.
    • Involucrum is the dense sclerotic bone overlying a sequestrum formed from deep layers of stripped periosteum. It is usually obvious by the end of 2nd week.
    • If infection persists, pus and tiny sequestrated spicules of bone may continue to discharge from the perforations called cloacae.

 

 

  • Rim sign is seen on MRI.

 

 

  • Treatment:
    • Treatment of chronic osteomyelitis is primarily surgical.
    • Paprika sign is the appearance of the live bone after removal of sequestrum.
       

 

  • Antibiotics are useful only during acute exacerbations and during postoperative period.
  • Various surgical options are:
    • Sequestrectomy
    • Saucerisation
    • Curettage
    • Excision of an infected bone
    • Amputation

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ewing’s sarcoma. Ewing sarcoma is the fourth most common primary malignancy of bone, but it is the second most common (after osteosarcoma) in patients younger than 30 years of age and the most common in patients younger than 10 years of age. Its maximum incidence is seen in 2nd decade of life. Pain is an almost universal complaint of patients. In addition to pain, patients also may have fever, erythema, and swelling suggesting osteomyelitis. Laboratory studies may reveal increased WBC count, an elevated ESR, and an elevated CRP. Classically, Ewing sarcoma appears radiographically as a destructive lesion in the diaphysis of a long bone with an “onion skin” periosteal reaction. Ewing sarcoma more often originates in the metaphysis of a long bone, but frequently extends for a considerable distance into the diaphysis. Lung is the most common site of metastases. The worst prognostic factor is the presence of distant metastases. Even with aggressive treatment, patients with metastases have only a 20% chance of long-term survival. The treatment include neoadjuvant or adjuvant chemotherapy, or both, to treat distant metastases. Chemotherapy is much more effective and include vincristine, actinomycin D, cyclophosphamide, bleomycin, adriamycin, ifosfamide and etoposide.

 

  • ABCD: Actinomycin D / Bleomycin / Cyclophosphamide / Doxorubicin
  • Best results are achieved by Preoperative chemotherapy; then wide excision (or amputation) if tumor is in favorable site and further chemotherapy for 1 year. Subsequently Radiotherapy may be given.

 

 

Option C. Osteosarcoma. Osteosarcoma is a radiation-induced sarcoma. It is characterized by the production of osteoid matrix by malignant cells. It is the second most common primary malignancy of bone after multiple myeloma. It is most commonly seen in the distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus. All patients report progressive pain. Night pain is also reported in about 25% patients. Characteristic findings are Codman’s triangle and Sunburst periosteal reaction. It is the most radioresistant bone tumor and treated by chemotherapy followed by limb salvage surgery/amputation followed by chemotherapy.

 

 

Option D. Stress fracture of tibia. A tibial shaft stress fracture is an overuse injury where normal or abnormal bone is subjected to repetitive stress, resulting in microfractures. It is commonly seen in runners. There is linear microfracture in trabecular bone from repetitive loading. The patient have pain directly over the fracture which initially worsen after running. Diagnosis can often be made on radiographs alone but MRI studies should be obtained in patients with normal radiographs with a high degree of suspicion for stress fracture. Lateral x-ray shows dreaded black line anteriorly, endosteal thickening, periosteal reaction with cortical thickening. Treatment is activity restriction with protected weight-bearing in most cases. Surgical intramedullary nailing is recommended in the presence of an anterior tibia tension-sided stress fracture ("dreaded black line").

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The radiological image shown in the question and the clinical symptoms described are suggestive of chronic osteomyelitis.

choices.text: The surgeon must use chromic catgut.
The surgeon must not include the submucosa in the sutures.
The surgeon must use the single layer, extramucosal suture technique.
The surgeon must use the single- layer seromuscular suture technique.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the hospital with symptoms of an inguinal hernia. During the operation, the surgeon observes a segment of necrotic bowel in the hernial sac. What is the appropriate course of action for resection and anastomosis of a necrotic bowel seen during surgery? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. The surgeon must use the single layer, extramucosal suture technique.

 

The single-layer, extramucosal suture technique of Halstead involves using a single layer of sutures to join the two ends of the bowel together, while avoiding the mucosal layer. This technique is less time-consuming than the double-layer technique and reduces the risk of complications such as bleeding, stricture formation, and anastomotic leak. This is one of the preferred techniques in small bowel anastomosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The surgeon must use chromic catgut:  Chromic catgut is a type of absorbable suture that is made from the collagen found in sheep or goat intestine. Chromic catgut has a relatively short duration of tensile strength, and so it is not recommended for use in areas of high tension or stress, including intestinal anastomosis.

 

Option B. The surgeon must not include the submucosa in the sutures: The submucosa is a layer of tissue beneath the mucosal lining of the bowel. It should be included in sutures as it is the toughest layer of the bowel.

 

Option D. The surgeon must use the single-layer seromuscular suture technique: The single-layer seromuscular suture technique involves suturing the seromuscular layer of the bowel to join the two ends together. This technique is quick and easy to perform but may not be suitable for all cases as it can increase the risk of anastomotic leakage and stenosis. Therefore, it is important to assess each case individually and choose the appropriate technique based on the specific circumstances.

 

Educational Objective:


The single-layer extramucosal suture technique is the preferred method in small bowel anastomosis to reduce complications such as bleeding, strictures, and anastomotic leaks.

questions.text: A 45-year-old lady complains of post-coital bleeding. She has a positive pap smear. What is the next line of management? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Colposcopy directed biopsy

 

Explanation:

 

A positive pap smear indicates the presence of some cytological abnormality (such as epithelial or glandular cell abnormalities). The next appropriate step is to perform a colposcopy and directed biopsy. Colposcopy provides a magnified view of the cervix, allowing for the identification and biopsy of abnormal areas. During the colposcopy, scoring systems like Ried’s index or Swede’s score are used to evaluate the severity of the pathology, and cervical biopsy samples are taken from acetowhite areas identified during the procedure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cone biopsy (Conization):

 

  • Conization is typically reserved for situations where there is:
    • Unsatisfactory colposcopic findings (where the entire lesion cannot be visualized).
    • Inconsistent findings between colposcopy, cytology, and directed biopsy.
    • Positive endocervical curettage.
    • When biopsy cannot rule out invasive cancer from carcinoma in situ (CIS) or microinvasion.

 

Option C. Repeat pap smear:

 

  • This is not preferred in this scenario as the exact abnormality on the pap smear is not specified. In cases of low-grade squamous intra-epithelial lesion (LSIL) with negative HPV, a repeat pap smear with HPV testing may be advised, but this is not applicable here.

 

Option D. Hysterectomy:

 

  • Hysterectomy is never indicated solely for an abnormal pap smear. It is considered only if the colposcopic-directed biopsy shows:
    • Cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN) associated with other gynecologic problems such as prolapse, fibroids, pelvic inflammatory disease, or endometriosis.
    • Persistent dyskaryotic smear despite treatment.
    • High-grade CIN in elderly women.
    • Patients with poor compliance for follow-up.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Following a positive pap smear indicating abnormal cytology, the next step is to perform a colposcopy and directed biopsy to further evaluate and manage the cervical pathology.

 

Ref: Page no 329, Dc Duttas Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: A newborn presented with a tuft of hair over the lumbosacral region. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Any of the above

 

Occult spinal dysraphism is a condition where there is a defect in the fusion of midline embryonic neural, vertebral, and mesenchymal structures, and it can be presented in newborns with a tuft of hair over the lumbosacral region. Typically, patients with occult spinal dysraphism have a cutaneous abnormality overlying the lower spine, such as a small dimple, a tuft of hair, or a subcutaneous lipoma. These abnormalities can be a sign of underlying spinal cord abnormalities, and it's important to evaluate them thoroughly to rule out any serious underlying conditions.

 

Spinal dysraphism includes-

 

Open spinal dysraphism: Myelomeningocele, meningocele

Occult spinal dysraphism:

  • Spina bifida occulta
  • Spinal lipoma
  • Dermal sinus
  • Tethered cord
  • Split cord malformation (diastematomyelia)
  • And others
     

 

 

 

The initial investigation is usually ultrasound in the neonate and the best investigation is MRI.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of a tuft of hair over the lumbosacral region in a newborn may indicate occult spinal dysraphism, which includes conditions such as spina bifida occulta, spinal lipoma, and dermal sinus, all of which can be signs of underlying spinal abnormalities requiring thorough evaluation, typically starting with ultrasound and definitive imaging with MRI.

questions.text: Low serum copper levels attributed to ATP7A gene is due to: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Menke’s disease

 

  • Menke's disease, also known as Menkes Kinky Hair syndrome, is caused by mutations in the ATP7A gene. This gene is crucial for the absorption and distribution of copper in the body. The mutation leads to reduced intestinal absorption of copper, resulting in low serum copper levels. This deficiency affects multiple systems, including neurodevelopment and connective tissue maintenance, often leading to severe developmental delay and life expectancy that rarely exceeds early childhood (Children die within 5 years). The condition is also associated with characteristic brittle, kinky hair, and growth retardation.
  • MCC: CVS-Aneurysmal dissection/Cardiac rupture

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dubin-Johnson syndrome: This is a liver disorder characterized by chronic jaundice and does not involve ATP7A or copper metabolism.

 

Option B. Wilson's disease: Although related to copper metabolism, Wilson's disease is due to mutations in the ATP7B gene, not ATP7A, leading to copper accumulation in tissues.

 

Option D. Gilbert's syndrome: This is a common hereditary condition that affects bilirubin metabolism, unrelated to copper levels or ATP7A.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Menke's disease is characterized by a genetic mutation in the ATP7A gene leading to poor copper absorption and severe systemic deficiencies, notable for its profound impact on early development and survival.

 

Reference - Harrison/Chap 333.

questions.text: What is the causative organism of angular conjunctivitis? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Moraxella lacunata

 

  • Moraxella species are gram-negative diplococci that can cause angular conjunctivitis.
  • Angular conjunctivitis is characterized by inflammation of the inner and outer canthi, skin excoriation, and a collection of dirty-white, foamy discharge at the angles.
  • Moraxella axenfeld, Moraxella lacunata, and Moraxella catarrhalis are common causes of angular conjunctivitis, while Staphylococcus aureus is a rare cause.
  • The source of infection is the nasal tract of healthy people and the nasal discharge of patients with angular conjunctivitis.
  • The infection spreads from the nasal cavity to the eye through contaminated hands and handkerchiefs.
  • Oxytetracycline is the preferred treatment for angular conjunctivitis, with a duration of 10 to 14 days.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Haemophilus influenzae: While this organism can cause bacterial conjunctivitis, it is not specifically associated with angular conjunctivitis.

 

Option C. Adenovirus type 32: Adenoviruses can cause viral conjunctivitis, including epidemic keratoconjunctivitis, but they are not the typical cause of angular conjunctivitis.

 

Option D. Coxsackie B virus: This virus can cause viral infections including conjunctivitis, but it is not the usual causative agent for angular conjunctivitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary causative organism of angular conjunctivitis is Moraxella lacunata, which is a gram-negative diplococci. The infection spreads from the nasal cavity to the eyes through contaminated hands and handkerchiefs, and is characterized by inflammation of the canthi and a dirty-white, foamy discharge. The preferred treatment is oxytetracycline for 10 to 14 days.

questions.text: A patient presents with frequent urination, nocturia, and enuresis. 24-hour urine volume was measured and recorded to be 7 liters. The urine osmolarity was 260 mOsm/L. ADH assay was performed and the recorded values were reported as 0.8 pg/mL. An MRI of the brain was performed and T1 weighted indicated the absence of the bright spot. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Pituitary DI

 

The patient's symptoms of frequent urination, nocturia, and enuresis combined with a large urine output (7 liters) and low urine osmolarity (260 mOsm/L) suggest a deficiency in ADH effect. The low ADH level (0.8 pg/mL) and the absence of the bright spot on T1 weighted MRI (indicative of a pituitary abnormality) further support the diagnosis of Pituitary Diabetes Insipidus (DI). In Pituitary DI, ADH (vasopressin) is not adequately produced by the hypothalamus or released from the posterior pituitary, which leads to reduced water reabsorption in the kidney and subsequent polyuria.

 

Approach to Polyuria:

 

  • Water vs solute diuresis: (first thing to know)
  • Water diuresis: DI, Primary polydipsia
  • Solute diuresis:
    • Glycosuria (Hyperglycemia, SGLT2 inhibitor use)
    • Iatrogenic hyper-osmolar agents (Hypertonic saline, Mannitol, Urea - from high-protein tube feeding, Radiocontrast agents)
    • Salt wasting (e.g., Medullary cystic disease, Diuretics, CSWS, Obstructive uropathy -especially if B/L, resolving ATN)
  • Before giving desmopressin → S. Na+ should be 145(or) P. Osm should be > 295.
  • If this cannot be achieved (usually due to severe thirst) during water deprivation - Alternative for water deprivation is Hypertonic saline infusion to achieve S. Na > 145 or P. Osm > 295 - then desmopressin test can be performed.
  • Hypertonic saline (to ↑P. Osm) + Plasma AVP measurement in response to ↑ P. Osm due to hypertonic saline. Plasma AVP is unstable and needs stringent storage techniques. Based on AVP levels- can diagnose pituitary vs nephrogenic vs primary polydipsia. Diagnostic accuracy is questionable.

 

 

**Plasma Co-Peptin (analogues to C-peptide of insulin) can be used for central vs nephrogenic DI.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nephrogenic DI: Incorrect because it typically involves normal or high levels of ADH, but the kidneys do not respond to it. The patient's ADH is low, making this diagnosis less likely.

 

Option B. Primary polydipsia: This is associated with excessive fluid intake leading to large volumes of dilute urine but generally will not affect ADH levels significantly, and the brain MRI would typically be normal.

 

Option D. Mannitol infusion: This causes an osmotic diuresis due to the mannitol not being reabsorbed in the renal tubules. There is no evidence of mannitol administration in the patient's history.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MMS algorithm for finding out the cause:

choices.text: Uptake of genetic material by other bacteria

questions.text: Bacterial transduction occurs by? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bacteriophage

 

Transduction is a mechanism of genetic exchange in bacteria where DNA is transferred from one bacterium to another via a bacteriophage, a type of virus that infects bacteria. This process involves a phage accidentally incorporating bacterial DNA during the assembly phase within a previously infected host cell. When this phage infects another bacterium, it can introduce the previously acquired bacterial DNA into the new host's genome, facilitating genetic exchange.

 

Other methods of exchange of genetic material are:

 

  • Transformation involves the uptake of genetic material from the environment, which is released by other bacteria.
  • Conjugation is the direct transfer of DNA from one bacterial cell to another bacterial cell through a sex pilus or bridge. The transferred DNA is a plasmid, a circle of DNA that is distinct from the main bacterial chromosome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Plasmids: Incorrect, as plasmids are involved in conjugation, not transduction. They are small, circular DNA molecules within bacteria that can replicate independently of chromosomal DNA.

 

Option B. Sex pili: Incorrect, sex pili are involved in conjugation, where they facilitate the direct transfer of DNA between bacterial cells.

 

Option D. Uptake of genetic material by other bacteria: Incorrect, this describes transformation, where bacteria take up DNA from their environment, not through a virus-mediated process.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transduction facilitated by bacteriophages represents a crucial mechanism of horizontal gene transfer in bacteria, contributing to genetic diversity and the spread of traits such as antibiotic resistance among bacterial populations.

questions.text: Roth spots are seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Acute leukemia

 

  • Roth's spots are retinal hemorrhages with white or pale centers, named after Moritz Roth.
  • Roth spots are classically described in and are considered as pathognomonic of Subacute Bacterial Endocarditis with the yellowish-white centre consisting of a focus of embolic infection.
  • They are commonly seen in other conditions as well.
  • In leukaemia, the white center typically represents fibrin-platelet plugs.
  • Roth's spots are composed of coagulated fibrin, including platelets, focal ischemia, inflammatory infiltrate, infectious organisms, or neoplastic cells.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Uveal melanoma: A primary cancer of the eye involving the iris, ciliary body, or choroid, not typically associated with Roth spots.

 

Option C. Uveal lymphoma: A rare type of eye cancer affecting the uvea, not commonly associated with Roth spots.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Roth's spots may be seen in -

 

1. Leukemia

2. Diabetes

3. Subacute bacterial endocarditis

4. Hypertensive retinopathy

5. HIV retinopathy

6. Systemic lupus erythematosus

7. Anemia

8. Pre-eclampsia

9. Anoxi

questions.text: Which of the following inhibits the synthesis of glucocorticoid?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Metyrapone

 

Metyrapone is a drug that inhibits the synthesis of glucocorticoids by blocking the enzyme 11β-hydroxylase. This enzyme is crucial for the final step in the biosynthesis of cortisol in the adrenal cortex. By inhibiting this enzyme, metyrapone reduces the production of cortisol and is used in the diagnosis and management of Cushing's syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mifepristone: Mifepristone is an anti-progestogen and also acts as a glucocorticoid receptor antagonist but does not inhibit the synthesis of glucocorticoids.

 

Option B. Flutamide: Flutamide is an androgen receptor antagonist used primarily in the treatment of prostate cancer. It does not affect glucocorticoid synthesis.

 

Option C. Finasteride: Finasteride is a 5-α reductase inhibitor used in the treatment of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) and androgenic alopecia. It inhibits the conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone (DHT) and has no effect on glucocorticoid synthesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mifepristone is an Anti-Progestogen.

 

Flutamide is an androgen receptor antagonist.

 

Finasteride is a 5-α Reductase inhibitor.

 

Metyrapone is enzyme 11ß-hydroxylase inhibitor.

choices.text: Impairment of consciousness
Being unaware of one's problems
Difficulty in identifying known faces
Failure to identify objects

questions.text: What is Prosopagnosia?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Difficulty in identifying known faces

 

Explanation

 

Prosopagnosia (also known as face blindness or facial agnosia) is a neurological disorder characterized by the inability to recognize faces. An autonomic response may be produced in response to a familiar face.

 

Note - Prosopagnosia is not related to memory dysfunction, memory loss, impaired vision, or learning disabilities. The disorder is thought to be the result of congenital influence, damage, or impairment in a fold in the brain that appears to coordinate the neural systems controlling facial perception and memory (right fusiform gyrus). 

 

Face recognitions is represented mainly in the right inferior temporal lobe, but left lobe is also involved and injury to this area cause prosopagnosia. Prosopagnosia can result from stroke, traumatic brain injury (TBI), or certain neurodegenerative diseases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Impairment of consciousness: Incorrect because prosopagnosia specifically relates to difficulty in recognizing faces, not general impairments of consciousness.

 

Option B. Being unaware of one's problems: Incorrect as this describes anosognosia, not prosopagnosia.

 

Option D. Failure to identify objects: Incorrect because this defines object agnosia, whereas prosopagnosia is specifically the inability to recognize faces.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prosopagnosia is the inability to recognize faces, often due to damage to the right fusiform gyrus and related brain areas involved in facial perception and memory, distinct from general memory loss or vision impairment.

 

Note:

 

  • Autotopagnosia - inability to recognize or to orient different parts of one's own body
  • Simultagnosia -the inability to perceive more than one object at a time.
  • Somatagnosia - inability to identify any part of the body, either one's own or another's body
  • Tactile agnosia (stereognosia) - inability to recognize objects by touch

choices.text: The "ebb" phase is associated with a decline in body temperature and oxygen consumption
The "flow" phase occurs after resuscitation from a state of shock
The "ebb" phase is aimed at reducing posttraumatic energy depletion
The "ebb" phase leads to activation of the innate immune system and induction of the hepatic acute-phase response

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about Cuthbertson's metabolic ebb and flow responses to trauma?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. The "ebb" phase leads to activation of the innate immune system and induction of the hepatic acute-phase response

 

Explanation

 

The "flow" phase (not "ebb") leads to activation of the innate immune system and induction of the hepatic acute-phase response.

 

Cuthbertson's ebb and flow response to trauma:

 

A short ebb phase characterized by hypometabolism occurs immediately after the injury and is characterized by a decrease in metabolic rate, oxygen consumption, body temperature, and enzymatic activity. The ebb phase is followed by a longer hypermetabolic flow phase marked by an increased catabolism, with a high oxygen consumption and an elevated resting energy expenditure rate.

 

The "flow" phase occurs after resuscitation from a state of shock, which leads to an increased metabolic turnover, activation of the innate immune system and induction of the hepatic acute-phase response.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The "ebb" phase is associated with a decline in body temperature and oxygen consumption: Correct, this describes the initial hypometabolic state following trauma.

 

Option B. The "flow" phase occurs after resuscitation from a state of shock: Correct, marking the transition to a hypermetabolic state.

 

Option C. The "ebb" phase is aimed at reducing posttraumatic energy depletion: Correct, as it focuses on conserving energy immediately after trauma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The statement that the "ebb" phase leads to activation of the innate immune system and induction of the hepatic acute-phase response is false. These processes are characteristics of the "flow" phase, which occurs after the initial ebb phase and involves increased metabolic activity and systemic responses aimed at recovery and defense.

questions.text: Which of the following poisons cause bluish discoloration of the stomach mucosa on postmortem examination? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sodium amytal

 

Sodium amytal poisoning is known to cause bluish discoloration of the stomach mucosa on postmortem examination. This distinctive feature helps in identifying the presence of this substance in cases of poisoning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oxalic acid

 

  • Symptoms: Severe abdominal pain, vomiting, hypocalcemia, renal failure.
  • Postmortem Findings: Erosion and ulceration of the gastrointestinal tract.

 

Option C. Soneryl

 

  • Description: A barbiturate used as a sedative-hypnotic.
  • Postmortem Findings: central nervous system depression.

 

Option D. Atomic number 33 (Arsenic)

 

  • Symptoms: Gastrointestinal distress, garlic-like odor on breath, multi-system organ failure.
  • Postmortem Findings: Hemorrhagic gastroenteritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bluish discoloration of the stomach mucosa on postmortem examination is a characteristic finding in sodium amytal and copper sulphate poisoning.

choices.text: It uses cell-free circulating fetal DNA in the maternal serum
It can be confirmatory test of trisomy 13, 18 and 21
It can be performed after 10 weeks of gestation
It is done after the routine first trimester ultrasound assessment

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about non-invasive prenatal testing? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It can be confirmatory test of trisomy 13, 18 and 21

 

Explanation:

 

Non-invasive prenatal testing (NIPT) is a screening tool, not a diagnostic tool. It uses cell-free fetal DNA circulating in the maternal serum to screen for certain genetic conditions, including trisomies 13, 18, and 21.

 

NIPT is not used for diagnosis but for screening. It has high sensitivity (about 99%) for detecting trisomies 21, 18, and 13, but positive results must be confirmed with diagnostic tests such as chorionic villus sampling (CVS) or amniocentesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It uses cell-free circulating fetal DNA in the maternal serum: Correct. NIPT uses cell-free circulating fetal DNA in the maternal serum to assess the risk of certain genetic conditions in the fetus.

 

Option C. It can be performed after 10 weeks of gestation: Correct. NIPT can be performed after 10 weeks of gestation, when there is enough fetal DNA in the maternal blood for accurate analysis.

 

Option D. It is done after the routine first trimester ultrasound assessment: Correct. NIPT is often done after the routine first trimester ultrasound assessment, which helps determine gestational age and detect multiple pregnancies or major anomalies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Non-invasive prenatal testing (NIPT) is a screening test for aneuploidy using cell-free fetal DNA in maternal serum, typically performed after 10 weeks of gestation.

 

Ref: Page 890, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: Cutis marmorata occurs due to? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Exposure to cold temperature

 

  • Cutis marmorata, also known as physiological livedo reticularis, describes the pinkish-blue mottled or marbled appearance of the skin that occurs when exposed to cold temperatures.

 

Fig: Cutis marmorata

 

  • During infancy, about half of all children exhibit a noticeable marbling pattern on their skin when exposed to cooler temperatures.
  • This effect arises from the simultaneous dilation and contraction of the superficial capillaries and may continue throughout early childhood.
  • However, the skin returns to its regular appearance when warmed again, indicating that this is a natural physiological response and does not necessitate any intervention.
  • Nevertheless, persistent cutis marmorata may be observed in individuals with trisomies 18 and 21.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Exposure to hot temperature

 

 

Erythema Ab Igne over thigh

 

 

Option B. An adverse reaction to drugs: They can cause various skin manifestations, including rashes, urticaria, or specific reactions like Stevens-Johnson syndrome, but not cutis marmorata.

 

Option D. Humidity: It is not known to cause cutis marmorata. High humidity can lead to other skin issues like sweating and chafing, but it does not cause the vascular changes seen in cutis marmorata.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cutis marmorata is a skin condition characterized by a marbled appearance of the skin, resulting from exposure to cold temperatures due to the vascular response of constriction and dilation.

 

References

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition, Chapter 25, Page no 125.7

 

Question Level – Intermediate

Question Id-7447 Unique Key-Q6575185

questions.text: Which of these options is not a means of directly transmitting communicable diseases? [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Droplet nuclei

 

  • Airborne transmission by droplet nuclei is a method of indirect transmission of diseases.
  • Droplet nuclei are tiny particles of size 1-5 microns range that may be formed by either due to evaporation of droplets coughed or sneezed into the air or are formed from aerosols.
  • These droplet nuclei remain airborne for long periods of time and can transmit diseases like tuberculosis, influenza, chickenpox, measles, Q fever and other respiratory infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Direct Transmission Methods:

 

Option A. Vertical transmission: This occurs when infections are passed from mother to child during pregnancy, childbirth, or breastfeeding. Examples include HIV and congenital syphilis.

 

Option B. Contact with soil (B): Direct contact with contaminated soil can lead to infections. Soil-transmitted helminths and diseases like tetanus are examples.

 

Option D. Droplet transmission: This involves large respiratory droplets (typically greater than 5 microns) that are expelled when an infected person coughs, sneezes, or talks. These droplets can travel short distances and infect individuals through mucosal surfaces (e.g., eyes, nose, mouth). Examples include the common cold, influenza, and COVID-19.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Droplet nuclei represent an indirect transmission method, as they can remain airborne for long periods and travel over distances, whereas vertical transmission, contact with soil, and droplet transmission are forms of direct transmission of communicable diseases.

questions.text: Kala-Azar is endemic in all these regions except: [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Assam

 

Kala-Azar, also known as visceral leishmaniasis, is a parasitic disease caused by the Leishmania donovani parasite. It is transmitted through the bite of infected sandflies.

 

Kala-Azar is not endemic in Assam. It is endemic in the following states in 54 districts:

 

  • Uttar Pradesh
  • West Bengal
  • Bihar
  • Jharkhand

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Saturnine gout is seen in: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lead poisoning

 

Saturnine Gout:

 

  • Description: Saturnine gout is a type of gout caused by chronic lead intoxication. This can result from occult or occupational exposure to lead, or from the ingestion of moonshine (illegally produced alcohol that may contain lead contaminants).
  • Incidence: Accounts for less than 5% of gout cases.
  • Mechanism: Lead induces tubulointerstitial renal damage, which impairs the kidneys' ability to excrete uric acid, leading to hyperuricemia (excessive uric acid in the blood).
  • Clinical Features:
    • Similar to primary gout, but with a predilection for affecting the knee more than the first metatarsophalangeal joint (big toe).
    • Hyperuricemia in Saturnine gout exceeds the reduction in glomerular filtration rate (GFR), meaning the high uric acid levels are disproportionate to the kidney's filtration capacity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cadmium poisoning: Symptoms: Kidney damage, osteomalacia (bone softening), and respiratory issues.

 

Option C. Beryllium poisoning: Symptoms: Respiratory problems, chronic beryllium disease (CBD), and lung cancer.

 

Option D. Mercury poisoning: Symptoms: Neurological and behavioral disorders, kidney damage, and gastrointestinal disturbances.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Saturnine gout is a specific type of gout caused by chronic lead poisoning, characterized by hyperuricemia and tubulointerstitial renal damage.

questions.text: Sabin-Feldman dye test is used for diagnosis of which of the following condition? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Toxoplasmosis

 

Sabin-Feldman dye test is used for the diagnosis of toxoplasmosis.

 

It is based on the principle that the presence of anti-toxoplasma antibodies in the patient's serum inhibits the staining of trophozoites by alkaline methylene blue dye.

 

Toxoplasma trophozoites and complement are added to the patient's serum which is then incubated for an hour at 37°C. After incubation, methylene blue dye is added.

 

If anti-toxoplasma antibodies are present in the serum, these are activated by complement and the parasite membrane is lysed. Thus, the trophozoites are not stained (positive result).

 

If there are no antibodies, trophozoites will take up the stain and appear blue under the microscope. This is considered to be a negative result.

 

The dilution of the test serum at which 50% of the tachyoites are not stained is reported as the antibody titer of the test serum. The test is highly sensitive and specific.

 

It cannot differentiate between recent or past infections as it detects only IgG antibodies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Paragonimiasis: Incorrect, as the Sabin-Feldman dye test is not used for diagnosing Paragonimiasis.

 

Option B. Hydatid cyst: Incorrect, the diagnosis of hydatid disease is primarily performed using imaging techniques and the Casoni skin test.

 

Option D. Cryptococcus: Incorrect, Cryptococcus infections are typically diagnosed using fungal cultures and cryptococcal antigen tests.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Sabin-Feldman dye test remains a gold standard for the serological diagnosis of Toxoplasmosis due to its ability to detect the presence of specific antibodies against Toxoplasma gondii, reflecting the body's immune response to the infection.

 

Additional Information

 

Skin test for diagnosis of parasitic infections:

 

  1. Casoni test – Hydatid disease
  2. Montenegro test – Kala azar
  3. Frenkel test – Toxoplasmosis
  4. Fairley test – Schistosomiasis
  5. Bachman test – Trichinellosis

questions.text: Tom-Smith arthritis destroys: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Femoral capital epiphysis

 

TOM SMITH ARTHRITIS

 

  • It is septic arthritis of hip in infants which destroy the cartilaginous femoral head rapidly and completely (chondrolysis).
  • It is caused by non-tuberculous bacteria.
  • This intra-articular infection in children peaks in first few years of life with 50% patients younger than 2 years of age.
  • Males affected more than females – 2:1 ratio
  • Hip joint is more commonly involved, followed by knee joint.
  • Risk factors:
    • Prematurity
    • Caesarean section
    • Treatment in NICU
    • Invasive procedures like umbilical/venous catheterization, heel puncture
       
  • Clinical features: 
    • Child presents with limp, unstable gait
    • Shortening of limb
    • Positive telescopy
    • Increased hip movements in all direction
    • Limb position – flexion, abduction, external rotation (FABER)
    • Fever
    • Unable to bear weight
       
  • In 55% cases, no organism is identified.
    • Streptococcus is most commonly seen in neonates
    • Staphylococcus aureus is commonly seen in children over 2 years of age
    • Neisseria gonorrhoeae is commonly seen in adolescents
       
  • Kocher criteria is used for diagnosis:
    • WBC > 12,000 cells/ml of serum
    • Inability to bear weight
    • Fever > 101.3°F
    • ESR > 40 mm/h
    • Additional criteria – CRP (Modified Kocher criteria)
       
  • Investigations:
    • Elevated WBC – leukopenia
    • Elevated ESR – may be normal in early course of infection
    • CRP may increase in first 6-8 hours of infection
    • Hip aspirate will show high WBC, low glucose levels, high lactic acid levels
       
  • Radiographic findings:
    • X-ray may be normal in early stages
    • Shows widening of joint space, subluxation/dislocation

 

 

  • Treatment: 
    • Non-operative: antibiotics
    • Operative: surgical irrigation and debridement followed by IV antibiotics
       
  • Prognosis:
    • Good prognosis
    • Delayed diagnosis may result in permanent joint damage and long-term disability. 
    • Long-term morbidity includes acetabular dysplasia, subluxation and dislocation, cartilage necrosis, limb length discrepancy, abnormal/premature closure of proximal femoral physis, ischemic necrosis, and complete destruction of femoral head
    • Poor prognostic factors:
      • Age < 6 months
      • Associated osteomyelitis
      • Delay of > 4 days until presentation
      • Hip joint involvement

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acetabular roof. Acetabular roof lesions are uncommon in children. If they occur, their cause can be eosinophilic granuloma, ewing’s sarcoma, non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma, metastases, and neuroblastoma.

 

 

Option C. Femoral neck. Femoral neck is affected in children in femoral neck fractures due to high-impact injuries, but this is uncommon. Benign bone tumors or tumor-like bone lesions in the femoral neck can also be the cause.

 

Option D. Greater trochanter. Avulsion fractures of greater trochanter are very rare in children. They can be secondary to gluteal muscle contraction, femoral neck fracture, hip dislocation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tom smith arthritis or the septic arthritis in children, most commonly affects the femoral capital epiphysis.

choices.text: Child is delivered after death of biological father
Child is born to an unmarried couple
Child is abandoned by the parents

questions.text: A posthumous child can be best defined as: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Child is delivered after death of biological father

 

  • A posthumous child is defined as a child who is born after the death of one of their biological parents, typically the father. This term is most commonly used to describe children whose fathers passed away before they were born.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Delivery of a macerated fetus: A macerated fetus refers to a fetus that has died in utero and has undergone specific changes due to prolonged retention in the uterus.

 

Option C. Child is born to an unmarried couple: This describes the marital status of the parents and does not pertain to the death of a parent.

 

Option D. Child is abandoned by the parents: This refers to a situation where a child is left without care by their parents.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A posthumous child is one who is born after the death of one of their biological parents, most commonly the father.

questions.text: Corticosteroid indicated for the stimulation of fetal lung maturation in preterm labor is? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Betamethasone

 

Corticosteroids are used in pregnant females delivering premature babies in order to prevent Respiratory Distress Syndrome in the newborn due to inadequate levels of surfactants in the lungs of premature babies. Corticosteroids also reduce the chances of development of Necrotizing Enterocolitis and Intraventricular Hemorrhage in the newborn.

 

For this purpose, we can use either Dexamethasone or Betamethasone.

 

Dose:

 

  1. Dexamethasone 6 mg 12 hourly x 4 doses
  2. Betamethasone 12mg 24 hourly x 2 doses

 

Total dose should be 24 mg in 48 hrs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hydrocortisone: Hydrocortisone is not typically used for fetal lung maturation. It is more commonly used for adrenal insufficiency and inflammatory conditions.

 

Option B. Triamcinolone: Triamcinolone is not indicated for the stimulation of fetal lung maturation. It is primarily used for its anti-inflammatory effects in various conditions.

 

Option C. Methylprednisolone: Methylprednisolone is also not typically used for this purpose. It is often used for its potent anti-inflammatory and immunosuppressive properties in various conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Betamethasone is the corticosteroid of choice for stimulating fetal lung maturation in preterm labor, administered to reduce the risk of neonatal respiratory distress syndrome and other complications associated with preterm birth.

questions.text: The following scan is of a young woman on oral contraceptives. The most likely diagnosis is: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Hepatic adenoma

 

The image given is of hepatic adenoma which is the most frequent hepatic tumor in young women on oral contraceptive pills. Hepatic adenomas are benign liver tumors, predisposed in patients on OCPs and glycogen storage disorders with a predilection for hemorrhage. They are enhancing lesions on the arterial phase.

 

  • Liver tumors - IOC: Triple phase CT
  • Typical appearance of hemangioma

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hepatocellular carcinoma: More commonly associated with chronic liver disease and hepatitis B or C infections.

 

Option B. Metastatic infiltrates: Typically appear as multiple lesions with variable enhancement patterns depending on the primary cancer's nature.

 

Option D. Hemangioma: The most common benign liver tumor, characterized by its classic "light bulb" bright enhancement on T2-weighted MRI images, not typically associated with oral contraceptive use.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatic adenomas are benign liver tumors often associated with the use of oral contraceptive pills (OCPs). They occur more frequently in young women and are known for their risk of hemorrhage.

questions.text: Long-standing pelvic inflammation may lead to which of the following conditions? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pyometra

 

Explanation:

 

Long-standing pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) involves infection and inflammation of the upper genital tract, which can include the uterus, fallopian tubes, and ovaries. PID can result from sexually transmitted infections and, if left untreated, can lead to several serious complications.

 

Complications of long-standing pelvic inflammation include:

 

  1. Infertility: Due to damage to the fallopian tubes and the resulting adhesions, which can block the passage of eggs from the ovaries to the uterus.
  2. Ectopic pregnancy: Scarring of the fallopian tubes can cause a fertilized egg to implant outside the uterus, most commonly in the tubes.
  3. Pyometra: Accumulation of pus within the uterine cavity, often due to obstruction of the cervical canal combined with chronic infection.
  4. Dyspareunia: Pain during sexual intercourse, often due to adhesions and chronic pelvic pain.
  5. Chronic pelvic pain: Persistent pain in the lower abdomen, which can be severe and debilitating.
  6. Frozen pelvis: Severe adhesions can cause the pelvic organs to become fixed in place, leading to significant pain and dysfunction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Uterine polyposis: Uterine polyposis involves the development of benign polyps within the endometrial cavity and is not typically a direct result of PID.

 

Option C. Pseudocyesis: Pseudocyesis, or false pregnancy, is a psychological condition where a woman believes she is pregnant and may exhibit pregnancy symptoms, but is not related to PID.

 

Option D. Endometrial hyperplasia: Endometrial hyperplasia refers to the thickening of the endometrial lining due to excess estrogen stimulation and is not a direct consequence of PID.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Long-standing pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) can lead to serious complications such as infertility, ectopic pregnancy, chronic pelvic pain, and pyometra.

 

Ref: Page no 155, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: Identify the Mallampati class of this patient? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Class II

 

The image shows a Mallampati class II airway.

 

  • The Mallampati classification, sometimes referred to as the Mallampati score or Mallampati test, is a system used to predict the ease of endotracheal intubation. It correlates the visibility of the base of the uvula, faucial pillars, and the soft palate with the ease of laryngeal visualization and intubation.
  • Class I: Hard palate, Soft palate, entire uvula, and tonsillar pillars are visible.
  • Class II: Hard palate, Soft palate and base of the uvula are visible.
  • Class III: Only hard palate and  soft palate is visible.
  • Class IV: Only hard palate is visible.

 

 

The primary purpose of the Mallampati classification is to assess the potential difficulty of intubation in patients prior to surgery or in any other situation requiring airway management. A higher Mallampati score generally indicates a more challenging intubation. Anesthesiologists and surgeons use the Mallampati classification as a component of the preoperative airway assessment. This assessment helps them to be prepared for potential airway challenges during surgery and determine if specialized equipment or techniques might be necessary.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Class I: This classification is incorrect as the image does not show all the structures visible in Class I, such as the uvula and pillars.

 

Option C. Class IV: This classification is incorrect because the image does not show only the hard palate, which would be indicative of Class IV.

 

Option D. Class III: This classification is incorrect as the image shows more structures than what would be visible in Class III, where only the soft palate is visible.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Mallampati classification is a useful tool for predicting the difficulty of intubation, with higher classes indicating more challenging airways. The image provided corresponds to Mallampati class II, where the soft palate and base of the uvula are visible.

questions.text: What is the most common causative organism for verruca vulgaris? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Human papillomavirus-2

 

  • The hands, fingers, and knees of young children are the areas that are most frequently affected with common warts.
  • Verruca vulgaris or common wart is most commonly caused by human papillomavirus-2 (HPV-2) but is also related to types 1, 4, 27, and 57.

 

Below image depicts Verruca vulgaris:

 

 

Common warts typically have no symptoms. They appear as firm papules with a rough horny surface and exhibit acanthosis, hyperkeratosis, and papillomatosis. Pseudo-Koebner phenomenon may be observed.

 

Treatment:

 

Topical – Salicylic acid, formalin, caustics etc.

 

Other:

 

  • Laser
  • Cryotherapy
  • Surgical removal

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Human papillomavirus-3 (HPV-3): While HPV-3 is a strain of the virus that can cause warts, it is not the predominant strain for verruca vulgaris.

 

Option B. Human papillomavirus-7 (HPV-7):

  • HPV-7 is associated with butcher's warts, which are common among meat handlers.
  • This strain is not the primary one responsible for the verruca vulgaris seen in the general population.

 

Option D. Human papillomavirus-1 (HPV-1): HPV-1 is mainly responsible for plantar warts, which appear on the soles of the feet as shown in the below image.

 

 

  • It is not the primary strain for verruca vulgaris on the hands and fingers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Human papillomavirus-2 is the most common cause of verruca vulgaris (common warts), which is important for understanding the etiology and guiding treatment options for these lesions.

 

References

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition Chapter 25, Page no 25.43, 25.47, 25.48, 25.52

Andrew's Diseases of the Skin: Clinical Dermatology - 11th Edition Chapter 19, Page no 401

Online resources:

https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/9434721/
