https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK321770/

questions.text: Which of the following atypical antipsychotics has the highest risk of galactorrhea? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Risperidone

 

The antipsychotics work by blocking the D2 receptors in various parts of the brain. The dopaminergic block in the Tuberoinfundibular pathway leads to increase in the levels of Prolactin (As physiologically Dopamine has a negative feedback effect on Prolactin). Typical antipsychotics like Haloperidol have a very high risk of hyperprolactinemia. Among the atypical antipsychotics, Risperidone has the highest risk of galactorrhea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Iloperidone: Iloperidone has a lower risk of causing hyperprolactinemia and galactorrhea compared to risperidone.

 

Option C. Clozapine: Clozapine has a relatively lower risk of causing hyperprolactinemia and galactorrhea among atypical antipsychotics. It is known for its efficacy in treatment-resistant schizophrenia but has other significant side effects, such as agranulocytosis.

 

Option D. Aripiprazole: Aripiprazole is a partial agonist at D2 receptors and is associated with a lower risk of hyperprolactinemia and galactorrhea. In some cases, it can even be used to counteract hyperprolactinemia caused by other antipsychotics.

 

Mechanism of Hyperprolactinemia

 

  • Dopamine: Acts as an inhibitory regulator of prolactin secretion via D2 receptors in the tuberoinfundibular pathway.
  • Antipsychotics: By blocking D2 receptors, they remove this inhibition, leading to increased prolactin levels.
  • Prolactin: Elevated levels can lead to galactorrhea, menstrual disturbances, and sexual dysfunction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Risperidone is the atypical antipsychotic with the highest risk of causing galactorrhea due to its potent D2 receptor antagonism in the tuberoinfundibular pathway, leading to increased prolactin levels.

questions.text: TB test done only on whole blood sample is:(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Interferon gamma release assay

 

TB test done on a whole blood sample is the interferon-gamma release assay. It has been used for the diagnosis of latent tuberculosis in patients with HIV (who frequently have a negative Mantoux test).

 

Interferon-gamma release assays include:

 

  • QuantiFERON-TB Gold
  • T-SPOT.TB

 

QuantiFERON-TB Gold quantitates the amount of IN- produced by CD4+ T cells in response to the antigens from Mycobacterium tuberculosis. QuantiFERON-TB Gold Plus (QFT- Plus) is an improved version of the QuantiFERON-TB Gold test. QuantiFERON-TB Gold detects only TB-specific CD4+ responses. However, QuantiFeron-TB Gold Plus detects both CD8+ and CD4+ T-cell responses to TB-specific antigens.

 

T-SPOT.TB determines the total number of individual effector T cells expressing IFN-v.

 

The TrueNat TB test is a new molecular test that can diagnose TB in one hour as well as test for rifampicin resistance. This test uses a sputum sample taken from the patient. Only about 0.5 ml of the sample is required. Gene Xpert is also a molecular method of testing that cannot use blood as a sample.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. TrueNat TB: Incorrect, as this molecular test diagnoses TB and tests for rifampicin resistance using a sputum sample, not whole blood.

 

Option B. Gene Xpert: Incorrect, this is another molecular test that identifies TB and resistance to rifampicin but also uses sputum samples rather than whole blood.

 

Option D. All of the above: Incorrect, as only the interferon gamma release assay is designed to be used with whole blood samples.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Interferon gamma release assay is a valuable tool for diagnosing latent TB, particularly suitable for patients who may not be effectively diagnosed through traditional skin tests, offering a sensitive and specific method that utilizes whole blood to detect an immune response to TB antigens.

questions.text: Periodic acid Schiff positive macrophages are seen in: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Whipple's disease

 

Periodic acid Schiff (PAS) positive macrophages are indicative of Whipple's disease, a rare bacterial infection that primarily affects the small intestine but can also impact other parts of the body like the heart, brain, and joints. PAS stains are used to identify polysaccharides, mucopolysaccharides, glycoproteins, and glycolipids in tissues. In Whipple's disease, PAS-positive macrophages in the small bowel biopsy are laden with Tropheryma whipplei bacteria, showing up as granular, magenta-colored inclusions in the cytoplasm of macrophages.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Agammaglobulinemia: This is an immunodeficiency disorder characterized by the absence of gamma globulins in the blood and a lack of mature B cells; it does not feature PAS-positive macrophages.

 

Option C. Abetalipoproteinemia: This is a disorder of lipid metabolism, leading to extremely low levels of cholesterol and triglycerides in the blood; it does not cause PAS-positive staining in macrophages.

 

Option D. Crohn's disease: An inflammatory bowel disease that causes chronic inflammation of the gastrointestinal tract, also not associated with PAS-positive macrophages.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PAS +ve macrophages are seen in:

 

  1. Small bowel biopsy = Chronic Infection (E.g., Whipple’s disease, leishmaniasis, endemic mycoses).
  2. Liver Biopsy: Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency.
  3. Bone Marrow: Disseminated infections vs Storage disorders (Niemann-Pick).

 

Reference - Harrison/Malabsorption syndromes/Chap 176

choices.text: Karyotype is 46 XY
Ovotestis is seen in the gonadal biopsy
The response of testosterone to hCG is increased
Uterus is usually absent

questions.text: What is true about ovotesticular disorders of sex development? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ovotestis is seen in the gonadal biopsy

 

  • Ovotesticular disorder of sex development (DSD) is characterized by the presence of both ovarian and testicular tissue in the same individual.
  • Most affected individuals have a 46, XX chromosomal karyotype, which normally results in female sexual development.
  • In about 10% of patients, testicular tissue in an individual with a 46, XX karyotype is present as a result of a translocation of the SRY gene on the Y chromosome to the X chromosome or another chromosome.
  • An abnormal vagina and underdeveloped uterus are usually present.
  • The testes are usually undescended, and the penis may present with hypospadias.
  • Upon reaching puberty, breast development, feminization, and menstruation may occur.
  • Most affected individuals are infertile, but ovulation or spermatogenesis is possible.
  • The response of testosterone to hCG is normal or reduced.
  • A defect in R-spondin1 protein encoded by the RSPO1 gene is described in 46, XX ovotesticular DSD.
  • An ovotestis is present in approximately 2/3 of affected individuals.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ovotesticular disorder of sex development is characterized by the presence of both ovarian and testicular tissues, typically with a 46, XX karyotype and possible SRY gene translocation, and can present with ovotestis seen on gonadal biopsy.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with bitemporal hemianopia. CT is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Craniopharyngioma

 

A calcified lesion in the suprasellar region suggests craniopharyngioma. It is derived from Rathke's pouch.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Pituitary adenomas are seen in the sellar region in adults. Macroadenomas are seen as snowman or figure of eight appearance.

 

Option B: Meningioma is a supratentorial tumor, mainly in the parasagittal region. A classical Dural tail is seen.

 

Option D: Oligodendroglioma is exclusively found in the cerebral hemispheres, most commonly in the frontal lobes. Up to 90% of oligodendrogliomas contain visible calcification on CT.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Craniopharyngioma should be considered in young patients presenting with symptoms of visual field loss and a calcified suprasellar mass on imaging. This tumor's characteristic location and calcification are key diagnostic clues.

 

Reference– Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 742

questions.text: What is defined as the emotional release and discharge after consciously reliving a painful experience that has been repressed? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Abreaction

 

This term specifically refers to the process of bringing repressed traumatic experiences to consciousness, accompanied by the appropriate emotional response, often leading to relief.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Catharsis: This is a broader term for the release of emotional tension and can occur without specifically reliving a traumatic event.

 

Option C. Venting out: This generally means expressing feelings, especially of anger or frustration, but doesn't necessarily imply working through repressed trauma.

 

Option D. Guided relaxation: This involves being led (usually verbally) to a state of relaxation, and is not directly related to processing repressed emotions.

 

Therefore, "abreaction" best describes the conscious reliving of a painful, repressed experience and the subsequent emotional discharge.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In abreaction, an attempt is made to bring the unconscious memories and emotions into conscious awareness using hypnosis, medications and other techniques.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 860.

questions.text: Defective fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase enzyme is associated with?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Type 1 Tyrosinemia

 

  • True. Type 1 Tyrosinemia, also known as hereditary tyrosinemia type 1 (HT1), is characterized by a deficiency of the enzyme fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase (FAH). This deficiency leads to the accumulation of toxic substances in the body, causing various health problems.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Type 2 Tyrosinemia: False. Type 2 Tyrosinemia is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme tyrosine aminotransferase, not fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase.

 

Option C. Type 3 Tyrosinemia: False. Type 3 Tyrosinemia is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme 4-hydroxyphenylpyruvate dioxygenase, not fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase.

 

Option D. Type 4 Tyrosinemia: False. There is no Type 4 Tyrosinemia. The primary types of Tyrosinemia are Type 1, Type 2, and Type 3.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatorenal Tyrosinemia (Tyrosinemia Type I) aka Tyrosinosis –

 

  • Autosomal recessive, most common type of tyrosinemia.
  • Due to a deficiency of enzyme fumaryl acetoacetate hydrolase.
  • Symptoms manifest by the first 6 months of life and death occurs rapidly. Cabbage like odor and hypoglycemia and eventual liver failure are seen. There may be mild mental retardation.
  • Urine contains tyrosine, para-hydroxyphenyl pyruvic acid (p-HPPA) and hydroxyphenyl lactic acid; and serum shows tyrosine.
  • Tyrosine and phenylalanine restricted diet is advised.

 

Oculocutaneous Tyrosinemia/ Richner-Hanhart Syndrome (Tyrosinemia Type II) is due to deficiency of tyrosine amino transferase (tyrosine transaminase). Mental retardation, keratosis of palmar surface, painful corneal lesions and photophobia are seen. There is increased excretion of tyrosine and tyramine in urine. A diet low in protein is advised.

 

Neonatal Tyrosinemia (Tyrosinemia Type III) is due to the absence of the enzyme para-hydroxyphenylpyruvate hydroxylase. This deficiency may cause transient hypertyrosinemia in the newborn; this will respond to administration of ascorbic acid and dietary protein restriction.

questions.text: A patient is confused, opens his eyes on painful stimuli, flexes one limb on painful stimuli, and can localize the stimulus with the other limb. His Glasgow Coma Score is? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 11

 

The GCS in this patient is 11.

  • The score for verbal response: 4, because he is confused.
  • The score for eye-opening: 2, because his eyes are opening to only painful stimulus.
  • The score for best motor response: 5, because he can localize pain. Though he also flexes on one side (M4), the higher response is counted in GCS.

Therefore, the GCS score is (4+2+5) = 11

 

 

Educational Objective:


The Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) is calculated based on eye response, verbal response, and motor response, with a total score indicating the level of consciousness.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male patient came with complaints of sudden onset ocular pain and haemorrhagic discharge accompanied with diminution of vision. He is suspected to have acute haemorrhagic conjunctivitis. What is the causative organism? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Enterovirus 70

 

Acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis is caused by enterovirus 70, a picornavirus.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Enterovirus 68: Known to cause respiratory illnesses and has been associated with acute flaccid myelitis, but not typically with hemorrhagic conjunctivitis.

 

Option B. Enterovirus 69: Less commonly associated with conjunctivitis and more related to respiratory infections.

 

Option D. Enterovirus 71: Known to cause hand, foot, and mouth disease and severe neurological diseases, but not typically associated with hemorrhagic conjunctivitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Enterovirus 70 is the primary causative organism of acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis, characterized by sudden onset of ocular pain, redness, and hemorrhagic discharge. The condition is highly contagious and typically self-limiting, with supportive care being the mainstay of treatment.

choices.text: Variation in cell size and shape
Replacement of one type of cell by other

questions.text: Anaplasia refers to: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lack of differentiation

 

A lack of differentiation is referred to as anaplasia.

 

Anaplasia means "backward formation," implying a reversal of differentiation to a more primitive level.

 

As a result of anaplasia, morphological and functional changes in the neoplastic cells are observed like:

 

  • Loss of polarity
  • Pleomorphism - variation in the size and shape of cells
  • Increased N: C ratio (nucleus: cytoplasmic ratio) - around 1:5 in normal cells, increases to 1:1 in malignant cells
  • Hyperchromasia - coarsely clumped and darkly stained chromatin within irregular nuclei
  • Nucleolar changes - prominent nucleolus or nucleoli in the nucleus reflecting increased nucleoprotein synthesis
  • Increased mitosis - atypical, bizarre mitotic figures
  • Tumour giant cells
  • Functional (Cytoplasmic) changes

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Variation in cell size and shape: This is a feature of pleomorphism, a characteristic of anaplasia but not the definition of it.

 

Option C. Replacement of one type of cell by another: This describes metaplasia.

 

Option D. Disordered arrangement of tumor cells: This can be a feature seen in anaplastic tumors but is not definitive for anaplasia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anaplasia indicates a high grade of malignancy due to the significant loss of differentiation and structural and functional changes in the neoplastic cells.

questions.text: A patient on angina medication comes to you with erectile dysfunction. Because the patient is being treated with one drug, you decide against prescribing sildenafil, that drug is? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nitrates

 

Nitrates and Sildenafil should not be prescribed together. Sildenafil is a PDE-5 inhibitor that is useful in the treatment of erectile dysfunction. Nitrates are metabolized into NO, that stimulates Guanylate cyclase and increases the level of cGMP and causes vasodilation. For the metabolism of cGMP, Phosphodiesterase enzyme will be needed, and if that is inhibited, then it will lead to severe hypotension due to the potentiation of action of nitrates.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Calcium channel blockers: Calcium channel blockers are used to treat hypertension and angina. They work by relaxing the blood vessels and reducing the heart's workload. They do not interact dangerously with sildenafil.

 

Option B. Beta blockers: Beta blockers are also used to treat hypertension, angina, and other cardiovascular conditions. They reduce the heart rate and the force of contraction, thus reducing the heart's oxygen demand. They do not have a dangerous interaction with sildenafil.

 

Option D. ACE inhibitors: ACE inhibitors are used to treat hypertension and heart failure by relaxing blood vessels. They work by inhibiting the angiotensin-converting enzyme, reducing the production of angiotensin II. ACE inhibitors do not have a dangerous interaction with sildenafil.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nitrates and sildenafil should not be used together due to the risk of severe hypotension from the combined effect on cGMP levels leading to excessive vasodilation.

choices.text: Partial pressure of O2 becomes zero
No exchange of O2 & CO2
CO2 alone equilibrates with the venous blood
Partial pressure of both CO2 and O2 remain normal

questions.text: Va/Q = infinity means? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. No exchange of O2 & CO2

 

Explanation

 

In quantitative terms, the ventilation-perfusion ratio is expressed as Va/Q. When Va (alveolar ventilation) is normal for a given alveolus and Q (blood flow) is also normal for the same alveolus, the ventilation-perfusion ratio (Va/Q) is also said to be normal.

 

  • This ratio explains the respiratory exchange when there is an imbalance between alveolar ventilation and alveolar blood flow
  • When the ventilation (Va) is zero, yet there is still perfusion (Q) of the alveolus, the Va/Q is zero.
  • When there is adequate ventilation (Va) but zero perfusion (Q), the ratio Va/Q is infinity.
  • At a ratio of either zero or infinity, there is no exchange of gases through the respiratory membrane of the affected alveoli.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Partial pressure of O2 becomes zero: Incorrect as partial pressure of O2 will be high in the alveoli but without perfusion, no exchange occurs.

 

Option C. CO2 alone equilibrates with the venous blood: Incorrect because without perfusion, there's no blood flow to equilibrate CO2 levels.

 

Option D. Partial pressure of both CO2 and O2 remain normal: Incorrect because, although the partial pressures in the ventilated alveoli might appear normal or even high for O2, without perfusion, these gases are not effectively exchanged with the blood.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A ventilation-perfusion (Va/Q) ratio of infinity, indicative of ventilation without perfusion, results in no exchange of oxygen (O2) and carbon dioxide (CO2) due to the absence of blood flow to the ventilated alveoli. This scenario highlights the critical balance needed between air delivery to the lungs and blood flow through the pulmonary circulation for effective respiratory gas exchange.

choices.text: It has one artery and two veins
It contains a gelatinous substance called Wharton's jelly
Presence of a single umbilical artery is associated with congenital anomalies
Normal average umbilical cord length is 50-60 cm

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about the umbilical cord? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It has one artery and two veins

 

Explanation:

 

  • The umbilical cord has two arteries and one vein.
  • This 3 vessel umbilical cord appears as a “mickey-mouse sign” manner on the ultrasound finding
  • The umbilical vein carries oxygenated blood from the placenta to the fetus and the 2 umbilical arteries carry deoxygenated blood from the fetus to the placenta

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. It contains a gelatinous substance called Wharton's jelly: Wharton’s jelly is the gelatinous material surrounding the umbilical cord which protects it from external forces

 

Option C. Presence of a single umbilical artery is associated with congenital anomalies: A single umbilical artery is the most common anomaly in an umbilical cord.

 

It is associated with congenital anomalies such as genitourinary and cardiac anomalies

 

It may also be associated with Trisomy 18 (Edward syndrome) and other chromosomal anomalies

 

Option D. Normal average umbilical cord length is 50-60 cm: The average length of the umbilical cord is 50 cm

 

Educational objective:

 

The umbilical cord has two arteries and one vein.

 

Ref: Page no 44, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition

questions.text: Water's view is used to best visualize which of the following sinuses? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Maxillary sinus

 

Waters’ view (occipitomental view or nose-chin position). The X-ray beam is angled at 45° to the orbitomeatal line.

 

In this view, petrous bones are projected below the maxillary antra.

 

Structures seen are:

 

  1. Maxillary sinuses (seen best)
  2. Frontal sinuses
  3. Sphenoid sinus (if the film is taken with an open mouth).
  4. Zygoma
  5. Zygomatic arch
  6. Nasal bone.
  7. Frontal process of maxilla
  8. Superior orbital fissure
  9. Intratemporal fossa.

 

Other 3 Options: Not best visualized in Water's view as this technique primarily highlights the maxillary and other larger sinuses.
 

Educational Objective:
 

Water's view is particularly effective for visualizing the maxillary sinus, making it an essential diagnostic tool in sinus imaging, especially when evaluating issues related to the maxillary sinuses.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 493

questions.text: The Van Nuys grading system for ductal carcinoma in situ does not include:(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Hormone receptor staining

 

Hormone receptor status, which determines if the tumor cells have receptors for hormones like estrogen and progesterone, is not included in the VNPI. While hormone receptor status is crucial for managing invasive breast cancers, as it determines potential responses to hormone therapies like tamoxifen, it's not a component of the Van Nuys grading system for DCIS.

 

Staining for estrogen and progesterone receptors is not part of the Van Nuys system used for grading DCIS.

 

The Van Nuys Prognostic Index (VNPI) is a grading system that helps to stratify patients with ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) based on several factors to determine the likelihood of recurrence and guide treatment decisions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Age of the patient: The age of the patient is one of the factors in the Van Nuys Prognostic Index. Younger age (below 40) is associated with a higher risk of recurrence.

 

Option B. Size of the tumor: Tumor size is an essential factor in the Van Nuys grading system. Larger DCIS lesions (> 4cm) are associated with a higher risk of recurrence. Thus, the size can influence the treatment approach.

 

Option D. Presence of necrosis: In DCIS, the presence or absence of necrosis plays a role in determining the prognosis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Van Nuys grading system for ductal carcinoma in situ does not include Hormone receptor staining.

questions.text: In which condition is excessive urinary excretion of 5- hydroxy indole acetic acid (5HIAA) seen?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Carcinoid syndrome

 

Carcinoid syndrome is the correct answer. It is a condition associated with the overproduction of serotonin by certain tumors, known as carcinoid tumors. Elevated serotonin levels can lead to increased 5HIAA excretion in the urine. This condition is known for causing flushing, diarrhea, and other symptoms.

 

5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid (5HIAA) is a metabolite of serotonin, a neurotransmitter that is produced in the enterochromaffin cells of the gastrointestinal tract. In normal circumstances, most of the serotonin produced in the enterochromaffin cells is metabolized in the liver and then excreted in the urine as 5HIAA. However, in carcinoid syndrome, serotonin-secreting tumors can produce excessive amounts of serotonin that overwhelm the metabolic capacity of the liver, resulting in high levels of urinary 5HIAA.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alkaptonuria is a rare genetic disorder in which homogentisic acid is not properly metabolized, leading to its accumulation in various tissues and the urine. This condition is not related to serotonin metabolism.

 

Option B. Albinism is a genetic disorder that results in reduced or absent production of melanin, the pigment that gives color to the skin, hair, and eyes. This condition is also not related to serotonin metabolism.

 

Option D. Phenylketonuria is an inherited metabolic disorder in which the body cannot properly process the amino acid phenylalanine. This results in the accumulation of toxic byproducts that can lead to intellectual disability, seizures, and other serious health problems. This condition is also not related to serotonin metabolism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Carcinoid syndrome leads to the overproduction of serotonin by carcinoid tumors, resulting in increased levels of its metabolite, 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid (5HIAA), in the urine, which is a diagnostic marker for this syndrome.

choices.text: Deficiency of vitamin K leads to hypercoagulability.
It is a water-soluble vitamin.
Prolonged use of antibiotics leads to vitamin K deficiency.
Menaquinone is the dietary source of vitamin K found in green vegetables.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about vitamin K? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Prolonged use of antibiotics leads to Vitamin K deficiency

 

Option C: Prolonged use of antibiotics leads to vitamin K deficiency.

 

  • True. Prolonged use of certain antibiotics can disrupt the normal gut flora responsible for synthesizing vitamin K. This disruption can lead to a deficiency in vitamin K, which is essential for blood clotting.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Deficiency of vitamin K leads to hypercoagulability.

 

  • False. Vitamin K deficiency does not lead to hypercoagulability. Instead, it leads to hypocoagulability, which means impaired blood clotting. Vitamin K is essential for the activation of clotting factors in the blood, and its deficiency can result in bleeding disorders, not excessive blood clotting.

 

Option B. It is a water-soluble vitamin.

 

  • False. Vitamin K is not a water-soluble vitamin; it is a fat-soluble vitamin. Fat-soluble vitamins, including vitamins A, D, E, and K, are absorbed with dietary fats and are stored in the body's fatty tissues.

 

Option D. Menaquinone is the dietary source of vitamin K found in green vegetables.

 

  • Partially true. While menaquinone (vitamin K2) is a form of vitamin K, the primary dietary source of vitamin K found in green vegetables is phylloquinone (vitamin K1). Both forms of vitamin K are essential for various biological functions.

 

Educational objective:

 

Vitamin K is a fat-soluble vitamin.

 

Sources of vitamin K:

 

  • Green leafy vegetables (Phylloquinone/ Vitamin K1)
  • Synthesis by intestinal bacteria (Menaquinones/Vitamin K2)
  • Menadione is synthetic compound metabolized to phylloquinone.

 

In normal adult dietary deficiency seldom occurs since the intestinal bacterial synthesis is sufficient to meet the needs of the body. However, deficiency can occur in conditions of malabsorption of lipids due to obstructive jaundice, chronic pancreatitis, sprue, etc.

 

Prolonged antibiotic therapy and gastrointestinal infections with diarrhea will destroy the bacterial flora and can also lead to vitamin K deficiency.

 

Vitamin K is necessary for coagulation. Factors dependent on vitamin K are Factor II (prothrombin); Factor VII (SPCA); Factor IX (Christmas factor); Factor X (Stuart Power factor) therefore deficiency will to lead to bleeding disorders.

choices.text: Previous manual removal of placenta

questions.text: Which of the following is not considered as a factor for a high-risk pregnancy? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Previous manual removal of placenta

 

Explanation:

 

Previous manual removal of the placenta does not automatically categorize a subsequent pregnancy as high-risk. High-risk pregnancies are characterized by various factors that may complicate the pregnancy or pose risks to the mother and fetus. These factors include existing health conditions, certain lifestyle factors, age-related risks, and specific pregnancy conditions.

 

High-risk pregnancy factors according to the NIH include:

 

  1. Existing health conditions:
    • Hypertension
    • Diabetes
    • Autoimmune diseases
    • PCOS (Polycystic Ovary Syndrome)
    • Thyroid disorders
    • Obesity
    • HIV
    • Anemia
    • Uterine fibroids
  2. Age:
    • Adolescence
    • First-time pregnancy at age >35 years
  3. Lifestyle factors:
    • Alcohol consumption
    • Smoking
    • Drug use
  4. Pregnancy conditions:
    • Multiple pregnancy
    • Gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM)
    • Pre-eclampsia
    • Previous preterm birth
    • Congenital or chromosomal anomalies
    • Polyhydramnios or oligohydramnios
    • Rh iso-immunization
    • Antepartum hemorrhage
    • Fetal growth restriction

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Obesity: Obesity is a significant factor for a high-risk pregnancy as it is associated with various complications such as gestational diabetes, pre-eclampsia, and increased risk of cesarean delivery.

 

Option B. Polyhydramnios: Polyhydramnios, which is an excessive amount of amniotic fluid, can lead to complications such as preterm labor and fetal malformations, making it a high-risk condition.

 

Option C. Anemia: Anemia during pregnancy can affect the health of both the mother and the fetus, leading to conditions such as preterm birth and low birth weight, thus categorizing it as high-risk.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Previous manual removal of the placenta is not considered a factor for categorizing a subsequent pregnancy as high-risk.

 

Ref: https://www.nichd.nih.gov/health/topics/high-risk

questions.text: The fate of the Mullerian duct is determined by the? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Y chromosome

 

Explanation:

 

The fate of the Mullerian duct is determined by the presence or absence of the Y chromosome, specifically the SRY gene located on the short arm of the Y chromosome. The SRY gene produces testis-determining factor (TDF), which induces the development of the bipotential gonads into testes. The Sertoli cells in the testes secrete Anti-Mullerian Hormone (AMH), which causes regression of the Mullerian ducts, structures that would otherwise develop into female internal genitalia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The fate of the Mullerian duct is determined by the presence or absence of the Y chromosome, specifically the SRY gene, which leads to the secretion of Anti-Mullerian Hormone (AMH) by the Sertoli cells and regression of the Mullerian ducts in males.

choices.text: Cigarette smoking is a risk factor
Carcinoma of body of pancreas often present with jaundice

questions.text: All of these are characteristic features of pancreatic carcinoma except: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Carcinoma of body of pancreas often present with jaundice

 

Patients with carcinoma of the head of the pancreas, not the body develop jaundice. This is due to obstruction of the biliary tract.

 

Etiology of pancreatic carcinoma

 

  1. Heavy cigarette smokers have higher incidence than the non-smokers.
  2. Diet with high total caloric value and high consumption of animal proteins and fats is related to higher incidence of pancreatic cancer. Obesity is a risk factor for pancreatic cancer.
  3. Chemical carcinogens: Individuals exposed to β-naphthylamine, benzidine and nitrosamines have higher incidence of cancer of the pancreas.
  4. Diabetes mellitus: Patients of long-standing diabetes mellitus have a higher incidence.
  5. Chronic pancreatitis patients are at increased risk.
  6. H. pylori infection has been reported to have association with pancreatic cancer.
  7. Genetic factors have been found to have association with pancreatic cancer e.g. its occurrence in first-degree relatives in 10% cases, occurrence in certain hereditary syndromes (Lynch, FPC, HNPCC).

 

Obstructive jaundice is more often and early in the course of disease in cases with carcinoma head of the pancreas (80%), and less often in cancer of the body and tail of the pancreas (as they do not impinge on the biliary duct)

 

Two features are characteristic of pancreatic cancer:

 

  • Highly invasive (even “early” invasive pancreatic cancers extensively invade peripancreatic tissues)
  • Elicits an intense non-neoplastic host reaction composed of fibroblasts, lymphocytes, and extracellular matrix (called a “desmoplastic response”).

 

Dense stromal fibrosis accompanies the invasive cancer, and there is a proclivity for perineural invasion within and beyond the organ. Lymphatic and large vessel invasion are also commonly seen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cigarette smoking is a risk factor: Directly linked to higher incidence rates of pancreatic carcinoma.

 

Option C. They elicit an intense desmoplastic response: Refers to the fibroblastic proliferation in the stroma surrounding the tumor, a hallmark of pancreatic cancer.

 

Option D. Perineural invasion is common: Indicates the aggressive nature of pancreatic cancer, with frequent invasion of nerves by cancer cells, contributing to pain and complex management challenges.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While pancreatic carcinomas are generally associated with intense desmoplastic responses and perineural invasion, jaundice is specifically linked more with carcinoma at the head of the pancreas rather than the body or tail.

questions.text: The replacement dose of hydrocortisone for adrenal insufficiency is: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 15-25

 

  • The replacement dose of hydrocortisone in adrenal insufficiency varies depending on the severity of the condition and the individual needs of the patient. However, the usual starting dose is 15-25 mg of hydrocortisone per day, divided into two or three doses.
  • For those with more severe adrenal insufficiency or during periods of stress, higher doses may be needed, up to 100-150 mg per day, also divided into two or three doses.
  • It is important to note that the replacement dose of hydrocortisone may need to be adjusted over time based on the patient's response to treatment and any changes in their medical condition. Therefore, patients with adrenal insufficiency should be regularly monitored by their healthcare provider to ensure they are receiving the appropriate dose of hydrocortisone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The standard replacement dose of hydrocortisone for adrenal insufficiency is 15-25 mg per day, divided into two or three doses to mimic the body's natural cortisol production. This dose may be adjusted based on individual patient needs and response to treatment.

questions.text: A patient develops prosthetic valve endocarditis 2 years after valve replacement surgery. Which of the following organisms is the most likely cause? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Streptococcus

 

Streptococcus, particularly Streptococcus viridans, is the most likely cause of prosthetic valve endocarditis (PVE) occurring late (more than 12 months after surgery). In the context of PVE, late cases are often similar to native valve endocarditis where Streptococcus viridans is a common pathogen due to its ability to adhere to damaged heart valves and form biofilms. The presentation of endocarditis 2 years post-surgery aligns with this etiological pattern.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Staphylococcus aureus: While a common cause of early prosthetic valve endocarditis (within the first 2 months), its prevalence decreases as the time post-surgery increases.

 

Option C. Coagulase negative staphylococci (CONS): These are more typical in early PVE cases, often within the first 2 months post-surgery, associated with intraoperative contamination.

 

Option D. HACEK organisms: These are a less common cause of endocarditis and are generally not the leading pathogens in prosthetic valve infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prosthetic Valve Endocarditis:

 

  • Early (< 2 months): CONS > S. Aureus
  • Late (> 2-12 months): Similar to native valve -S. viridans

questions.text: Which of these disorders was earlier known as minimal brain dysfunction?  (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder

 

Attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) was earlier referred to as minimal brain dysfunction. ADHD is characterized by symptoms of inattention, hyperactivity, and impulsivity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dyslexia is a specific learning disorder that affects reading, despite normal intelligence. It is characterized by difficulties with accurate and/or fluent word recognition and by poor spelling and decoding abilities.

 

Option C. Mental sub normality is an outdated term, previously used to describe intellectual disabilities or developmental delays.

 

Option D. Oligophrenia is an old term that was used to describe intellectual disability or mental retardation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ADHD, formerly known as minimal brain dysfunction, is characterized by symptoms of inattention and/or hyperactivity-impulsivity. Diagnosis requires symptoms before age 12 in multiple settings. Treatment commonly involves stimulant medications and behavioral therapy.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 1171.

questions.text: Identify the condition represented in the image below: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Miliary tuberculosis

 

The above image represents “miliary tuberculosis”. Individual lesions are small (2-mm) foci of yellow-white consolidation scattered through the lung parenchyma.

 

Miliary tuberculosis is lymphohematogenous spread of tuberculous infection from primary focus or later stages of tuberculosis. The spread may occur to systemic organs or isolated organ. The spread is either by entry of infection into pulmonary vein producing disseminated or isolated organ lesion in different extra-pulmonary sites (e.g. liver, spleen, kidney, brain and bone marrow) or into pulmonary artery restricting the development of miliary lesions within the lung. The miliary lesions are millet seed-sized (1 mm diameter), yellowish, firm areas without grossly visible caseation necrosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Emphysema: This condition is characterized by the abnormal, permanent enlargement of airspaces distal to the terminal bronchioles and the destruction of the alveolar walls. Large subpleural bullae (air-filled spaces >1 cm) may be present, especially in paraseptal emphysema.

 

 

Option C. Sarcoidosis: Typically presents with non-caseating granulomas.

 

 

Option D. Asbestosis: Associated with fibrous thickening and plaque formation primarily in the lung bases.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Miliary tuberculosis appears as small, millet seed-sized yellowish foci scattered throughout the lung parenchyma, indicative of widespread hematogenous dissemination of tuberculosis.

questions.text: What is the ideal number of antenatal visits? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 12-14

 

Explanation:

 

The ideal number of antenatal visits as recommended by various guidelines:

 

  1. MOHFW (Indian guidelines):
    • At least 4 visits including the first (registration visit) – minimum requirement.
    • Suggested schedule:
      • 1st Visit: Within 12 weeks
      • 2nd Visit: 14-26 weeks
      • 3rd Visit: 28-34 weeks
      • 4th Visit: 36 weeks to term
  2. WHO (2016):
    • Recommends 8 visits:
      • 1st Trimester:
        • Contact 1: Up to 12 weeks
      • 2nd Trimester:
        • Contact 2: 20 weeks
        • Contact 3: 26 weeks
      • 3rd Trimester:
        • Contact 4: 30 weeks
        • Contact 5: 34 weeks
        • Contact 6: 36 weeks
        • Contact 7: 38 weeks
        • Contact 8: 40 weeks
  3. ACOG (American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists):
    • Ideally recommends:
      • Once every month till 28 weeks
      • Every 2 weeks till 36 weeks
      • Weekly till 40 weeks
    • This totals approximately 12-14 visits.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ideal number of antenatal visits is 12-14, as recommended by ACOG, ensuring comprehensive prenatal care.

questions.text: Heller's operation is done for: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Achalasia cardia

 

Heller's operation, also known as Heller myotomy, is a surgical procedure designed to treat achalasia. During this procedure, the surgeon makes a series of cuts into the thickened muscle of the LES to allow it to relax and improve the passage of food into the stomach. So, Heller's operation is indeed done for achalasia cardia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Carcinoma esophagus: Carcinoma of the esophagus refers to cancer that starts in the esophagus. While surgeries are often performed for esophageal cancer, Heller's operation specifically is not one of them. Instead, procedures like esophagectomy (removal of all or part of the esophagus) are performed for esophageal cancer.

 

Option C. Esophageal stricture: An esophageal stricture is a narrowing of the esophagus, which can lead to difficulty swallowing. It can result from various causes, including acid reflux or injuries to the esophagus. Esophageal dilatation (stretching of the esophagus using dilators) is commonly done for esophageal strictures.

 

Option D. Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis: Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis is a condition in infants where the muscle at the junction between the stomach and the small intestine (the pylorus) becomes enlarged, leading to obstruction. The treatment for this condition is a surgery called pyloromyotomy, where the thickened muscle is split to relieve the obstruction.

 

In conclusion, among the given options, Heller's operation is specifically done for achalasia cardia (Option A).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Heller's myotomy is a surgical procedure used to treat achalasia cardia by cutting the lower esophageal sphincter muscle to relieve obstruction and improve swallowing.

choices.text: Asking the patient to void and see if the pessary is in place
Seeing if the patient feels any discomfort, which means that the pessary is retained
Asking the patient to perform the Valsalva manuever and see if the pessary is in place
Being able to admit two fingers between the ring and the pessary

questions.text: Which of the following is the first step after fitting the pessary to check if the pessary is adequately retained? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Asking the patient to perform the Valsalva maneuver and see if the pessary is in place

 

Explanation:

 

 

 

A vaginal pessary is a device used to support the pelvic organs in women with uterovaginal prolapse who are either unfit for surgery or unwilling to undergo surgery. The fitting process involves several steps to ensure the pessary is comfortable and effective:

 

  1. Patient Preparation: The patient is positioned in the lithotomy position and should have an empty bladder and rectum.
  2. Vaginal Examination: An assessment of vaginal length and width is performed to estimate the appropriate pessary size.
  3. Insertion: The pessary is lubricated and inserted in a cephalad direction against the posterior vaginal wall.
  4. Placement Check: An index finger is directed into the posterior vaginal fornix to ensure the cervix is above the pessary, and the pessary should fit snugly against the vaginal walls without causing pain.
  5. Adequacy Check: The patient is asked to perform a Valsalva maneuver (forceful exhalation against a closed airway) to see if the pessary remains in place, ensuring it is not dislodged during increased intra-abdominal pressure.
  6. Functionality Check: The patient should be able to stand, walk, cough, and urinate without difficulty or discomfort.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Asking the patient to void and see if the pessary is in place: While checking the ability to void is important, it is not the first step after fitting the pessary.

 

Option B. Seeing if the patient feels any discomfort, which means that the pessary is retained: Patient comfort is crucial, but discomfort does not necessarily mean the pessary is adequately retained.

 

Option D. Being able to admit two fingers between the ring and the pessary: This is not a standard method for checking the fit of a pessary.

 

Educational Objective:

 

After fitting a pessary, the first step to check if it is adequately retained is to ask the patient to perform the Valsalva maneuver and see if the pessary remains in place.

choices.text: 73 degree Celsius for 20 minutes
63 degree Celsius for 30 minutes
72 degree Celsius for 30 seconds
63 degree Celsius for 30 seconds

questions.text: Pasteurization is done at: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 63 degree Celsius for 30 minutes

 

Pasteurization: Milk is heated at either

 

  • 63°C for 30 minutes: the Holder method or
  • 72°C for 15-20 seconds: the flash process

 

followed by cooling quickly to 13°C or lower.

 

All the non-sporing pathogens are killed except Coxiella burnetti, which may survive in Holder method.

 

Educational Objective

 

Pasteurization can be conducted using different time-temperature combinations, primarily the Holder method (63°C for 30 minutes) and the flash pasteurization method (72°C for 15-20 seconds), each designed to ensure the safety of milk consumption while preserving its quality.

choices.text: It is made from cat gut
It is made from rabbit gut
It is absorbed by enzymatic degradation and macrophage phagocytosis
It is tanned with nickel salts to improve handling and to resist degradation in tissue

questions.text: Which of the following is true about chromic catgut? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. It is absorbed by enzymatic degradation and macrophage phagocytosis.

 

True. Chromic catgut is an absorbable suture, which means that it gets absorbed by the body over time. The process involves enzymatic degradation (breaking down by enzymes) and phagocytosis by macrophages (special cells that engulf and digest foreign substances, microbes, and cellular debris).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is made from cat gut: While the term "catgut" might suggest that the material is derived from cats, this is a misnomer. Catgut suture material is historically derived from the submucosal layer of sheep or goat intestines. The term is a shortened version of the word "cattlegut."

 

Option B. It is made from rabbit gut: This statement is also misleading. As mentioned, the primary sources for catgut are sheep and goat intestines, not rabbit.

 

Option D. It is tanned with nickel salts to improve handling and to resist degradation in tissue: This statement is inaccurate in the context of chromic catgut. Chromic catgut is treated with chromium salts, not nickel salts. Chromium salts are used to cross-link the collagen fibers in the catgut, which increases its resistance to degradation, thus prolonging its time before being absorbed in the tissue. This treatment also improves the suture's handling properties.

 

Educational Objective:


Chromic catgut is an absorbable suture material derived from sheep or goat intestines and is absorbed in the body through enzymatic degradation and macrophage phagocytosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is called as Australia antigen? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) HBsAg

 

HBsAg (Hepatitis B surface antigen) is also known as the Australia antigen. It is called so because it was first isolated from the serum of an Australian person.

 

Sera from hepatitis B patients when observed under an electron microscope show three types of particles:

 

  • A spherical particle: 22nm, most abundant, contains only HBsAg.
  • Filamentous or tubular particle: 22m, contains only HBsAg.
  • A double-walled spherical structure: 42m diameter, is the complete Hepatitis B virus. It was described by Dane and is called Dane particle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. HBeAg: Incorrect, as HBeAg is a Hepatitis B envelope antigen associated with the virus's replication and infectivity but not known as the Australia antigen.

 

Option C. HBcAg: Incorrect, HBcAg or Hepatitis B core antigen is associated with the core of the virus but is not referred to as the Australia antigen.

 

Option D. HBV-DNA: Incorrect, this refers to the genetic material of the Hepatitis B virus itself and is not synonymous with the Australia antigen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

HBsAg, also known as the Australia antigen, plays a pivotal role in the diagnosis and monitoring of Hepatitis B infection. Its presence in the blood typically indicates an active Hepatitis B infection.

choices.text: Pain in both active and passive movements

questions.text: Non-articular bone pain is differentiated from articular bone pain by:(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pain in only active movements

 

ARTICULAR VS NON-ARTICULAR PAIN

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Non-articular pain occurs only during active movements. When both active and passive range of movements are painful, it is due to articular pain.

choices.text: Low TSH levels
Low free T4 levels
Low serum T3 levels
Radioactive iodine Uptake (RAIU) at 24 hours below normal

questions.text: A middle-aged woman who presented with tremors, palpitations, weight loss, and menstrual irregularities is diagnosed with Graves' disease. Which of the following statements would be correct with respect to her thyroid function test? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Low TSH levels
 

Grave’s disease in an autoimmune disease characterized by production of antibodies against the TSH-Receptor which stimulates the gland resulting in release of thyroid hormones (T3, T4) producing symptoms of thyrotoxicosis. Elevated T3, 4 produce reduction in TSH via negative feedback.

 

Other options:

 

Option B, C: Elevated levels of T3, T4 are seen in Grave’s disease.

 

Option D: Due to stimulation of the gland, there is Homogenous uptake on RAIU scan.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Graves' disease, low TSH levels are a key diagnostic marker reflecting the increased production and release of thyroid hormones T3 and T4, which exert negative feedback on the pituitary gland to reduce TSH secretion.

 

Reference - Harrison 21/Hyperthyroidism/Grave’s disease/Chap 384

questions.text: Identify the prominent nerve pointed in the given image?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Great auricular nerve

 

The thickened nerve marked with the arrow in the above image is the great auricular nerve.

 

 

Great auricular nerve:

 

  • The great auricular nerve is the cervical plexus's largest ascending branch, arising from the anterior rami of spinal nerves C2 and C3.
  • The nerve emerges just behind the sternocleidomastoid muscle's middle portion, curves around its posterior border, and emerges on the muscle's anterior surface.
  • The great auricular nerve perforates the deep cervical fascia and ascends along the external jugular vein, passing under the platysma muscle.
  • The great auricular nerve divides into terminal branches as it approaches the parotid gland.

 

Clinical considerations:

 

  • ﻿﻿Leprosy - Nerve thickening is present. The nerve is palpable over the upper part of the sternocleidomastoid muscle. (As seen in the above image)
  • ﻿﻿Frey's syndrome - An aberrant connection between the auriculotemporal nerve and great auricular nerve causes gustatory sweating.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lesser Occipital Nerve: The lesser occipital nerve is another branch of the cervical plexus, arising from the second cervical spinal nerve (C2). It provides sensory innervation to the skin over the posterior part of the scalp.

 

Option C. Facial Nerve: The facial nerve, also known as the seventh cranial nerve (CN VII), is a mixed nerve responsible for controlling the muscles of facial expression. It also carries taste sensation from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. It does not primarily provide sensory innervation to the skin.

 

Option D. Auriculotemporal Nerve: The auriculotemporal nerve is a branch of the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve (CN V3). It supplies sensory innervation to the external ear and the skin of the temple region.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The great auricular nerve is a branch of the cervical plexus, specifically originating from the second and third cervical spinal nerves (C2-C3). It provides sensory innervation to the skin over the parotid gland, the external ear, and the angle of the mandible.

choices.text: Both the treatments are equally effective
Neither of the treatments is effective
The new treatment is more effective than the usual treatment
The information given is not adequate to compare the efficacy of the treatments

questions.text: In a well-designed cancer study, comparable rates of remission were achieved for both a new treatment (33.2%) and the conventional treatment (32.2%). The corresponding p-value was recorded as 0.04. Which of the following statements is true regarding the study? [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) The new treatment is more effective than the usual treatment 

 

  • A p-value of 0.04 (< 0.05) indicates that the results are statistically significant and there is evidence to suggest that the new treatment is more effective than the usual treatment. 
  • Although the difference in remission rates is small, it is still statistically significant, which means that the new treatment may have some clinical benefits compared to the usual treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Both the treatments are equally effective: This statement is misleading because, although the remission rates are close, the statistical analysis (p-value < 0.05) indicates a significant difference, favoring the new treatment.

 

Option B. Neither of the treatments is effective: This option is incorrect as the statement about effectiveness cannot be deduced solely from the remission rates and p-value provided; effectiveness also depends on other factors such as comparison with control groups or historical data which are not mentioned here.

 

Option D. The information given is not adequate to compare the efficacy of the treatments: While more information about the study design and other factors could be beneficial, the p-value provided is adequate under standard scientific criteria to make a preliminary comparison regarding the efficacy of the treatments.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Even small differences in treatment outcomes can be statistically significant. A p-value of less than 0.05, as seen in this study, typically supports the conclusion that the new treatment offers a measurable improvement over the conventional treatment in terms of remission rates.

questions.text: Confusion assessment test is used in: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Delirium

 

The Confusion Assessment Method (often referred to as CAM) is a diagnostic tool specifically designed to identify delirium.

 

CAM is used primarily for the detection of delirium, especially in hospitalized or elderly patients. It evaluates features like acute onset and fluctuating course, inattention, disorganized thinking, and altered level of consciousness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dementia: While CAM can help differentiate delirium from dementia, it is not specifically designed for the diagnosis of dementia.

 

Option C. Schizophrenia: CAM is not used in the diagnosis or assessment of schizophrenia.

 

Option D. Depression: CAM is not used in the diagnosis or assessment of depression.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The Confusion Assessment Method (CAM) is a tool specifically developed to detect delirium. Bedside examinations such as mini mental status examination (MMSE) are used to provide a measure of cognitive impairment.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 701.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an OCD related disorder?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Temper tantrums

 

Obsessive-Compulsive and Related Disorders include conditions that share features with OCD, such as repetitive behaviors or obsessive thoughts.

 

Temper tantrums, on the other hand, are emotional outbursts seen typically in children and are not directly related to OCD or its spectrum disorders.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hair pulling disorder (Trichotillomania): Hair pulling disorder (Trichotillomania) is characterized by repetitive hair pulling resulting in hair loss.

 

Option C. Hoarding disorder: Hoarding disorder is characterized by persistent difficulty discarding possessions, leading to clutter.

 

Option D. Skin picking (Excoriation disorder): Skin picking (Excoriation disorder) involves recurrent skin picking resulting in skin lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Obsessive-compulsive or related disorders are classified as:

 

  • Obsessive-compulsive disorder
  • Body dysmorphic disorder
  • Hoarding disorder
  • Trichotillomania
  • Excoriation disorder

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 418-436.

choices.text: Sodium outflow in thick ascending limb
Water outflow in thin descending limb
Sodium outflow in thin ascending limb
Flow of tubular fluid from PCT and DCT

questions.text: All of the following are components responsible for the countercurrent mechanism in the kidney except? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Flow of tubular fluid from PCT and DCT

 

Explanation

 

PCT and DCT is not a component of the countercurrent mechanism.

 

Countercurrent system has two divisions:

 

  1. Countercurrent multiplier formed by loop of Henle & Medullary CD
  2. Countercurrent exchanger formed by vasa recta.

 

The major factors that contribute to the buildup of solute concentration into the renal medulla are as follows:

 

  1. Ascending limb of loop of Henle - thick portion (Active transport) and thin portion (Passive transport) of sodium ions and co-transport of potassium, chloride, and other ions into the medullary interstitium
  2. Descending limb of loop of Henle – Passive transport of water from the tubules to interstitium
  3. Inner medullary collecting ducts - facilitated diffusion of large amounts of urea into the medullary interstitium

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sodium outflow in thick ascending limb: Incorrect as exclusion because it is a key component of the countercurrent multiplier, actively transporting sodium out of the tubular fluid.

 

Option B. Water outflow in thin descending limb: Incorrect as exclusion because it contributes to the countercurrent mechanism by allowing water to passively leave the tubular fluid, increasing its concentration.

 

Option C. Sodium outflow in thin ascending limb: Incorrect as exclusion; although less active than the thick segment, it still participates in sodium transport.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The flow of tubular fluid from the PCT and DCT is not a component of the kidney's countercurrent mechanism, which primarily involves the loop of Henle and medullary collecting ducts in actively and passively managing solute and water concentrations to concentrate urine.

questions.text: Which of the following antihypertensive are not used in pregnancy? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Propranolol

 

Propranolol is a non-selective Beta blocker that is not used in Pregnancy. However, Labetalol is a third generation Beta blocker with additional vasodilatory property which can be used as an antihypertensive.

 

Other Options:

 

Antihypertensives Safe for Use in Pregnancy

 

Option A. Alpha methyldopa: This is considered safe for use during pregnancy and is often used as a first-line treatment for hypertension in pregnant women.

 

Option B. Hydralazine: This is also considered safe and is commonly used in managing severe hypertension and hypertensive emergencies during pregnancy.

 

Option D. Labetalol: This is a third-generation beta-blocker with additional vasodilatory properties and is considered safe and effective for use in pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Antihypertensive to be avoided in pregnancy:

 

  • ACE inhibitors, ARBS
  • Diuretics
  • Nonselective beta-blockers
  • Nitroprusside

choices.text: 12 hours
24 hours
6 hours

questions.text: What is the maximum duration for TRALI to occur after blood transfusion? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 6 hours

 

The maximum duration for TRALI (transfusion-related acute lung injury) to occur after blood transfusion is 6 hours.

 

TRALI is characterized as sudden onset respiratory failure that occurs during or shortly after a blood transfusion. The pathogenesis is based on a two-hit hypothesis:

 

  • Priming event - increased sequestration and sensitization of neutrophils in the lung microvasculature
  • Second knock - the factor (most commonly MHC class I antigens) present in the transfused blood product stimulates the primed neutrophils

 

Pathogenesis of transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI):

 

  1. Dysregulation of Inflammatory Process: This indicates an imbalance or dysregulation in the normal inflammatory response.
  2. Leukocyte Antigen (Ag) Recipient: Refers to the recipient's leukocytes, which play a role in the immune response.
  3. Blood AB Donor: Indicates the presence of antibodies (AB) in the donated blood.
  4. First Hit: Represents an initial insult or trigger such as trauma, sepsis, or neutrophil activation that can activate the immune system.
  5. Endothelial Permeability: Describes the increased permeability of endothelial cells lining blood vessels.
  6. Second Hit: Refers to a secondary insult, which in this case is the transfusion of blood components.
  7. Transfusion Blood Components: Represents the infusion of blood products, including lysophosphatidylcholine (Lyso PC).
  8. Endothelial Activation: Activation of endothelial cells leading to cytokine release, which is the release of signalling molecules involved in immune responses.
  9. Common Pathway: Illustrates that both the first hit and the second hit converge to activate a common pathway.
  10. Alveolar Capillary Pulmonary Damage: Indicates the injury and damage occurring in the alveolar-capillary membrane in the lungs.
  11. Acute Respiratory Failure: Refers to the development of sudden respiratory distress and failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

TRALI vs TACO: -

questions.text: What is basiliximab? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) IL-2 receptor antagonist

 

Basiliximab is a monoclonal antibody that specifically targets and binds with high affinity to the IL-2 receptor, also known as CD25, on the surface of activated T-cells. By antagonizing this receptor, basiliximab inhibits the proliferation of T-cells that are critical for the immune response, thereby helping to prevent transplant rejection. It is commonly used in combination with other immunosuppressive agents to prevent acute rejection in organ transplantation, particularly kidney transplants.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IL-1 receptor antagonist: IL-1 receptor antagonists, such as anakinra, target the IL-1 receptor and are used in conditions like rheumatoid arthritis. Basiliximab does not target the IL-1 receptor.

 

Option B. Anti-CD3 antibody: Anti-CD3 antibodies, such as muromonab-CD3, target the CD3 receptor on T-cells and are used for acute transplant rejection. Basiliximab, however, is not an anti-CD3 antibody.

 

Option D. TNF inhibitor: TNF inhibitors, such as infliximab and adalimumab, target tumor necrosis factor (TNF) and are used in autoimmune conditions like rheumatoid arthritis and Crohn's disease. Basiliximab does not inhibit TNF.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Basiliximab is an IL-2 receptor antagonist that binds to the CD25 receptor on activated T-cells, thereby preventing T-cell proliferation and helping to prevent transplant rejection reactions. It is specifically used in the context of organ transplantation to reduce the risk of acute rejection.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis based on the given image? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Unicornuate uterus

 

The given image shows the HSG of a Unicornuate uterus. The endometrial cavity forms a fusiform (banana type) shape, tapering at the apex and draining into a single fallopian tube. The uterus is generally shifted off the midline.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Uterus didelphys is a type of Müllerian duct anomaly where there is a complete duplication of uterine horns as well as duplication of the cervix, with no communication between them.

 

 

Option B. Bicornuate uterus is due to incomplete fusion of the mullerian ducts and is characterized by the presence of a cleft in the external contour of the uterine fundus.

 

 

Option C. Septate uterus is the result of partial or complete failure of resorption of the uterovaginal septum after fusion of the paramesonephric ducts.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Unicornuate uterus is identified on HSG by a fusiform shape and a single fallopian tube connection, often displaced from the midline, indicating unilateral Müllerian duct development.

questions.text: In a screening examination conducted on a population of 1000 individuals for diabetes mellitus (DM), 90 individuals tested positive. Subsequently, a gold standard test for DM was performed, identifying 100 positive cases. What is the calculated sensitivity? [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) 90/100

 

In given question, the following data are provided:

 

Total population = 1000

 

Total diseased people = 100 (identified by gold standard test)

 

Total number of diabetics identified initially = 90, thus

 

total positive identified by screening test =90

 

 

Therefore:

 

Sensitivity = TP/(TP+FN) =90/ (90+10) = 90/100 = 90%

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sensitivity is the proportion of true positive cases correctly identified by a screening test out of all actual positive cases identified by the gold standard test.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is the given X-ray finding seen? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Reflux esophagitis

 

The given image is a barium swallow X-ray showing a feline esophagus suggestive of eosinophilic esophagitis seen in asthma and GERD.

 

Other important barium swallow signs:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Esophageal atresia: This condition involves a discontinuity of the esophagus and is typically diagnosed in neonates.

 

Option B. Esophageal stenosis: Esophageal stenosis would show as a narrowing of the esophagus on an X-ray, which is not evident in the provided image.

 

Option D. Barrett's esophagus: Barrett's esophagus involves a change in the esophageal lining from squamous to columnar epithelium due to chronic acid exposure. While it may be associated with GERD, its specific changes are not visible on a barium swallow X-ray and are instead diagnosed through endoscopic biopsy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The appearance of a feline esophagus on a barium swallow X-ray is indicative of eosinophilic esophagitis and is often associated with conditions like asthma and GERD. This finding underscores the importance of considering inflammatory and allergic contributions in patients presenting with esophageal symptoms.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms produce urease? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Helicobacter pylori

 

Helicobacter pylori is well-known for its ability to produce urease, an enzyme that catalyzes the hydrolysis of urea into carbon dioxide and ammonia. This enzymatic activity is crucial for the survival of H. pylori in the acidic environment of the stomach. By producing ammonia, H. pylori can neutralize the acidity around it, creating a more hospitable environment for itself and contributing to its pathogenicity, which is associated with gastric ulcers and chronic gastritis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Salmonella: Incorrect, Salmonella does not produce urease and is known for causing foodborne illnesses primarily affecting the intestinal tract.

 

Option C. Escherichia coli: Incorrect, while some strains of E. coli can produce urease, it is not a characteristic feature, and they are primarily known for other virulence factors.

 

Option D. Shigella: Incorrect, Shigella does not produce urease and is known for causing dysentery or shigellosis through invasion and inflammation of the intestinal mucosa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Urease-producing organisms: (Mnemonic-PUNCH)

 

  • Proteus
  • asma urealyticum
  • Nocardia
  • Cryptococcus, Corynebacterium urealyticum
  •  H. pylori

questions.text: What immunization coverage percentage is required by the WHO for the eradication of measles? [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) 96% 

 

  • The World Health Organization (WHO) stipulates that to achieve the complete elimination of measles, an immunization coverage of at least 96% among children under the age of 1 is necessary. 
  • This high percentage is critical because measles is highly contagious. Such a high coverage rate ensures herd immunity, significantly reducing the chances of measles transmission and protecting those who are not immune.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To eradicate measles, the WHO recommends an immunization coverage of 96% among children under the age of 1, emphasizing the need for near-universal coverage to achieve herd immunity and effectively control the disease.

questions.text: The flipped LDH ratio implies:(NEET  PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) LDH1 > LDH 2

 

Normally LDH 2 is predominant in the blood and LDH 1 is predominant in the heart. During a myocardial infarction, due to damage to the cardiac tissue, LDH 1 is released into the bloodstream resulting in a high LDH1: LDH2 ratio called flipped LDH ratio (LDH1 > LDH2).

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Types of LDH -

 

  • LDH-1: Heart
  • LDH-2: Blood
  • LDH-3: Brain, kidney, lungs, spleen, pancreas
  • LDH-4: Liver and skeletal muscle
  • LDH-5: Liver and skeletal muscle

questions.text: A 68-year-old male patient, who is a known case of diabetes mellitus since the past 25 years, came for a health checkup. He was found to have uncontrolled blood sugar levels and third cranial nerve palsy. Which is the most common feature of third nerve palsy seen in such a case?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Ptosis

 

  • Diabetic oculomotor nerve palsy is caused by hyperglycemia-induced damage to nerve cells and neuronal ischemic change.
  • The arrangement of the fibers in the third cranial nerve is such that the fibers controlling the pupillary reflex are superficial and often spared from diabetic ischemia-induced injury.
  • Pupillary dysfunction is not commonly present in diabetic oculomotor nerve palsy.
  • The levator palpebrae superiors and most of the oculomotor muscles, except for the lateral rectus and superior oblique, are damaged in diabetic oculomotor nerve palsy.
  • Diabetic oculomotor nerve palsy typically presents with ptosis and diplopia.

 

APPLIED ANATOMY OF PUPILLOMOTOR NERVE FIBRES

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Proptosis: Protrusion of the eye, not typically associated with diabetic oculomotor nerve palsy.

 

Option B. Pseudoptosis: False appearance of ptosis, not related to actual muscle dysfunction.

 

Option D. Pupillary dysfunction: Although part of the oculomotor nerve's function, it is usually spared in diabetic oculomotor nerve palsy due to the peripheral location of the pupillary fibers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ptosis (drooping of the upper eyelid) is the most common feature of third nerve palsy seen in diabetic patients, due to the selective ischemic damage to the central fibers of the oculomotor nerve, sparing the peripheral pupillary fibers.

choices.text: Ipsilateral oculomotor nerve palsy
Ipsilateral paralysis of lower face

questions.text: Which among the following is wrong regarding Weber's syndrome? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Ipsilateral paralysis of lower face

 

LMN Facial palsy occurs in pontine/infra-pontine syndromes.

 

WEBER'S SYNDROME

 

Infarction - Ipsilateral subthalamus and medial thalamus injury with ipsilateral cerebral peduncle and mid- brain lesions.

 

Involvement:

 

  • Third nerve palsy with contralateral hemiplegia (localized to the cerebral peduncle).
  • Subthalamic nucleus - Contralateral hemiballismus
  • Occlusion of the artery of Percheron - Paresis of upward gaze and drowsiness
  • If bilateral proximal PCA occlusion - coma, unreactive pupils, bilateral pyramidal signs, and decerebrate rigidity.

 

Note: A Third nerve palsy with contralateral ataxia - Claude's syndrome. The ataxia indicates involvement of the red nucleus or dentato-rubro-thalamic tract.

 

  • Weber, claude, benedict are medial brainstem syndromes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Contralateral hemiplegia: Correct for Weber's syndrome, as it involves the cerebral peduncle, affecting motor pathways that result in weakness on the opposite side of the body.

 

Option B. Ipsilateral oculomotor nerve palsy: Also correct, reflecting the typical involvement of the third cranial nerve, which controls eye movements, eyelid opening, pupil constriction, and most of the eye's focusing muscles.

 

Option C. Contralateral Parkinsonism: While not classically described as a symptom of Weber’s syndrome, it could theoretically relate to potential involvement of nearby structures influencing motor function. However, it is less specific and not as classic a presentation as contralateral hemiplegia and ipsilateral oculomotor nerve palsy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Weber’s syndrome involves ipsilateral oculomotor nerve palsy and contralateral hemiplegia due to midbrain lesions, and does not typically include ipsilateral facial paralysis, which is associated with pontine lesions.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of ventriculomegaly in newborns? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Aqueductal stenosis

 

Aqueductal stenosis is the most common cause of ventriculomegaly (enlargement of ventricles of the brain) in newborns. It is a congenital condition where there is narrowing or obstruction of the cerebral aqueduct, a small channel that connects the third and fourth ventricles in the brain. This obstruction can result in an enlargement of the ventricles, which can lead to hydrocephalus (accumulation of cerebrospinal fluid in the brain). Arnold-Chiari malformation, Dandy-Walker syndrome, and arachnoid villi malformation are other conditions that can cause ventriculomegaly, but they are less common causes than aqueductal stenosis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Arnold chiari malformation: Arnold chiari malformation will have downward displacement of cerebellum and brainstem. This is not the most commonest cause of ventriculomegaly

 

Option B. Dandy walker malformation: Dandy walker malformation will have cerebellar hypoplasia with hydrocephalus.

 

Option C. Arachnoid villi malformation: Arachnoid villi malformation is not the most commonest cause

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aqueductal stenosis is the leading cause of ventriculomegaly in newborns due to the narrowing or obstruction of the cerebral aqueduct, leading to hydrocephalus.

questions.text: Which of the following is responsible for the negative charge in fibrinopeptide A? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Aspartate and Glutamate

 

Aspartate and glutamate are both acidic amino acids that contain a carboxylic acid group in their side chains. This carboxylic acid group can ionize in solution to release a hydrogen ion, resulting in a negative charge. The negative charges on the aspartate and glutamate residues in fibrinopeptide A contribute to the overall negative charge of the peptide.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Histidine and lysine are positively charged amino acids that can form ionic bonds with negatively charged molecules, but they do not contribute to the negative charge of the peptide.

 

Options A and D Valine and serine are non-polar and uncharged amino acids that do not contribute to the negative charge of the peptide.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fibrinopeptide A is a peptide that is cleaved from fibrinogen during blood clotting to form fibrin. Fibrin is a key component of blood clots and is responsible for stopping bleeding from injured blood vessels. Fibrinopeptide A contains a negative charge due to the presence of aspartate and glutamate residues.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis for a 13-year-old boy with a history of chronic and recurrent itchy flexural lesions, considering his family history of asthma?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Atopic dermatitis

 

The image displays scratch marks and excoriations caused by pruritic lesions at a flexural site. The patient has a personal history of chronic and recurrent course, and there is also a family history of atopy, specifically asthma. These findings suggest a diagnosis of atopic dermatitis (AD) or atopic eczema (AE).

 

Atopic dermatitis (AD):

 

  • It is a chronic inflammatory condition that tends to persist or exhibit chronic relapses.
  • In infants, the first site of involvement is often the face.
  • Flexural distribution is observed in both the childhood and adult phases of the condition, while in the infantile phase, extensor distribution is more typical.

 

Atopic eczema can be divided into 3 phases:

 

  1. Infantile
  2. Childhood
  3. Adult

 

 

Atopic eczema infantile variant with face affected:

 

 

  • Atopic dermatitis typically presents with erythematous papules or papulovesicular lesions, often appearing in early childhood.
  • As the condition progresses, the lesions may evolve into excoriated and lichenified areas. Atopic dermatitis is commonly associated with secondary infections and skin dryness.
  • In the diagnosis of atopic dermatitis, the UK refinement of the Hanifin & Rajka criteria is employed.

 

UK refinement of Hanifin & Rajka’s diagnostic criteria of atopic dermatitis (Eczema).

 

  • An itchy skin condition (or parental report of scratching or rubbing in a child)
  • Plus, three or more of the following
    1. Onset below age 2 years (not used if child is under 4 years)
    2. History of skin crease involvement (including cheeks in children under 10 years)
    3. History of a generally dry skin
    4. Personal history of other atopic disease (or history of any atopic disease in a first degree relative in children under 4 years)
    5. Visible flexural dermatitis (or dermatitis of cheeks/ forehead and outer limbs in children under 4 years)

 

Clinical features of AD include:

 

  • Dennie-morgan fold under lower eyelid
  • Allergic shiners – periorbital pigmentation
  • Allergic salute – horizontal groove on dorsum of nasal bridge

 

Fig: Dennie-morgan fold

 

Complications of AD:

  • Staphylococcus aureus is the most common organism to cause secondary infections in the lesions of atopic dermatitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Seborrheic dermatitis:

 

  • This is a chronic condition that primarily affects sebum-rich areas of the body such as the scalp, face, and central chest.
  • It's characterized by yellowish, greasy scales and underlying erythema as shown in the image below.
