  • While it can be itchy, its distribution and features are different from the description given.
  • There is no direct association between seborrheic dermatitis and a family history of asthma.

 

Option C. Allergic contact dermatitis:

 

  • This results from direct skin contact with allergens. It's an immunological response to a substance the individual has become sensitized to.
  • The lesions would be more correlated with contact to specific allergens, and it's not typically chronic or recurrent unless there is repeated exposure to the same allergen.
  • The distribution would be more in line with areas that contacted the allergen, rather than the typical flexural pattern described.

 

Option D. Erysipelas:

 

  • Erysipelas is an acute bacterial skin infection, typically caused by Group A Streptococcus.
  • It presents as a well-demarcated, raised, erythematous, and tender skin lesion, often accompanied by systemic symptoms like fever.
  • This condition is acute, not chronic or recurrent as described in the scenario.
  • There's no association with a family history of asthma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Identify atopic dermatitis as a chronic, pruritic inflammatory skin disease commonly associated with flexural distribution of eczematous lesions and a family history of atopic conditions, such as asthma.

 

 

Reference:

Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition volume 2 Chapter 41 page no 41.1, 41.2, 41.13-19

Rooks’ textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition volume 3 Chapter 149 page no 149.21

Online resources:

https://www.jaad.org/article/S0190-9622(13)01095-5/fulltext

questions.text: Name the investigation shown in the given image?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Conventional HSG

 

Hysterosalpingography

 

  • Hysterosalpingography is the fluoroscopic examination commonly used in the investigations of infertility to assess uterine morphology and tubal patency.
  • The best time to investigate is during the 6th to 10th day of menstrual cycle (not to be done during menstruation; risk of damage to undiagnosed pregnancy after 10th day)
  • A radiopaque dye is injected through the Leech-Wilkinson or Rubin's cannula, or Foley's catheter into the uterine cavity under direct vision with fluoroscopic screen.
  • If the tubes are patent, the medium is usually adequate to exit through the abdominal ostia and smear the adjacent bowel.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MR HSG: Involves the use of magnetic resonance imaging to view the uterine cavity and fallopian tubes, not compatible with the use of traditional radiopaque dyes and does not involve real-time fluoroscopy.

 

Option B. CT HSG: Utilizes computed tomography, which is less common and not shown in the image due to the distinct fluoroscopic appearance of conventional HSG.

 

Option D. USG HSG: Ultrasound HSG, also known as sonohysterography, uses ultrasound technology to evaluate the uterus and fallopian tubes, which would not display the classic radiopaque dye pattern seen in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Conventional HSG is a critical diagnostic tool in the assessment of uterine structure and tubal patency, using a radiopaque dye visualized with fluoroscopy, particularly useful in the workup of infertility.

choices.text: Serum ceruloplasmin levels
Serum copper levels

questions.text: A child presents with hepatitis and progressive neurological degeneration. A picture of his eye has been provided below. Among the following options, what would be the initial step regarding the investigations done for this child's diagnosis? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Serum ceruloplasmin levels

 

The image of the eye, showing a possible Kayser-Fleischer ring, along with symptoms of hepatitis and progressive neurological degeneration, strongly suggests Wilson disease. Wilson disease is a genetic disorder affecting copper metabolism. The initial screening test in suspected cases is the measurement of serum ceruloplasmin levels, as ceruloplasmin is the primary copper-carrying protein in the blood, and levels are typically reduced in Wilson disease.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Serum copper levels: This test is used to further support the diagnosis after abnormalities in ceruloplasmin levels are noted. Total serum copper is typically low in Wilson disease, but free copper is elevated due to the low ceruloplasmin levels.

 

Option C. Enzyme assay: Not relevant for Wilson disease, which involves a defect in copper transport rather than an enzyme deficiency.

 

Option D. Karyotyping: Also not relevant, as Wilson disease is related to mutations in the ATP7B gene, not chromosomal abnormalities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a child presenting with hepatitis and neurological symptoms, the presence of a Kayser-Fleischer ring strongly suggests Wilson disease. The first diagnostic step is to measure serum ceruloplasmin levels.

questions.text: What is the observational unit in ecological investigations? [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Population

 

  • In ecological studies, the unit of observation is the population or community, which refers to a group of individuals or entities living in the same geographic area or sharing a common characteristic.
  • Ecological studies are observational studies that investigate the relationship between exposure and disease at a population level rather than an individual level.
  • Therefore, the data collected and analyzed in ecological studies are not at the individual level, but at the group or population level.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: The best time to identify the type of twin pregnancy on ultrasound is? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 11-14 weeks

 

Explanation:

 

The optimal time for determining the type of twin pregnancy through ultrasound is between 11+0 to 13+6 weeks, when the crown-rump length (CRL) is between 45 to 84 mm. This period allows for the most accurate dating and assessment of chorionicity, which is crucial for the management and outcome of twin pregnancies.

 

  • Chorionicity: The type of twin pregnancy (dichorionic or monochorionic) is determined by examining the thickness of the membrane at the site of insertion.
    • Lambda (λ) sign: Indicates a dichorionic diamniotic pregnancy.
    • Inverted T sign: Indicates a monochorionic diamniotic pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The best time to determine the type of twin pregnancy on ultrasound is between 11 and 14 weeks of gestation.

 

 

Ref: Page no 2190, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Keratinized epithelium, submucosa, minor salivary glands
Keratinized epithelium, absent submucosa, no salivary glands
Non-keratinized epithelium, submucosa, minor salivary glands
Non-keratinized epithelium, absent submucosa, minor salivary glands

questions.text: During a histological examination of the oral cavity, which combination of features is typically seen in the hard palate mucosa? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Keratinized epithelium, submucosa, minor salivary glands

 

Hard palate is composed of a dense layer of connective tissue covered by a specialized oral mucosa. It is composed of keratinized epithelium, a submucosal layer for support, and contains minor salivary glands. These structures contribute to the function of the hard palate in speech, mastication (chewing), and the initial digestion of food in the oral cavity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The hard palate is composed of keratinized epithelium to withstand mechanical stress, a submucosa that provides structural support, and contains minor salivary glands, which are essential for the lubrication and initial digestion of food. This structural composition is crucial for its function in the oral cavity.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the clinic with a long-standing history of recurrent abdominal pain, nausea, and steatorrhea. The patient reports a significant history of alcohol abuse, and diagnostic imaging reveals signs of chronic pancreatitis. What is the most common cause of chronic pancreatitis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Alcohol

 

Chronic alcohol consumption is the leading cause of chronic pancreatitis. Excessive alcohol intake can lead to repeated episodes of acute pancreatitis, eventually resulting in chronic inflammation, fibrosis, and loss of pancreatic function. Alcohol-induced chronic pancreatitis often presents with pain, malabsorption (leading to steatorrhea), and diabetes mellitus due to the destruction of insulin-producing cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gallstones: When they travel out of the gallbladder into the bile ducts, they can block the pancreatic duct, leading to inflammation of the pancreas, termed acute pancreatitis. While gallstones are a common cause of acute pancreatitis, they are not the predominant cause of chronic pancreatitis.

 

Option C. Autoimmune: Autoimmune pancreatitis (AIP) is a type of chronic pancreatitis caused by an autoimmune reaction against the pancreatic tissue. It can be part of the spectrum of IgG4-related disease. The pancreas may become enlarged and look like a tumor on imaging studies. AIP might present with jaundice, weight loss, and the aforementioned pancreatic enlargement. Treatment usually involves corticosteroids to suppress the immune response.

 

Option D. Drugs: Some drugs are known to cause pancreatitis. While the incidence is generally low, drug-induced pancreatitis can turn chronic if the offending medication isn't identified and discontinued. Common culprits include diuretics like furosemide and thiazides, certain antiretroviral drugs, and some antiepileptics like valproic acid, among others.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic alcohol consumption is the most common cause of chronic pancreatitis, leading to repeated inflammation, fibrosis, and loss of pancreatic function over time.

choices.text: Painless hematuria
Painful hematuria

questions.text: The most consistent and persistent feature of bladder carcinoma is: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Painless hematuria

 

Bladder tumors classically produce painless hematuria. This is their dominant and sometimes only clinical manifestation. Frequency, urgency, and dysuria occasionally accompany the hematuria.

 

Bladder tumors produce a wide range of clinical features including:

 

  • Painless hematuria - classical feature and may be the only clinical manifestation
  • Irritative urinary symptoms (frequency, urgency, dysuria) - diffuse tumors or tumors at the bladder neck
  • Pyelonephritis or hydronephrosis - when the ureteral orifice is involved
  • Obstructive symptoms, palpable suprapubic mass, or lower extremity edema - late presentation with a large tumor mass
  • Weight loss and/or localized bone pain - metastatic disease

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Painful hematuria: This symptom, while possible, is less common and typically associated with other urological conditions.

 

Option C. Dysuria: Often occurs with more diffuse tumors or when the tumor is located at the bladder neck but is not as consistently observed as hematuria.

 

Option D. Suprapubic mass: Typically, a sign of advanced disease and not a consistent initial symptom.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Painless hematuria is the classical and most persistent feature of bladder carcinoma, often being the initial and sometimes the only symptom observed.

choices.text: It is a thickening of the lumbar fascia
It lies anterior to the Poupart's ligament
It inserts into the pubic tubercle in front of the conjoint tendon
Its fibers fan out with fascia illaca laterally

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the iliopubic tract?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Its fibers fan out with fascia illaca laterally

 

  • Laterally, the fibres of the iliopubic tract fan out with fascia iliaca.
  • The iliopubic tract is a thickening of the transversalis fascia immediately posterior to the inguinal (Poupart's) ligament.
  • It runs superolaterally from the anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS) and arches across the front of the femoral sheath.

 

 

The muscle has a broad attachment medially into the pubic tubercle and pectineal line, situated behind the conjoint tendon. On the lateral side, its fibers spread out within the fascia transversalis and fascia iliac without being attached to the iliac spines.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is a thickening of the lumbar fascia: This statement is incorrect. The iliopubic tract is not a thickening of the lumbar fascia. Instead, it is a thickened band of the iliopectineal fascia, which is an extension of the transversalis fascia. It runs parallel and posterior to the inguinal ligament (Poupart's ligament).

 

Option B. It lies anterior to the Poupart's ligament: This statement is incorrect. The iliopubic tract runs parallel to and posterior to the inguinal ligament (also known as Poupart's ligament). It forms the inferior border of the internal inguinal ring and provides a posterior boundary for the femoral canal.

 

Option C. It inserts into the pubic tubercle in front of the conjoint tendon: This statement is not accurate. The iliopubic tract doesn't insert into the pubic tubercle. Instead, it runs laterally from the pubic tubercle, posterior to the inguinal ligament, and continues as the iliopectineal arch or fascia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

As the iliopubic tract moves laterally from the pubic tubercle, its fibers fan out and blend with the fascia of the iliacus muscle (often referred to as the iliac fascia or fascia iliaca). This provides a connection between the structures of the anterior abdominal wall and the pelvic sidewall.

questions.text: Warthin Finkeldey cells are seen in: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rubeola

 

Warthin-Finkeldey cells are a type of giant multinucleated cells that are seen in cases of measles (rubeola). Measles is a highly contagious viral infection caused by the measles virus. The virus primarily affects the respiratory system and spreads through respiratory droplets or direct contact with secretions from an infected person.

 

Warthin-Finkeldey cells are thought to be formed due to the interaction of the measles virus with lymphoid tissue, leading to the proliferation of lymphoid cells and formation of giant cells. These cells are characterized by a central mass of nuclei surrounded by a clear halo.

 

 

Warthin-Finkeldey cells are not seen in rubella, rabies, or typhoid. Rubella is a viral infection that causes a mild rash and fever. Rabies is a viral infection that affects the nervous system and is usually transmitted through the bite of an infected animal. Typhoid fever is a bacterial infection caused by Salmonella typhi and is typically transmitted through contaminated food or water.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rubella: Congenital rubella syndrome infection will have a triad of “CCD “congenital heart disease (PDA), cataract & deafness.

 

Option C. Rabies: For rabies there should be a history of hydrophobia with history of dog bite.

 

Option D. Typhoid: Typhoid fever will have rose like spots on trunk on 7th day of fever, relative bradychardia, step ladder pattern of fever.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Warthin-Finkeldey cells are pathognomonic giant multinucleated cells associated with measles (rubeola) infection and are indicative of viral interaction with lymphoid tissue, aiding in the diagnosis of this highly contagious respiratory illness.

questions.text: A 55-year-old lady comes with abnormal uterine bleeding. A hysterectomy was performed, and the following specimen was retrieved. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Leiomyoma

 

Explanation:

 

 

  • The given image shows a large leiomyoma. (Submucosal, i.e., the location of the fibroid is in the endometrial cavity)
  • Patients usually present with heavy menstrual bleeding.
  • According to their location, fibroids are classified according to FIGO classification.
  • Most common HPE features are: Whorled appearance in cross section, well circumscribed firm lesion.  ﻿
  • The most common degeneration associated with myomas is cystic degeneration.
  • Red degeneration is common during pregnancy.

 

 

FIGO Classification of Fibroids

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Endometrial carcinoma: This will show an irregular growth In the endometrial cavity as shown in the image

 

 

Option C. Endometrial polyp: This will appear as a soft fleshy projection in the endometrial cavity as shown in the image

 

 

Option D. Adenomyosis: This usually will be a globular enlargement of the uterus with myometrial thickening as shown below

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Leiomyomas, or fibroids, are the most common benign tumors of the uterus, often presenting with heavy menstrual bleeding. They are characterized by a whorled appearance in cross section and a well-circumscribed, firm lesion.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient has hypokalemia, hypertension and metabolic alkalosis. What is the most likely etiology? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Liddle’s Syndrome

 

Liddle's syndrome is a genetic disorder characterized by early-onset hypertension, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis due to a gain-of-function mutation in the epithelial sodium channel (ENaC). This mutation leads to increased sodium reabsorption in the distal nephron, which indirectly causes potassium loss and elevated blood pressure. The syndrome mimics hyperaldosteronism but occurs in the absence of elevated aldosterone levels.

 

 

Hypokalemia + HTN causes:

 

Aldosterone Activation

 

  • Liddle syndrome (ENaC channel Gain of function mutation)
  • Apparent Mineralocorticoid Excess (AME) (11Beta-HSD loss of function)
    • ↓11-βHSD→↑Cortisol →↑Stimulation of MR receptor → HTN + Hypokalemia + alkalosis
  • Geller Syndrome (Mineralocorticoid mutation responding to progesterone): Presents in pregnancy. Rx with specific drug like Finerenone.
  • Glucocorticoid remediable Hyperaldosteronism (GRA): Chimeric gene b/w CYP11B1, B2 causing ACTH driven hyperaldosteronism.
  • Primary Hyperaldosteronism

 

Other options:

 

Option A : Bartter syndrome mimics loop diuretics which occur due to loss of function of Na+-K+-2Cl- transporter at the Loop of Henle. Often patient has NORMOTENSION.

 

Option C : Gitelman syndrome mimics thiazide diuretic occurring due to loss of function mutation of Na+-Cl- transporter in DCT. Both Bartter and Gitelman syndrome are normotensive

 

Option D : Gordon syndrome is opposite of Gitelman syndrome characterized by Gain of function mutation to Na+-Cl- channel which occurs either due to GOF of WNT1 pathway (OR) LOF of WNT 4 pathway, leads to inhibition of ROMK channel causing HYPERKALEMIA.

 

Note: Gordon = HTN + Hyperkalemia

 

Educational Objective:

 

Liddle's syndrome is characterized by hypertension, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis due to increased activity of sodium channels in the distal nephron, not due to increased aldosterone, distinguishing it from other similar electrolyte disorders.

 

Reference - Harrison 21E/ Physiology of Kidney/Chap 309 - Table 309-1

questions.text: What is the latest online software introduced by the government under the national tuberculosis elimination program (NTEP) to monitor patients with tuberculosis? [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) NIKSHAY

 

  • NIKSHAY is the latest online software introduced by the Indian government under the National Tuberculosis Elimination Program (NTEP) to monitor and manage patients with tuberculosis. This software facilitates the tracking of TB patients from diagnosis through treatment, ensuring that all cases are adequately monitored to achieve the goal of TB elimination.
  • NIKSHAY (Nikshay) aims to improve the surveillance, monitoring, and treatment of TB patients by providing a centralized platform for data collection and management. It enables health workers to record details of TB cases, track patient progress, and ensure that treatment protocols are followed, which is crucial for the effective management of TB.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. NISCHAY:   This refers to a pregnancy test kit and is unrelated to the monitoring of TB patients.

 

Option C. E-DOTS:  Electronic Directly Observed Therapy (eDOT) aka Virtual Directly Observed Therapy, is an approach for treating TB where healthcare providers observe patients taking their medication through real-time or prerecorded video.

 

Option D. NIKUSTH:  This software is used for monitoring leprosy patients, not tuberculosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

NIKSHAY - Monitoring TB patients.

 

NIKUSTH - Monitoring leprosy patients.

                                          

NISCHAY - Pregnancy test kit.

 

E-DOTS - Virtual Directly Observed Therapy DOT.

questions.text: What is the recommended dietary allowance for iodine dosage among lactating women in India? [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) 280 µg/day

 

As per the 2020 guidelines from the National Institute of Nutrition (NIN), the suggested dietary intake of iodine for lactating women in India is 280 micrograms per day.

 

NIN guidelines on recommended dietary allowance of Iodine -

 

 

Educational Objective:  

 

India had adopted WHO guideline of Iodine requirement 150 mcg per day in Adults, 250 mcg per day in Pregnancy and 280 mcg per day in Lactation

choices.text: Start ART immediately and continue till 6 weeks after delivery
Start ART after 1st trimester and continue life-long
Start ART immediately and continue life-long
Start ART after 1st trimester and continue till 6 weeks after delivery

questions.text: A woman is diagnosed to be positive for HIV in her first trimester. What is the most appropriate management? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Start ART immediately and continue life long

 

Explanation:

 

The National AIDS Control Organisation (NACO) recommends that all pregnant women with HIV should start antiretroviral therapy (ART) immediately, regardless of the stage of their disease or their CD4 count. This approach is aimed at reducing the viral load as quickly as possible, thereby decreasing the risk of mother-to-child transmission of HIV. ART should be continued lifelong to ensure ongoing viral suppression and the health of the mother.

 

Management of HIV-positive pregnancy includes:

 

  1. Antenatal care:
    • Testing for other sexually transmitted diseases (STDs), CMV, toxoplasmosis, tuberculosis, fungal, and other opportunistic infections.
    • Partner/husband should also be tested.
    • To prevent pneumocystis pneumonia, start co-trimoxazole if CD4 count is ≤ 250 cells/mm³ and continue through pregnancy, delivery, and breastfeeding (dose: double strength tablet, 1 tablet daily).
    • Assess immunization status and update as needed.
    • Counseling on the impact of HIV on pregnancy and factors influencing the progression of the disease and risk of perinatal transmission.
    • CD4 count testing in each trimester.
    • Monitor HIV RNA levels monthly after changing/initiating therapy.
    • CBC, LFT, and KFT in each trimester.
  2. Anti-retroviral therapy for all:
    • As per NACO: Start ART at diagnosis (regardless of CD4 count); continue lifelong.
    • Initiate lifelong ART in all pregnant women with confirmed HIV infection regardless of WHO clinical stage or CD4 cell count.
    • TDF + 3TC + EFV is recommended as first-line ART in pregnant and breastfeeding women (including pregnant women in the first trimester of pregnancy).
    • Pregnant women detected to be HIV-positive for the first time in labor should be initiated on ART (TDF + 3TC + EFV) immediately.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Start ART immediately upon diagnosis of HIV in pregnancy and continue lifelong to reduce the risk of mother-to-child transmission and maintain the health of the mother.

questions.text: Cryoglobulinemia is associated with? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Hepatitis C

 

Cryoglobulinemia, a condition characterized by the presence of abnormal proteins in the blood that precipitate at cold temperatures, is most commonly associated with Hepatitis C infection. This association is due to the immune response to the virus, which can lead to the production of these abnormal proteins. Hepatitis C-related cryoglobulinemia can result in a variety of symptoms, including rash, joint pain, and kidney problems.

 

Other causes:

 

  • Infection: Hep B, C, HIV
  • Autoimmune Disease: Sjogren, SLE
  • Malignancy: MGUS, Myeloma, CLL

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ovarian cancer: There is no established link between ovarian cancer and cryoglobulinemia. While malignancies can be associated with cryoglobulinemia, ovarian cancer is not typically among them.

 

Option C. Diabetes: Diabetes is not associated with cryoglobulinemia. While diabetes can cause a wide range of vascular and immunological issues, it does not directly cause the production of cryoglobulins.

 

Option D. Lymphoma: While certain hematologic malignancies like multiple myeloma and chronic lymphocytic leukemia can be associated with cryoglobulinemia, lymphoma is not as commonly linked compared to Hepatitis C.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Most common cause a/w Cryoglobulinemia is hepatitis C

choices.text: Skin, Subcutaneous tissue, Superficial fascia and Deep fascia
Skin, Subcutaneous tissue, Superficial fascia, Deep fascia and a few muscular fibers

questions.text: Identify the correct order of layers incised while performing a fasciotomy for compartment syndrome? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Skin, Subcutaneous tissue, Superficial fascia and Deep fascia

 

The incision for a fasciotomy involves the skin, subcutaneous tissue, superficial fascia, and deep fascia.

 

  • Deep fascia is a dense connective tissue layer that surrounds muscles, bones, and neurovascular structures. It creates the compartments in limbs, and in compartment syndrome, it is this fascial layer that is primarily responsible for the elevated pressures.
  • For a fasciotomy, the incision goes through the skin, subcutaneous tissue, superficial fascia, and, crucially, the deep fascia. This releases the increased pressure in the muscle compartment and restores blood flow.
  • The procedure is best carried out via longitudinal incisions of skin, subcutaneous fat, and superficial and deep fascia.
  • The lower limb can be decompressed via two incisions, each being lateral to the subcutaneous border of the tibia.
  • This gives access to the two posterior compartments and to the peroneal and anterior compartments of the leg.

 

 

Educational Objective:


During a fasciotomy for compartment syndrome, the incision must pass through the skin, subcutaneous tissue, superficial fascia, and deep fascia to adequately decompress the affected muscle compartments.

questions.text: What is the site of action of amphotericin B in fungi? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cell membrane

 

Amphotericin B is an antifungal drug that acts by sequestering ergosterol in the cell membrane, it leads to formation of pores in the cell membrane that leads to leakage of cytosolic contents out of the cell and eventually death of the fungus.. It is the drug of choice in systemic fungal infections , mucormycosis , cryptococcal meningitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nucleic acid: Amphotericin B does not target nucleic acids. Antifungal drugs that affect nucleic acid synthesis include flucytosine.

 

Option B. Ribosome: Amphotericin B does not target ribosomes. Antifungal drugs that interfere with protein synthesis at the ribosomal level are not commonly used.

 

Option D. Cytoplasm: Amphotericin B acts at the cell membrane, not directly within the cytoplasm. The disruption of the cell membrane causes the loss of cytoplasmic contents.

 

Additional Information

 

  • Mechanism of Action: By binding to ergosterol and forming pores, amphotericin B disrupts the integrity of the fungal cell membrane, leading to cell death.
  • Uses: Amphotericin B is the drug of choice for treating systemic fungal infections, mucormycosis, and cryptococcal meningitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amphotericin B targets the cell membrane of fungi by binding to ergosterol, forming pores that lead to leakage of cytoplasmic contents and fungal cell death. It is highly effective in treating severe systemic fungal infections.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman was involved in a car accident two months ago, and she now complains of screaming and waking up in the middle of the night after having nightmares about the same incident over and over. Which of the following conditions does she have? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Post traumatic stress disorder

 

This woman's presentation of recurrent nightmares about a traumatic event (the car accident) that happened two months ago suggests Post traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). PTSD can develop after a traumatic event and involves symptoms such as re-experiencing the trauma (e.g., flashbacks, nightmares), avoidance of reminders of the trauma, negative alterations in mood and cognition, and increased arousal (e.g., irritability, difficulty sleeping).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute stress reaction: Acute stress reaction typically occurs immediately after a traumatic event and lasts for a few days to a few weeks.

 

Option B. Adjustment disorder: Adjustment disorder develops in response to a stressor and is characterized by emotional and behavioral symptoms, rather than the nightmares. It arises within three months of the stressor.

 

Option C. Mania: Mania is characterized by elevated mood, increased energy, and decreased need for sleep, among other symptoms, and isn't directly related to a traumatic event.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PTSD manifests after experiencing or witnessing significant traumatic event, with symptoms like flashbacks, nightmares,hypervigilance, exaggerated startle response,  severe anxiety centered on the event and avoidance of the situations that remind of the trauma. The symptoms must be present for at least one month. It is more common in females and young adults. Hippocampus and amygdala are implicated in the etiology of PTSD. Treatment includes trauma-focussed CBT (treatment of choice), SSRIs (Drug of choice), and eye movements desensitization and reprocessing.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 439-441.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is associated with QT prolongation? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Quinidine

 

Quinidine is a Class Ia anti arrhythmic drug that acts by blocking Na+ channels as well as K+ channels. It can lead to prolonged QT interval and Torsades de pointes. Flecainide, Encainide and Propafenone are other drugs that belong to Class Ic antiarrhythmics and can also precipitate Torsades de pointes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lignocaine: Lignocaine (lidocaine) is a Class Ib antiarrhythmic drug that primarily blocks sodium channels. It does not significantly affect the QT interval and is not associated with QT prolongation.

 

Option C. Magnesium sulfate: Magnesium sulfate is used to treat Torsades de Pointes and other arrhythmias but does not cause QT prolongation. In fact, it is often administered to help stabilize the cardiac electrical activity in cases of prolonged QT interval.

 

Option D. All of the above: This option is incorrect because neither lignocaine nor magnesium sulfate is associated with QT prolongation. Only quinidine is known to cause QT prolongation among the listed drugs.

 

Additional Information

 

  • Class Ia Antiarrhythmics: These drugs, including quinidine, procainamide, and disopyramide, are known to prolong the QT interval by blocking both Na+ and K+ channels.
  • Class Ic Antiarrhythmics: Drugs like flecainide, encainide, and propafenone can also precipitate Torsades de Pointes, although their primary action is on Na+ channels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Quinidine, a Class Ia antiarrhythmic drug, is associated with QT prolongation and can lead to Torsades de Pointes due to its action on both sodium and potassium channels.

questions.text: Which of the following is an X-linked disorder? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Color blindness

 

Among the options given, color blindness is an X-linked disorder.

 

Color blindness is a condition in which an individual has difficulty distinguishing between different colors. It is caused by a genetic mutation that affects the development or function of the photopigments in the retina of the eye.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thalassemia: Thalassemia, sickle cell anemia, and cystic fibrosis are not X-linked disorders. They are all Autosomal recessive inheritance. Thalassemia is an inherited blood disorder that affects the production of hemoglobin, a protein in red blood cells that carries oxygen.

 

Option C. Sickle cell anemia: Sickle cell anemia is also an inherited blood disorder that affects the production of hemoglobin, leading to the formation of abnormal, sickle-shaped red blood cells.

 

Option D. Cystic fibrosis: Cystic fibrosis is an inherited disorder that affects the production and function of mucus, leading to the buildup of thick, sticky mucus in the lungs and other organs.

 

These conditions are inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, meaning that both parents must carry a mutated gene to pass the condition on to their children.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Color blindness is an X-linked disorder, meaning that the gene causing the condition is located on the X chromosome, which primarily affects males and is passed down from carrier mothers.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked in the CT scan shown below: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Superior vena cava

 

The structure marked as 'A' in the CT thorax is the superior vena cava.

questions.text: Serotonin is also known as? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 5-hydroxytryptamine

 

  • Serotonin is 5-hydroxytryptamine. It is produced in the brain, mast cells, platelets and gastrointestinal tract mucosa.
  • Tryptophan is first hydroxylated by tryptophan hydroxylase. The co-enzyme is tetrahydrobiopterin. The tetrahydrobiopterin is regenerated using NADPH.
  • In the next step, 5-hydroxytryptophan is decarboxylated to 5-hydroxytryptamine (5HT), (serotonin). The enzyme, decarboxylase requires pyridoxal phosphate.
  • The effect of serotonin is dependent on the amount of serotonin available at the synaptic site. Part of the serotonin released is again taken up (reuptake). Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRI) are widely used in the treatment of psychiatric disorders
  • Monoamine oxidase (MAO) converts serotonin to 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid (HIAA). MAO will oxidatively deaminate compounds having an amino group attached to a carbon atom. MAO inhibitors (e.g., iproniazid) will cause mood elevation.

 

Clinical correlation:

 

CARCINOID SYNDROME

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 5-hydroxytryptophan: This is a precursor to serotonin, involved in its biosynthetic pathway, but not the same as serotonin.

 

Option C. 5-carboxytryptamine: This compound does not exist in serotonin’s metabolic pathway and is unrelated to its structure or function.

 

Option D. 5-carboxytryptophan: This is also not part of the serotonin synthesis or its structure; it is a hypothetical derivative that does not have a role in serotonin’s biological actions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Serotonin, also known as 5-hydroxytryptamine, is a crucial neurotransmitter synthesized from tryptophan and involved in numerous physiological processes. Its synthesis involves specific enzymatic actions that are targeted pharmacologically to manage various psychiatric

questions.text: Mycoplasma is inherently resistant to which of the following antibiotics? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Beta lactam antibiotics

 

Mycoplasma is inherently resistant to beta-lactam antibiotics.

 

Mycoplasma lack cell wall, and therefore, are inherently resistant to beta-lactam antibiotics as these drugs act on the cell wall.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Macrolides: Incorrect, as macrolides are effective against Mycoplasma. They work by inhibiting protein synthesis and are commonly used to treat infections caused by these bacteria.

 

Option C. Tetracycline: Incorrect, tetracyclines are also effective against Mycoplasma and work by inhibiting bacterial protein synthesis.

 

Option D. Fluoroquinolones: Incorrect, fluoroquinolones, which inhibit bacterial DNA synthesis, are effective against a broad range of bacteria, including Mycoplasma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The unique features of Mycoplasma is the absence of a cell wall, this is why beta-lactam antibiotics are not suitable for treating infections caused by Mycoplasma.

questions.text: Fallen fragment sign is characteristic of:(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Simple bone cyst

 

SIMPLE BONE CYST

 

  • Also known as unicameral bone cyst.
  • It affects children in the first and second decade.
  • The lesions are most active during skeletal growth and usually heal spontaneously at maturity.
  • They arise in the metaphysis and are central or medullary.
  • The proximal humerus and proximal femur are common sites.
  • It is not a tumor.
  • The condition is usually asymptomatic, unless discovered after a pathological fracture or as an incidental finding on X-ray.
  • An SBC contains serous or serosanguinous fluid.
  • Plain radiographs reveal a centrally located, purely lytic lesion with a well-marginated outline.
  • Occasionally (20%), a thinned cortical fragment fractures and falls into the base of the lesion confirming its empty cystic nature. This, ‘Fallen Fragment’ sign, is pathognomonic of a unicameral bone cyst.
  • Bone fragment may also hinge around and move with fluid – ‘Trap Door sign’
  • Unicameral bone cysts are classified as active when they are within 1 cm of the physis and latent when they are closer to the diaphysis.
  • Small, asymptomatic lesions in the upper extremities can be treated with observation with serial plain radiographs.
  • Larger lesions (lesions at risk for pathological fracture), symptomatic lesions, and lesions in the lower extremities are usually are treated with curettage (with or without bone grafting or internal fixation) or aspiration and injection (often using steroids, bone marrow aspirate, demineralized bone matrix, or sclerosant).

 

 

A. Unicameral or simple bone cyst; B. Fallen fragment (leaf) sign

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aneurysmal bone cyst. Aneurysmal bone cysts are locally destructive, blood-filled reactive lesions of bone and are not considered to be true neoplasms. Most commonly involves the lower limbs. Vertebral lesions (15-20%) are located in the posterior elements.

 

 

Radiographs reveal an expansile lytic lesion that elevates the periosteum, but remains contained by a thin shell of cortical bone. It can have well-defined margins or a permeative appearance that mimics a malignancy. It is most often eccentrically located in the metaphysis. When differentiating between a unicameral and aneurysmal bone cyst using MRI, the presence of a double-density fluid level and intralesional septations usually indicates an aneurysmal bone cyst.

 

 

Double-density fluid level on MRI

 

Aneurysmal bone cysts are treated with extended curettage and grafting. Lesions in the spine or pelvis can be treated with preoperative embolization to minimize surgical blood loss. Low-dose irradiation is an effective method of treatment, often associated with rapid ossification; however, it is not used routinely because of the potential for malignant transformation.

 

Option C. Giant cell tumor. They typically occur in 20-40 years old patients. There is a slight female predominance. The most common location is the distal femur, followed by the proximal tibia. Tumor of lower end radius is GCT till proved otherwise. GCT has egg shell crackling on palpation. Although these tumors are benign, pulmonary metastases occur in approximately 3% of patients. Malignant giant cell tumors represent less than 5% of total GCT. Radiographic findings often are diagnostic. The lesions are eccentrically located in the epiphyses of long bones and usually about the subchondral bone. Although rare in skeletally immature patients, giant cell tumors arise in the metaphysis in this age group. Radiographically, the lesions are purely lytic. The lesion frequently expands or breaks through the cortex; however, intraarticular extension is rare because the subchondral bone usually remains intact.

 

 

Treatment includes extended curettage and bone grafting; excision and replacement by vascularized bone graft/prosthetic replacement.

 

Option D. Ewing’s sarcoma. Ewing sarcoma is the fourth most common primary malignancy of bone, but it is the second most common (after osteosarcoma) in patients younger than 30 years of age and the most common in patients younger than 10 years of age. Its maximum incidence is seen in 2nd decade of life. Pain is an almost universal complaint of patients. In addition to pain, patients also may have fever, erythema, and swelling suggesting osteomyelitis. Laboratory studies may reveal increased WBC count, an elevated ESR, and an elevated CRP. Classically, Ewing sarcoma appears radiographically as a destructive lesion in the diaphysis of a long bone with an “onion skin” periosteal reaction. Ewing sarcoma more often originates in the metaphysis of a long bone, but frequently extends for a considerable distance into the diaphysis. Lung is the most common site of metastases. The worst prognostic factor is the presence of distant metastases. Even with aggressive treatment, patients with metastases have only a 20% chance of long-term survival. The treatment include neoadjuvant or adjuvant chemotherapy, or both, to treat distant metastases. Chemotherapy is much more effective and include vincristine, actinomycin D, cyclophosphamide, bleomycin, adriamycin, ifosfamide and etoposide.

 

  • ABCD: Actinomycin D / Bleomycin / Cyclophosphamide / Doxorubicin
  • Best results are achieved by Preoperative chemotherapy; then wide excision (or amputation) if tumor is in favorable site and further chemotherapy for 1 year. Subsequently Radiotherapy may be given.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fallen fragment sign is seen in simple (unicameral) bone cyst. It is a thinned cortical fragment that fractures and falls into the base of the lesion, confirming its empty cystic nature

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient has come with sudden onset of chest pain and his CT scan shows the following picture. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Aortic dissection

 

The presence of double lumen of the ascending aorta on the CT angiography is a characteristic finding of aortic dissection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pulmonary embolism: Typically presents with chest pain and shortness of breath, but the key imaging finding would be a filling defect in the pulmonary arteries, not aortic abnormalities.

 

Option C. Aortic aneurysm: Characterized by an abnormal bulge in the aorta, which would appear as an outpouching of the aortic wall rather than a dissection.

 

Option D. Myocardial infarction: The primary diagnostic tools are ECG and cardiac enzymes; it would not typically be diagnosed via CT angiography focusing on the aorta.

 

Educational Objective:

 

AORTIC DISSECTION

 

  • Risk factor – Hypertension (MC), connective tissue disorder – Marfan’s syndrome
  • Clinical features – Acute chest pain, radiating to back
  • IOC in unstable patients - TEE
  • IOC in stable patients - CT angiography

 

Stanford classification

 

  • Ascending is involved – Urgent surgical intervention
  • B – Ascending not involved – Medical management – IV esmolol

choices.text: Concentration of the drug is 50% ionized and 50 % non-ionized
Concentration of the drug is 90% ionized and 10% non-ionized
Concentration of the drug is 75% ionized and 25 % non-ionized
Concentration of the drug is 25% ionized and 75 % non-ionized

questions.text: When the pH = pKa of a drug, which of the following statements is true? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Concentration of the drug is 50% ionized and 50 % non-ionized

 

As per the Henderson Hasselbach equation:

 

pH = pKa + log (Ionized form/Non-ionized form)

 

pKa of a drug is the pH at which 50% of the drug is ionized and 50% of the drug is non-ionized.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When the pH of the environment is equal to the pKa of the drug, the drug exists in a state where 50% is ionized and 50% is non-ionized. This is a critical concept in understanding drug solubility and absorption.

questions.text: Cutaneous larva migrans is most commonly caused by which organism? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ancylostoma braziliense

 

Cutaneous larva migrans is most commonly caused by Ancylostoma braziliense.

 

Cutaneous larva migrans or ground itch or creeping eruption is caused by nematode larvae that infect by skin penetration.

 

The most common cause is non-human species of Hookworm Ancylostoma braziliense and A. caninum.

 

Larva currens – Strongyloides stercolaris

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Strongyloides stercolaris: Incorrect, although Strongyloides stercolaris can cause skin symptoms (known as larva currens) due to the rapid migration of larvae, it is not the most common cause of cutaneous larva migrans.

 

Option B. Toxocara canis: Incorrect, this organism causes toxocariasis or visceral larva migrans, primarily affecting organs and causing systemic symptoms, rather than the localized skin manifestations seen in cutaneous larva migrans.

 

Option D. Necator americanus: Incorrect, this is a human hookworm that primarily causes gastrointestinal symptoms upon infection, not cutaneous larva migrans.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ancylostoma braziliense is the primary cause of cutaneous larva migrans, a condition where the migration of hookworm larvae in the skin results in distinctive creeping eruptions. This condition is a reminder of the zoonotic potential of certain parasites and underscores the importance of preventive measures, especially in areas where pets are likely to be infected.

questions.text: Modified shock index is calculated using? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. HR/MAP

 

Modified shock index = HR/MAP

 

A shock index >0.9 is indicative of higher mortality.

 

HR: Heart rate

 

MAP: Mean arterial pressure

 

SBP: Systolic blood pressure

 

DBP: Diastolic blood pressure

 

# Commonly confused:

 

Formula for shock index= Heart rate/ systolic blood pressure

 

Educational Objective :

 

Modified shock index = HR/MAP

questions.text: In which trimester does acute fatty liver manifest most commonly during pregnancy? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Third trimester

 

Explanation:

 

Acute fatty liver of pregnancy (AFLP) is a life-threatening medical disorder involving the liver. It most commonly manifests during the late second and third trimester of pregnancy. The diagnosis is made by the Swansea Criteria, wherein 6 or more of the following are required to make the diagnosis:

 

  • Vomiting
  • Abdominal pain
  • Polydipsia, polyuria
  • Encephalopathy
  • Coagulopathy (raised PT, aPTT)
  • Increased bilirubin
  • Increased uric acid levels
  • Increased creatinine
  • Leukocytosis
  • Hypoglycemia
  • Raised liver enzymes
  • Raised serum ammonia levels
  • Ascites or bright liver on ultrasound
  • Microvascular steatosis on liver biopsy

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute fatty liver of pregnancy (AFLP) most commonly manifests during the third trimester of pregnancy and is diagnosed using the Swansea Criteria.

 

Ref: Page no 2684, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common end-product of fatty acid synthesis pathway? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Palmitic acid

 

Palmitic acid is the most common end-product of fatty acid synthesis. It is a saturated fatty acid with 16 carbon atoms and is a major product of de novo fatty acid synthesis in the body.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Arachidonic acid: Arachidonic acid is not the most common end-product of fatty acid synthesis. It is a polyunsaturated fatty acid that can be synthesized from linoleic acid, which is an essential fatty acid.

 

Option B. Oleic acid: Oleic acid is not the most common end-product of fatty acid synthesis. It is a monounsaturated fatty acid that can be synthesized within the fatty acid synthesis pathway but is not the most common end product.

 

Option D. Acetyl CoA: Acetyl CoA is not an end-product of fatty acid synthesis. It is a starting substrate for fatty acid synthesis, as fatty acids are synthesized by adding two-carbon units (acetyl groups) to a growing fatty acid chain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fatty acids are synthesized from acetyl CoA mainly by a de novo synthetic pathway operating in the cytoplasm referred to as extramitochondrial or cytoplasmic fatty acid synthase system.

 

The major fatty acid synthesized de novo is palmitic acid, the 16C saturated fatty acid. The process occurs in liver, adipose tissue, kidney, brain, and mammary glands.

 

Beta oxidation of fatty acids breaks it down into Acetyl CoA.

 

 

Defect in pathway - Inhibition of lipogenesis occurs in type 1 (insulin-dependent) diabetes mellitus, and variations in its activity affect the nature and extent of obesity.

questions.text: Which of the following should be avoided by a patient of fish odor syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Choline

 

Choline should be avoided by patients with fish odor syndrome. Choline is metabolized in the body to trimethylamine (TMA), which is responsible for the fishy odor in individuals with TMAU. Therefore, reducing choline intake can help manage the condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Biotin: Biotin is not typically associated with exacerbating fish odor syndrome, so it does not need to be avoided.

 

Option C. Niacin: Niacin, also known as vitamin B3, is not directly related to fish odor syndrome. It does not need to be avoided.

 

Option D. Pantothenic Acid: Pantothenic acid, also known as vitamin B5, is not directly associated with fish odor syndrome and does not need to be avoided.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fish odor syndrome (trimethylaminuria) is a metabolic syndrome caused by abnormal excretion of trimethylamine in the breath, urine, sweat, saliva and vaginal secretions. Trimethylamine is derived from the intestinal bacterial degradation of foods rich in choline and carnitine and is normally oxidized by the liver to odorless trimethylamine N-oxide which is then excreted in the urine. Impaired oxidation of trimethylamine due to the deficiency of flavin containing mono oxygenase 3 (FMO3) is thought to be the cause of the fish odor syndrome and is responsible for the smell of rotting fish.

 

Foods like eggs, liver, peanuts, meat, poultry, fish, dairy foods, pasta and rice are to be avoided.

choices.text: Decreased GFR
Has inotropic effect

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding the actions of endothelin-1 except? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Bronchodilation

 

Explanation

 

Contrary to bronchodilation, ET-1 actually causes bronchoconstriction in the lungs, mediated through ET-B receptors. This makes it detrimental in respiratory pathologies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vasoconstriction: Correct and a well-documented action of ET-1.

 

Option C. Decreased GFR: Correct, as ET-1 affects renal blood flow and filtration.

 

Option D. Has inotropic effect: Correct, ET-1 increases the force of heart contractions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Actions of Endothelin-1 (ET-1)

 

  1. On blood vessels - Potent vasoconstrictor, vascular growth, matrix production inflammation → can lead to atherosclerosis, Pulmonary artery hypertension, systemic hypertension
  2. On heart – Inotropic effect, Apoptosis, cardiomyocytes and cardio fibroblast growth and metabolism → can lead to heart failure, cardiac fibrosis, cardiac hypertrophy
  3. In the kidneys - involved in Tubuloglomerular feedback - \ GFR leads to diuresis, natriuresis, glomerular filtration, renal blood flow. Maybe be involved in glomerulosclerosis diabetic nephropathy, polycystic kidney disease, proteinuric diseases, hypertension.
  4. In the lungs, it causes bronchoconstriction (mediated via ET-B receptors)
  5. In the brain, - regulate the transport of substances across blood brain barrier (BBB).
  6. In GIT, they are involved in the migration of myenteric plexus to distal colon (failure leads to Hirschsprung's/megacolon).
  7. Platelet activation
  8. Closure of ductus arteriosus.
  9. Deletion of both alleles of ET-1 gene - craniofacial abnormalities and respiratory failure at birth.

questions.text: The single most important long-term limitation of cardiac transplantation is: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Allograft arteriopathy

 

The single most important long-term limitation of cardiac transplantation is allograft arteriopathy.

 

Allograft arteriopathy: It is the single most important long-term limitation for cardiac transplantation. It is a late, progressive, diffusely stenosing intimal proliferation in the coronary arteries, leading to ischemic injury. It can lead to silent myocardial infarction since transplant patients have denervated hearts and do not experience angina. Progressive congestive heart failure and sudden cardiac death can also occur.

 

Other Options:

 

Complications following cardiac transplantation:

 

Option A. Allograft rejection: It is the primary concern that requires close surveillance. Both classic cellular rejection and antibody-mediated rejection is recognized. Cellular rejection is characterized by interstitial lymphocytic inflammation, with associated myocyte damage.

 

Option C. Infection: Infection is common in organ transplant recipients. Bacteria and viruses account for more than 80% of infections after transplantation. The most common bacterial infections early after transplantation are nosocomial, caused by infected intravascular catheters or lines, or gram-negative pneumonias.

 

Renal dysfunction- Immunosuppressive therapy with calcineurin inhibitors has improved both graft function and survival in heart transplantation.

 

Option D. Malignancy: Following heart transplantation, malignancy is identified in 3% to 18% of the recipients, with an estimated risk of 1% to 2% per year. It ranks second to coronary vasculopathy as a major cause of mortality, accounting for 10% to 23% of all deaths following heart transplantation. Cutaneous malignancy is the most common type with a predominance of squamous cell carcinoma. Post-transplantation lymphoproliferative disorder (PTLD) is a frequently fatal complication, the peak occurrence of PTLD is 3 to 4 months after transplantation. A strong association of PTLD with Epstein-Barr virus has been observed in several series.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Allograft arteriopathy is the foremost long-term limitation in cardiac transplantation, causing significant morbidity and mortality through progressive coronary stenosis.

questions.text: Which fungus is most commonly associated with orbital cellulitis in patients with diabetic ketoacidosis? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rhizopus

 

Rhizopus is the most common fungus associated with orbital cellulitis in patients with diabetic ketoacidosis.

 

Diabetic patients are immunocompromised and so prone to develop opportunistic infections. Orbital cellulitis with Rhizopus may turn fatal in these patients as it is an angioinvasive fungus and could lead to septicemia and thromboses.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Candida: Incorrect, although Candida is a common opportunistic pathogen, it is more frequently associated with mucocutaneous and systemic infections rather than orbital cellulitis.

 

Option C. Aspergillus: Incorrect, Aspergillus can cause a variety of infections including orbital cellulitis, but it is not the most common cause in the context of diabetic ketoacidosis.

 

Option D. Trichophyton: Incorrect, Trichophyton primarily causes skin infections such as ringworm and athlete's foot, and is not typically associated with orbital cellulitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rhizopus is the predominant fungal pathogen linked with orbital cellulitis in patients with diabetic ketoacidosis, underscoring the critical need for prompt diagnosis and aggressive treatment in such high-risk groups to prevent severe complications.

choices.text: During palpation, over the left hypochondrium

questions.text: A 6-week-old infant is brought to the clinic with a history of projectile vomiting and poor weight gain. Physical examination reveals an abdominal mass in the epigastrium, and the diagnosis of congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis is suspected. An abdominal mass in a patient with congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis is best seen? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. During feeding

 

Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS) is a condition where the pylorus becomes hypertrophied and thickened. This leads to gastric outlet obstruction and symptoms such as projectile vomiting, dehydration, and electrolyte imbalances.

 

True. During feeding, or immediately after, the thickened muscle of the pylorus might be most palpable. As the stomach tries to empty its contents through the narrowed pylorus, the hypertrophied muscle can contract and become more prominent. This is called the "olive-like mass" which is palpable in the epigastrium to the right of the midline. This sign is pathognomonic for CHPS. The act of feeding induces peristaltic waves in the stomach, making the pyloric mass more prominent and easier to palpate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Soon after birth: CHPS typically presents in the third to fifth week of life, although it can be present at birth. It is rare to palpate the mass immediately after birth. The symptoms usually progress, and the hypertrophic pylorus becomes more palpable as the condition worsens.

 

Option C. During palpation, over the left hypochondrium: The pylorus is located on the right side of the abdomen, so palpating the left hypochondrium wouldn't help in detecting a mass related to CHPS.

 

Option D. During palpation, over the epigastrium: While the hypertrophied pyloric muscle can indeed be felt in the epigastrium, its palpability becomes much more distinct during or after feeding due to the reasons mentioned in option A. The epigastrium is the upper central region of the abdomen and is the location where the "olive-like mass" of CHPS is most frequently palpated.

 

Educational Objective:


In congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis, the characteristic "olive-like mass" is most easily palpated during or immediately after feeding when the stomach contracts against the hypertrophied pyloric muscle.

choices.text: Heart rate remains at < 60 beats/minute despite effective compressions and ventilations.
Heart rate remains at < 100 beats/minute despite effective compressions and ventilations.
Heart rate does not improve after 30 seconds with bag and mask ventilation.
Infants with severe respiratory depression fail to respond to positive-pressure ventilation via bag and mask.

questions.text: When do you consider administering epinephrine in a neonate during resuscitation? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Heart rate remains at < 60 beats/ minutes despite effective compression and ventilation.

 

If the heart rate remains at < 60 beats/minute despite effective compressions and ventilation, consider administering epinephrine in neonatal resuscitation.

 

 

Note: Umbilical venous catheter is the preferred method of obtaining emergency vascular access in the delivery room.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Heart rate remains at < 100 beats/minute despite effective compressions and ventilations.: if the heart rate is <100 bpm, we do bag and mask ventilation.

 

Option C. Heart rate does not improve after 30 seconds with bag and mask ventilation.: If the heart rate doesnot improve after 30 seconds of bag and mask ventilation, then we do ventilation corrective steps.

 

Option D. Infants with severe respiratory depression fail to respond to positive-pressure ventilation via bag and mask: if the baby is not responding to bag and mask ventilation then check the heart rate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Epinephrine is administered in neonatal resuscitation when the heart rate remains below 60 beats per minute despite 30 seconds of effective positive-pressure ventilation and chest compressions.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a common feature of ABPA? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Distal bronchiectasis

 

ABPA is diagnosed based on ISHAM criteria which requires the following:

  1. Predisposing Condition: Asthma/Cystic fibrosis
  2. Mandatory Criteria:
    • Serum IgE > 1000 IU/mL
    • Aspergillus specific IgE >0.35kU/L(OR) +ve skin test against A. fumigatus. (Test indicates sensitization/Type1 HSN reaction)
  3. Supportive Criteria (≥2 should be present):
    • Total eosinophil > 500 cells/mm3
    • Aspergillus specific IgG
    • Radiology Typical for ABPA
      • Central and proximal cylindrical bronchiectasis
      • Alterations predominantly in the upper lobe
      • Nodules
      • Atelectasis
      • Air trapping

 

Note: HAM (High attenuation mucus) is pathognomonic feature of ABPA on HRCT

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cough: Cough is a typical symptom of ABPA, resulting from airway inflammation and response to mucus production.

 

Option C. Wheezing: Wheezing in ABPA is due to airway obstruction caused by mucus plugging and inflammation.

 

Option D. Raised serum IgE levels: Elevated IgE levels are a hallmark of ABPA, reflecting the immune system’s hypersensitivity reaction to Aspergillus.

 

Educational Objective:


Central and proximal bronchiectasis, not distal bronchiectasis, is a characteristic radiological finding in ABPA, helping to differentiate it from other pulmonary conditions. The presence of cough, wheezing, and significantly raised serum IgE levels are supportive of the diagnosis.

 

Reference: Harrison 21/Pulmonary infiltrates with eosinophilia/Chap 288

questions.text:
Which of the following cannot cross the placenta? (NEET PG 2018)

 

  1. Iron
  2. Albumin
  3. Immunoglobulin M
  4. Immunoglobulin G
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2 and 3

 

High molecular weight substances such as proteins (e.g., albumin, IgM, IgA) cannot cross the placenta.

 

Other Options:

 

1: Iron can cross the placenta via active transport mechanisms, making this option incorrect.

 

4: Immunoglobulin G (IgG) can cross the placenta through endocytosis and exocytosis mechanisms, making this option incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

High molecular weight substances such as albumin and Immunoglobulin M (IgM) cannot cross the placenta.

questions.text: Which of the following is the drug of choice for scrub typhus? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Doxycycline

 

Scrub typhus is a rickettsial infection caused by Orientia tsutsugamushi. The main agent of choice in its treatment is Doxycycline. In pregnancy, as doxycycline is contraindicated, Azithromycin or Chloramphenicol can be used.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Azithromycin: Azithromycin is an alternative treatment for scrub typhus, especially in pregnant women where doxycycline is contraindicated. However, it is not the first-line treatment.

 

Option C. Chloramphenicol: Chloramphenicol can be used as an alternative treatment for scrub typhus. It is effective but less commonly used due to potential severe side effects like bone marrow suppression.

 

Option D. Ciprofloxacin: Ciprofloxacin is not typically used for the treatment of scrub typhus. It is more commonly used for bacterial infections, particularly those caused by gram-negative bacteria.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Doxycycline is the drug of choice for scrub typhus due to its high efficacy in treating this rickettsial infection. Azithromycin and chloramphenicol can be used as alternatives in cases where doxycycline is contraindicated, such as during pregnancy.

choices.text: Fertilization of 2 ova released at the same time by sperms released at single intercourse
Fertilization of 2 ova released at the same time by sperms released at intercourse on 2 different occasions

questions.text: In superfecundation, which of the following is seen? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) fertilization of 2 ova released at the same time by sperms released at intercourse on 2 different occasions

 

Explanation:

 

Superfecundation refers to the fertilization of two different ova released in the same menstrual cycle by sperm from separate acts of intercourse occurring within a short period of time. This can result in twins with different fathers if the sperm comes from two different men, a phenomenon known as heteropaternal superfecundation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fertilization of 2 ova released at the same time by sperms released at single intercourse: This describes the fertilization of two ova by sperm from a single act of intercourse, which is not superfecundation but simply the result of one intercourse fertilizing two ova simultaneously.

 

Option C. Both of the above: While it includes the correct scenario of superfecundation, it also includes an incorrect scenario, making it partially correct.

 

Option D. None of the above: This indicates that none of the given scenarios are correct, which is inaccurate as option B is correct.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Superfecundation is the fertilization of two ova released during the same menstrual cycle by sperm from separate acts of intercourse.

 

Ref: Page 227, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

questions.text: The ligament that maintains anteversion of the uterus during pregnancy is: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Round ligament

 

Explanation:

 

The round ligament is responsible for maintaining the anteversion of the uterus, particularly during pregnancy. It consists of smooth muscle extensions of the uterine corpus and is the homologue of the gubernaculum testis. These ligaments arise from the lateral aspect of the corpus just below and anterior to the origin of the fallopian tubes, extend laterally to the pelvic sidewall, and enter the retroperitoneal space. They pass lateral to the inferior epigastric vessels before entering the inguinal canal through the internal inguinal ring and terminate in the subcutaneous tissue of the labia majora. During pregnancy, the round ligaments stretch to accommodate the enlarging uterus, helping to maintain its anteverted position. It maintains the angle of anteversion of 120°

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cardinal ligament: Also known as the transverse cervical ligament or Mackenrodt ligaments, these provide significant support to the uterus and cervix by attaching the lateral aspect of the uterus and cervix to the pelvic walls. However, they do not maintain anteversion.

 

Option C. Uterosacral ligament: These ligaments insert broadly into the posterior pelvic walls and sacrum and form the lateral boundaries of the cul-de-sac (Pouch of Douglas). They play a role in supporting the uterus but do not contribute to maintaining anteversion.

 

Option D. Pubocervical ligament: This ligament forms part of the supportive structure for the uterus and vagina, attaching them to the pubic bone. It provides anterior support but does not maintain the anteversion of the uterus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The round ligament is primarily responsible for maintaining the anteversion of the uterus, especially during pregnancy.

choices.text: Transgastric FNAC guided by endoscopic ultrasound

questions.text: The best method to obtain tissue for the diagnosis of pancreatic carcinoma is: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Transgastric FNAC guided by endoscopic ultrasound

 

Transgastric FNAC guided by endoscopic ultrasound (EUS) is a minimally invasive technique that involves the insertion of a needle through the stomach wall under ultrasound guidance to obtain a sample of pancreatic tissue. EUS-guided biopsy has a high diagnostic accuracy and is considered the preferred method for diagnosing pancreatic carcinoma as it avoids the spillage of tumor cells into the peritoneal cavity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. MRI-guided biopsy: Is a technique that uses magnetic resonance imaging to guide the insertion of a needle to obtain a tissue sample. This technique is not commonly used for diagnosing pancreatic carcinoma due to its low accuracy.

 

Option C. Laparoscopic-guided biopsy: Is a minimally invasive surgical technique that involves the insertion of a laparoscope through small incisions in the abdomen to visualize the pancreas and obtain a tissue sample. Laparoscopic biopsy is a more invasive option than EUS-guided biopsy but may be used when other methods are unsuccessful.

 

Option D. Percutaneous transperitoneal biopsy: Involves the insertion of a needle through the abdominal wall to obtain a tissue sample from the pancreas. This technique is less commonly used for diagnosing pancreatic carcinoma due to the risk of complications such as bleeding and infection.

 

Overall, EUS-guided biopsy is the preferred method for obtaining tissue for the diagnosis of pancreatic carcinoma due to its high diagnostic accuracy and minimally invasive nature.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transgastric FNAC guided by endoscopic ultrasound (EUS) is the preferred method for diagnosing pancreatic carcinoma due to its high diagnostic accuracy and minimally invasive nature.

questions.text: Which of the following antimicrobials is effective against an organism producing extended-spectrum beta-lactamases? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Piperacillin - tazobactam

 

ESBL is produced by gram-negative organisms like Klebsiella and E. coli. They are resistant to most of the Beta-lactam antibiotics like Penicillin and most of the Cephalosporins. Tazobactam, Sulbactam and Clavulanic acid are beta lactamase inhibitors, hence they can be used against ESBL producing organisms. Therefore, the correct option will be Piperacillin+ Tazobactam combination.

 

Piperacillin-tazobactam is effective against ESBL-producing organisms because tazobactam inhibits the beta-lactamase enzyme, allowing piperacillin to exert its antibacterial effect.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amoxicillin - clavulanic acid: Although clavulanic acid is a beta-lactamase inhibitor, the combination of amoxicillin and clavulanic acid is generally less effective against ESBL-producing organisms compared to piperacillin-tazobactam.

 

Option B. Penicillin: Penicillin alone is not effective against ESBL-producing organisms because it is susceptible to degradation by beta-lactamases.

 

Option D. Ceftriaxone: Ceftriaxone, a third-generation cephalosporin, is generally ineffective against ESBL-producing organisms as they can hydrolyze this class of antibiotics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Piperacillin-tazobactam is effective against organisms producing extended-spectrum beta-lactamases (ESBLs) due to the beta-lactamase inhibitory action of tazobactam, which protects piperacillin from enzymatic degradation, allowing it to kill the bacteria.

choices.text: Primary active transport
Facilitated diffusion
Simple diffusion
Secondary active transport

questions.text: Which of the following process is responsible for glucose absorption into the intestine?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Secondary active transport

 

Explanation   

 

Glucose is absorbed into the intestine by secondary active transport because this process allows for the efficient uptake of glucose against its concentration gradient.

 

Secondary active transport involves the coupled movement of two substances across a membrane, where the movement of one substance is dependent on the electrochemical gradient created by the movement of another substance. In the case of glucose absorption in the intestine, the secondary active transport mechanism relies on the sodium gradient created by the sodium-potassium pump.

 

The process of glucose absorption in the intestine occurs in the brush border membrane of the intestinal epithelial cells, specifically in the small intestine. Here's a step-by-step explanation of how secondary active transport facilitates glucose absorption:

 

  1. Sodium-Potassium Pump: The sodium-potassium pump actively transports sodium ions (Na+) out of the epithelial cells and into the intercellular space, using ATP energy. This creates a concentration gradient where the sodium concentration is higher outside the cell.
  2. Sodium-Glucose Cotransporter: The sodium gradient generated by the sodium-potassium pump is utilized by a specific protein called the sodium-glucose cotransporter (SGLT). This cotransporter binds both sodium ions and glucose molecules on the outer surface of the cell.
  3. Co-transport of Sodium and Glucose: As sodium ions bind to the SGLT protein, their movement into the cell down the concentration gradient provides the necessary energy for the simultaneous movement of glucose against its concentration gradient. Glucose is "dragged" along with the sodium ions as they enter the cell.
  4. Glucose Transporter: Once inside the epithelial cell, glucose is transported across the basolateral membrane (the inner surface of the cell) and into the bloodstream by facilitated diffusion through a specific glucose transporter called GLUT2.

 

Overall, the energy stored in the sodium gradient created by the sodium-potassium pump is used to actively transport both sodium and glucose into the intestinal epithelial cells. This secondary active transport mechanism allows for the absorption of glucose from the intestinal lumen into the bloodstream efficiently, even when the concentration of glucose is higher inside the cell than in the lumen.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Primary active transport: Incorrect because primary active transport involves the direct use of ATP to move substances against their gradient, which does not apply to glucose absorption in this context.

 

Option B. Facilitated diffusion: Incorrect as this method does not involve the active transport of glucose against its concentration gradient; it only allows movement along the gradient.

 

Option C. Simple diffusion: Incorrect because simple diffusion does not involve any transport proteins and occurs only along the concentration gradient, which is not sufficient for glucose absorption in the intestine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glucose absorption in the intestine occurs via secondary active transport, utilizing the energy from the sodium gradient created by the sodium-potassium ATPase to transport glucose against its concentration gradient. This process is crucial for efficient glucose uptake from the intestinal lumen into the bloodstream.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is oxygen therapy not useful? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Central respiratory depression

 

Explanation 

 

Oxygen therapy is not beneficial in central respiratory depression, as oxygen therapy will reduce the hypoxic drive to breathe further depressing the respiratory frequency and minute ventilation.



 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Asthma: Because oxygen therapy can be crucial in severe asthma attacks where it helps alleviate hypoxia.

 

Option B. Acute myocardial infarction: As oxygen therapy is often used to increase oxygen delivery to the heart tissue, reducing ischemic damage during an acute myocardial infarction.

 

Option C. Pulmonary edema: Because oxygen therapy helps improve oxygenation in cases of pulmonary edema, especially if caused by heart failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oxygen therapy is not beneficial in central respiratory depression because it may reduce the hypoxic drive to breathe, potentially further depressing respiratory effort and overall ventilation.

choices.text: Suspicion of Laryngeal carcinoma planned for surgery later

questions.text: Which of the following is an indication of high tracheostomy? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Suspicion of Laryngeal carcinoma planned for surgery later

 

A high tracheostomy is done above the level of thyroid isthmus (isthmus lies against II, III and IV tracheal rings). It violates the first ring of trachea. Tracheostomy at this site can cause perichondritis of the cricoid cartilage and subglottic stenosis and is always avoided.

 

Only indication for high tracheostomy is carcinoma of the larynx because in such cases, the total larynx anyway would ultimately be removed and a fresh tracheostome made in a clean area lower down.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vocal cord palsy - Not an indication for high tracheostomy as it does not necessitate altering the anatomy at the level of the isthmus or above.

 

Option B. Tracheomalacia - This condition, characterized by a weakness of the tracheal support cartilage, does not require a high tracheostomy. Treatment usually involves support lower in the trachea.

 

Option C. Foreign body obstruction - Removal of a foreign body typically does not require a high tracheostomy. This procedure would be too high to effectively clear an obstruction that is likely situated lower in the airway.

 

Educational Objective:

 

High tracheostomy is specifically indicated for suspicion of laryngeal carcinoma planned for surgery, as this condition requires eventual removal of the larynx, allowing for the creation of a fresh tracheostome in a new, clean area.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 359

questions.text: Which of the following is an opsonin? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) C3b

 

C3b functions as an opsonin.

 

Opsonization: - The process of coating a foreign particle and preparing it for phagocytosis. The substances involved in this process are called opsonins.

 

Include:

 

  • Mannose-binding lectin
  • IgM and Fc receptor of IgG
  • CRP
  • Fibrinogen
  • C3b, C4b, C5b

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. C3a and C. C5a: These are anaphylatoxins involved in inflammation and promoting chemotaxis.

 

Option D. C6: Part of the membrane attack complex (MAC) of the complement system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

C3b is an opsonin important in the immune system for marking pathogens for phagocytosis, enhancing the body's ability to clear infections.

questions.text: Which of the following is the earliest sign in Crohn's disease? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Aphthous ulcers

 

These are shallow, round ulcers that are often seen in the mouth but can also occur in the small intestine and colon in Crohn's disease. They are the earliest sign of Crohn's disease and are often recurrent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cobblestone appearance: This is a characteristic finding in Crohn's disease and refers to the appearance of the mucosa with raised, rounded, and separated areas resembling cobblestones. This is caused by transmural inflammation and can be seen in the terminal ileum and colon.
