Option B. Deep fissured ulcers: These are another feature of Crohn's disease that can occur anywhere in the gastrointestinal tract. They are deep, often extend into the submucosa, and can lead to the formation of fistulas or abscesses.

 

Option C. Rose-thorn appearance: This term is sometimes used to describe the appearance of the mucosa in Crohn's disease, where there are linear ulcers that are surrounded by raised, edematous tissue. This pattern is more commonly seen in the colon.

 

Educational Objective:


Aphthous ulcers are the earliest sign of Crohn's disease, often appearing in the mouth and gastrointestinal tract before more severe lesions develop.

questions.text: Varicella-zoster virus remains dormant in the: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Dorsal root ganglion

 

  • Varicella-zoster virus (VZV) is a human herpesvirus that causes varicella (chickenpox) as a primary infection and then remains in a latent form in the dorsal root ganglia for a variable period after which it can reactivate to cause herpes zoster (shingles) which leads to vesicular lesions that are grouped together in a dermatomal / Segmental distribution as shown in the image below.

 

 

 

  • The mucous membranes within the affected dermatomes are involved.
  • The first symptom of zoster is usually pain, 1-3 days after which the lesions appear.
  • The patients are infectious, both from the virus in the lesions and nasopharynx.
  • The dermatomes of T3 to L3 spinal segments are most affected in all ages. The posterior nerve roots and ganglia show inflammatory changes.
  • Zoster is a self-limiting infection but it is painful and carries a risk of secondary infection and post-herpetic neuralgia. Analgesia and treatment of secondary infections are sufficient for mild infections.

 

Indications for antivirals in VZV (Acyclovir 800 mg):

 

  • Painful zoster infections in adults
  • Facial zoster at any age
  • Immunocompromised
  • The commonest and most intractable complication of zoster is post-herpetic neuralgia. It is generally defined as persistence or recurrence of pain more than 1-3 months after the onset of zoster. Post-herpetic neuralgia is most frequent when the trigeminal nerve is involved.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ventral root

  • It is not associated with the latency of VZV.
  • The ventral root carries motor neurons, not sensory neurons, and VZV is not known to remain dormant in motor neurons or their associated structures.

 

Option B. Skin

  • It is not a site of viral latency.
  • While VZV does cause lesions in the skin, it does not remain dormant there.
  • Skin lesions occur during active infection when the virus reactivates and travels down sensory nerves to the skin.

 

Option C. Medulla oblongata

  • It is a part of the brainstem and is not associated with the latency of VZV.
  • This virus specifically becomes dormant in the peripheral nervous system, not within the central nervous system structures such as the medulla oblongata.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The dorsal root ganglion is the site of latency for the Varicella-zoster virus, which is important for understanding the pathogenesis of both primary varicella infection and reactivation as herpes zoster.

 

Reference

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition, Page no 25.27-25.28

Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 20th Edition, Page no 106

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition, Page no 4.13

Question Level – EASY

Question Id-7448 Unique Key-Q4313194

questions.text: A neonate is brought to the OPD with complaints of redness and discharge from both the eyes, raising a suspicion of ophthalmia neonatorum. What is the most common cause of ophthalmia neonatorum in developed countries?  (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Chlamydia

 

Explanation : 


Chlamydia is the most common bacterial cause of ophthalmia neonatorum in developed countries.


Ophthalmia neonatorum is a type of conjunctivitis seen in the neonatal period,  presenting  5-14 days after birth with red eyes and discharge. It commonly gets transmitted during vaginal delivery. Requires antibiotic treatment.

 


Other Options:

 

Option B. Gonorrhea: Severe, purulent conjunctivitis presenting 2-5 days after birth. It commonly gets transmitted during vaginal delivery, and it correlates with severe complications such as corneal ulceration and perforation, which can potentially result in permanent blindness. Requires Urgent antibiotic treatment.

 

Option C. Chemical conjunctivitis : occurs within 24 hrs , Caused by 1% AgNO3 Crede's method used to prevent ophthalmia neonatorum. Presents with mild inflammation, redness, and tearing, and usually resolves on its own.

 

Option D. Staphylococcus aureus: Less common cause, presenting with mild to moderate redness and discharge. Treated with topical antibiotics.

 

Educational Objective: 
 

 

(REF: Matejcek A, Goldman RD. Treatment and prevention of ophthalmia neonatorum. Can Fam Physician. 2013 Nov;59(11):1187-90. PMID: 24235191; PMCID: PMC3828094.)

questions.text: The observed myocardial stunning pattern does not match the ECG findings of a patient. What is the probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Takotsubo cardiomyopathy

 

 

Stress cardiomyopathy commonly affects Women (post-menopausal) > men predominantly due to emotional > physical stress. Neurogenic myocardial stunning occurs leading to heart failure.

 

Beta-2 (Gs stimulation) is present at base and b2 (Gi) activation leads to hypercontractility at the base & apical ballooning giving a typical Takotsubo appearance.

 

ECG mimics ACS, RWMA not corresponding to single artery territory, normal CAG with Mild troponin elevation are clues to takotsubo.

 

Treatment with beta-blockers, ACE inhibitors if non-responsive. Carries good prognosis.

 

Other options:

 

Option B: Restrictive cardiomyopathy causes diastolic dysfunction on but NOT significant ECG changes.

 

Option C: Brugada syndrome is a channelopathy caused due LOF (loss of function) mutation of cardiac SCN5a (Sodium channel) resulting in transmural voltage difference between endocardium-epicardium causing ventricular arrhythmias which initially affects the RV myocardium.

 

 

Option D: Tamponade occurs due to rapid accumulation of fluid/blood in the pericardium producing the characteristic Beck triad (↑JVP ↓ Heart sounds ↓ BP).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Takotsubo cardiomyopathy should be considered when a patient's clinical presentation includes myocardial stunning that does not correspond to ECG findings typical of a myocardial infarction, especially in the context of recent significant emotional or physical stress.

 

Reference - Harrison/Cardiology/Cardiomyopathies/Chap 259

questions.text: During which week of embryonic development does cardiac activity typically commence? (NEET PG  2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 4th week

 

By the fourth week, the early heart begins to form and starts its contractions. The heart develops from a simple linear tube into a looping structure during this time. This looping eventually gives rise to the various chambers of the heart. Towards the end of the 4th week, the heart starts to beat and pump blood. However, it's worth noting that while the heart starts to beat during this week, the full structure of the heart with its four chambers isn't fully developed yet.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 2nd week: During the second week of embryonic development, formation of the bilaminar embryonic disc takes place, which consists of the epiblast and hypoblast. Additionally, events like the formation of the amniotic cavity, yolk sac and gastrulation begins towards the end of this week. At this point, the heart has not yet begun to form, and thus, there's no heart beating during the 2nd week.

 

Option C. 6th week: By the sixth week, the heart's development has progressed further. The interatrial and interventricular septa are beginning to form. While the heart is beating and becoming more sophisticated in its function, it had already started its contractions in the 4th week.

 

Option D. 10th week: By the 10th week, the embryonic period is concluding, and the fetal period is about to commence. The heart is much more developed, with more defined chambers and valves. Most major organs and external structures are formed by this time, and the fetus looks unmistakably human.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The heart starts to beat in the 4th week of development.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male patient has been diagnosed with hypertension. On examination, there is no existing cardiovascular disease, no hypertension-mediated organ damage (HMOD), and the renal function is normal. He should be immediately started on pharmacological management if his blood pressure is more than: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. > 160/100 mmHg

 

  • The ISH (International society of HTN) 2020 guidelines were made to help decision making in low-middle income countries.
  • Presence of ASCVD risk factors, HMOD (HTN mediated organ damage) is an indication to start anti-HTN therapy.
  • Home BP recording helps in diagnosis of Masked HTN, rule out white-coat effect
  • ABPM provides 24-hour trend and fluctuations in BP.

 

 

Home BP > 135/85 mmHg = HTN

 

ABPM cutoffs:

 

  1. Mean Awake (daytime) average ≥ 135/85 mmHg
  2. 24h average ≥ 130/80 mmHg
  3. Mean Asleep(night) ≥ 120/70 mmHg

 

BP drops at night by (10-20%), morning surge – Steep increase, peaks in late afternoon.
 

Best observed in ABPM (Ambulatory BP monitoring):

 

  • Normal Dip: 10-20 % at night
  • Extreme Dip > 20%
  • Non-dippers < 10% (A/w Activation of RAAS)
  • Risers: BP raise

 

Note: Increase mortality risk among Non-Dippers and Risers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Immediate pharmacological treatment for hypertension in patients without additional cardiovascular risk factors or organ damage should commence when blood pressure levels exceed 160/100 mmHg, according to the ISH 2020 guidelines. This approach helps to target treatment to those most likely to benefit from immediate intervention, balancing the benefits and risks of pharmacotherapy.

 

Reference: ISH2020, AHA2017 HTN guidelines

questions.text: Thrombosis of posterior inferior cerebellar artery causes? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Lateral Medullary syndrome.

 

LATERAL MEDULLARY SYNDROME:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: Weber is a medial midbrain syndrome caused by occlusion of PCA branches.

 

Option C: Medial medullary syndrome (aka Dejerine syndrome) supplied by vertebral/spinal artery.

 

Option D: Millard-Gubler is a lateral pontine syndrome involving peripheral LMN of 7th and 6th nerve (NOT NUCLEUS!) supplied by AICA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Image showing arteries involved in brainstem syndromes lateral vs medial brainstem.

 

 

Reference - Harrison 21E/Chap 426/Neurology/stroke

choices.text: Attached to the inner border of 2nd rib
Attached with transverse process of C7

questions.text: Which among the following statement is incorrect regarding Sibson’s fascia? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Attached to the inner border of 2nd rib

 

Sibson's fascia is joined to the first rib's inner border, not the second rib.

 

Sibson's fascia (suprapleural membrane)

 

  • Covers the apical portion of the lung and acts as a dividing line between the lower neck and the thorax.
  • It is attached to the inner border of the 1st rib and posteriorly to the anterior border of the transverse process of the C7 vertebra.
  • It is strengthened by a few spreading muscular fibers derived from the scalene muscles.
  • The subclavian vessels lie on top of it.

 

Clinical significance

 

  • The suprapleural membrane's function is to protect the apex of the lung (the part that extends outside the rib cage) and the cervical fascia. This aids in resisting intrathoracic pressure changes, preventing neck inflation and deflation during expiration and inspiration, and also providing rigidity to the thoracic inlet.
  • Herniation of the cervical fascia may result due to injury to suprapleural membrane.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Covers apical part of lung (Correct): Sibson's fascia covers the apical (uppermost) part of the lung and helps separate the cervical pleura from the surrounding structures.

 

Option C. Attached with transverse process of C7 (Correct): Sibson's fascia is posteriorly attached with the tip of the transverse process of C7.

 

Option D. Vessels pass above the fascia (Correct): Blood vessels, including the subclavian vessels, pass above Sibson's fascia as they enter and exit the thoracic cavity. This fascia serves as a landmark for the placement of central venous catheters, as it delineates the boundary between the cervical and thoracic regions.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Sibson's fascia is not directly attached to the inner border of the 2nd rib. Instead, it is associated with the cervical pleura and extends superiorly to attach to the transverse process of the 7th cervical (C7) vertebra. It forms the outer boundary of the cervicothoracic (suprapleural) space.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most important determinant of malignant potential in the papillary type of renal tumor? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Size

 

The size of the tumor is the most important determinant of malignant potential in papillary renal tumors.

 

Renal tumors of the papillary type include:

 

  • Papillary adenoma of the kidney (</= 1.5 cm)
  • Papillary renal cell carcinoma (RCC) - greater than 1.5 cm

 

Small renal papillary growths are fairly common and are discovered by chance. One of the processes carried out during the evaluation of donor transplant kidneys is the ruling out of malignancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immunohistology: While useful for diagnostic and subtyping purposes, it is not the primary determinant of malignant potential. It helps identify the type of cells involved and the presence of specific markers.

 

Option C. Cytogenetics: Provides information on genetic abnormalities and can predict aggressiveness but is secondary to size in determining malignant potential.

 

Option D. Part of kidney involved: Although the location can affect treatment approaches and outcomes, it does not primarily determine whether a tumor is malignant; size is more predictive of malignancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In papillary renal tumors, the size greater than 1.5 cm is the most critical determinant in assessing malignancy, outweighing factors like immunohistology, cytogenetics, and part of the kidney involved in terms of initial evaluation.

questions.text: A fetus with intrauterine growth restriction was born prematurely with jaundice, hepatosplenomegaly, microcephaly, and diffuse petechiae at birth. A brain CT was done which revealed periventricular calcifications. What is the best method for the diagnosis of the etiological agent? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Urine examination

 

Based on the clinical presentation, it appears that congenital cytomegalovirus infection is a likely diagnosis. The most effective method for diagnosing the specific cause of the infection is by examining urine samples. In order to diagnose congenital CMV infection, the best specimens to use for culture are urine and saliva, while the best specimens for PCR testing are saliva and cord blood.

 

Clinical features:

 

  1. Intrauterine growth retardation (IUGR)
  2. Prematurity
  3. Hepatosplenomegaly
  4. Jaundice
  5. Blueberry-muffin-like rash
  6. Thrombocytopenia, purpura
  7. Microcephaly,
  8. Intracranial calcifications
  9. Chorioretinitis
  10. Sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL)
  11. Mild increases in CSF protein.

 

Rx: Ganciclovir can limit hearing loss and improve the developmental outcome in symptomatically infected infants.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Liver biopsy: liver biopsy is the gold standard investigation of choice in Wilson disease.

 

Option C. Blood examination: Blood examination will not give us the diagnostic results.

 

Option D. CSF examination: CSF examination is useful in cases of meningitis or neonatal sepsis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Urine examination is the preferred diagnostic method for identifying congenital cytomegalovirus infection, which typically presents with symptoms such as intrauterine growth restriction, prematurity, hepatosplenomegaly, jaundice, microcephaly, diffuse petechiae, and periventricular calcifications.

questions.text: Multiple abscesses with discharging sinuses, demonstrating sulphur granules in pus, are caused by:  (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Actinomyces

 

Multiple abscesses with discharging sinuses, demonstrating sulfur granules in pus, are characteristic of actinomycosis caused by Actinomyces.

 

Actinomycosis is a chronic granulomatous infection characterized by indurated swellings mainly in the connective tissue with suppuration and discharge of sulfur granules. The most common causative agent is Actinomyces israelli

 

Various clinical forms of actinomycosis include cervicofacial, thoracic, abdominal, and pelvic actinomycosis.

 

Among them, actinomycosis most commonly occurs as oral-cervicofacial form presenting as a soft tissue swelling, abscess, or mass lesion involving the angle of the jaw.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nocardia: Incorrect, although Nocardia can also cause cutaneous infections with abscess and sinus formation, it does not produce sulfur granules.

 

Option C. Salmonella: Incorrect, known primarily for causing gastrointestinal infections rather than chronic skin and soft tissue infections.

 

Option D. Tularemia: Incorrect, although it can cause ulceroglandular disease with skin ulcers and lymphadenopathy, it does not produce sulfur granules.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Actinomycosis, particularly its cervicofacial form, is characterized by the formation of abscesses that discharge pus containing sulfur granules. This hallmark feature helps in diagnosing the disease, which requires prolonged antibiotic therapy due to its chronic and indurative nature.

questions.text: The following parameter in ALL indicate a poor prognosis: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Age > 10 years

 

Age >10 years indicates a poor prognosis in ALL.

 

Leukocyte count <50,000/mm, hyperdiploidy, trisomy of chromosomes 4, 10, 17 indicate a better prognosis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL), prognostic factors such as age greater than 10 years, WBC count greater than 200,000/mm^3, male gender, presence of CNS involvement, and certain cytogenetic abnormalities such as t(9;22) or t(4;11) are associated with a poorer prognosis compared to their counterparts.

questions.text: All of the following cranial nerve nuclei are part of special visceral afferent column except?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Trochlear nerve

 

The trochlear nerve nucleus belongs to the general somatic efferent column (GSE), not the special visceral afferent column. Special visceral afferent refers to sensory information associated with taste and smell.

 

The trochlear nerve is a motor nerve that innervates the orbit's superior oblique muscle.

 

The neurons of the general somatic efferent (GSE) column innervate the extrinsic ocular and tongue muscles (III, IV, VI, and XII cranial nerves).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Facial Nerve (CN VII):

 

  • Sensory Component: The facial nerve carries special visceral afferent fibers responsible for taste sensation from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue (via the chorda tympani branch).
  • Motor Component: The facial nerve also contains motor fibers responsible for controlling the muscles of facial expression.

 

Option C. Vagus Nerve (CN X):

 

  • Sensory Component: The vagus nerve carries special visceral afferent fibers responsible for taste sensation from the epiglottis and the root of the tongue.
  • Motor Component: The vagus nerve has a wide range of motor functions, including control of the muscles involved in swallowing and vocalization, as well as autonomic functions.

 

Option D. Glossopharyngeal Nerve (CN IX):

 

  • Sensory Component: The glossopharyngeal nerve carries special visceral afferent fibers responsible for taste sensation from the posterior one-third of the tongue and sensory input from the oropharynx.
  • Motor Component: It also has motor functions, including control of certain muscles involved in swallowing.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Cytotoxic and expired medications are appropriately discarded through: [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Incineration

 

  • Expired and cytotoxic drugs should be disposed of using specific methods, such as incineration, encapsulation, or plasma pyrolysis, and should be returned to the manufacturer if possible.
  • Other medications can also be disposed of using similar methods.
  • The use of yellow bags is common for hazardous waste to ensure proper handling and disposal by trained personnel.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: All of the following structure pass through the aortic opening of diaphragm except? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Vagal trunk

 

The vagal trunk does not pass through the aortic opening of the diaphragm.

 

It passes through the esophageal opening at the level of T10 vertebra.

 

The vagal trunks refer to the vagus nerves, specifically the right and left vagus nerves (cranial nerves X). These nerves are responsible for various functions in the body, including regulating heart rate, gastrointestinal activity, and respiratory functions. While the vagus nerves do extend into the thoracic cavity, they do not pass through the aortic opening of the diaphragm. Instead, they enter the abdomen separately.

 

 

 

The aortic opening of the diaphragm is an anatomical structure that allows certain structures to pass between the thoracic and abdominal cavities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aorta: It passes through the aortic opening of the diaphragm as it descends from the thoracic cavity (descending aorta) into the abdominal cavity (abdominal aorta). This is a significant passage, as it allows the aorta to continue its course into the abdomen.

 

Option B. Azygous Vein: It drains blood from the posterior thoracic and abdominal walls. It ascends through the aortic opening of the diaphragm to enter the superior vena cava. This allows for the return of blood from the posterior part of the body to the superior vena cava and then into the right atrium of the heart.

 

Option C. Thoracic Duct: It is responsible for draining lymph from the lower half of the body and the left upper half of the body. It also passes through the aortic opening of the diaphragm to enter the thoracic cavity and eventually drain into the venous circulation.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following would be prescribed for simple myopic astigmatism?  (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. -1.00 DC X 180 degree

 

  • The correct prescription for simple myopic astigmatism is -1.00 DC × 180 degrees.
  • Simple myopic astigmatism means that one principal meridian of the eye is in focus on the retina, while the other principal meridian is in front of the retina.
  • There are three components to the prescription of glasses for astigmatism: 
    1. The power of the spherical component (convex or concave dioptre sphere),
    2. The power of the cylinder (convex or concave dioptre cylinder),
    3. The axis (orientation) of the cylinder.

 

For example: -1.00 DC × 180 degree

 

This prescription indicates that the individual has simple astigmatism, which means one meridian of the eye is in focus while the other is not. In this case, the unfocused meridian is myopic (nearsighted) and requires correction with a concave cylinder lens. The strength of the cylinder lens is -1.00 diopters (DC). The axis of the cylinder is oriented at 180 degrees, which represents the meridian that is most affected by astigmatism.

 

Types of astigmatism:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. +1.00 DS: This represents a convex spherical lens for hypermetropia (farsightedness) and is not used for astigmatism correction.

 

Option C. -1.00 DS: This represents a concave spherical lens for simple myopia (nearsightedness) but does not correct astigmatism.

 

Option D. -1.00 DS -1.00 DC X 180 degree: This represents a prescription for compound myopic astigmatism, where both meridians are myopic, one corrected by the spherical component and the other by the cylindrical component.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Simple myopic astigmatism requires correction with a cylindrical lens that corrects the myopic meridian, typically specified with the cylinder power and the axis. The correct prescription for simple myopic astigmatism in this case is -1.00 DC X 180 degrees.

questions.text: In extroversion, what is the yoke muscle of the right lateral rectus muscle? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Left medial rectus

 

The yoke muscle of the right LR is the left MR.

 

Yoke muscles are the primary muscles in each eye that accomplish a given version (eg, for right gaze, the right lateral rectus and left medial rectus muscles).

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Left superior oblique: This muscle is involved in intorsion, depression, and abduction of the left eye, not in coordinating rightward gaze with the right lateral rectus.

 

Option C. Left inferior rectus: This muscle is responsible for depression and adduction of the left eye, not relevant to the rightward gaze.

 

Option D. Left superior rectus: This muscle is involved in elevation and intorsion of the left eye, not in the horizontal movement to the right.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In extroversion (rightward gaze), the yoke muscle for the right lateral rectus (which abducts the right eye) is the left medial rectus (which adducts the left eye), enabling coordinated horizontal movement.

choices.text: It can cause scleroderma which makes injecting insulin difficult.
It can increase the metabolism of oral hypoglycemic drugs.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with hypertriglyceridemia is considered for niacin therapy. She is a known diabetic managed adequately with sugars well under control. Why should niacin be used cautiously in this patient?( NEET PG 2018 )
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It can cause hyperglycemia.

 

  • Niacin has been associated with an increase in blood glucose levels, which can lead to hyperglycemia. This effect can be concerning for individuals with diabetes, especially if their blood sugar levels are well-controlled. Therefore, caution is needed when considering niacin therapy in diabetic patients to prevent the risk of elevated blood sugar levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. It can cause scleroderma which makes injecting insulin difficult: There is no known direct association between niacin therapy and scleroderma. Scleroderma is a separate medical condition characterized by the hardening and tightening of the skin and connective tissues. It is not a common side effect of niacin therapy.

 

Option C. It can increase the metabolism of oral hypoglycemic drugs: Niacin is not typically known to increase the metabolism of oral hypoglycemic drugs. However, it is essential for diabetic patients to monitor their blood sugar levels closely when starting niacin therapy, as it may interact with their existing medications.

 

Option D. It can cause hypoglycemia: Niacin is not known to cause hypoglycemia. In fact, the primary concern with niacin therapy in diabetic patients is the potential for elevated blood sugar levels (hyperglycemia).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Niacin can cause increase in blood sugar levels by inducing insulin resistance and decreasing glucose-stimulated insulin secretion. Hence, it should be used cautiously in diabetic patients. When prescribed, weekly monitoring of blood sugars is required.

questions.text: Which fontanelle is the last to close during normal skull development? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Anterior

 

The anterior fontanelle (Bregma) is the largest and most prominent fontanelle on a baby's skull.

 

The anterior fontanelle is the last fontanelle to close. It closes at around 18-24 months of age.

 

These openings in the skull allow for flexibility during childbirth and rapid brain growth during infancy. Fontanelles gradually close as the bones of the skull grow and fuse.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Posterior Fontanelle (Lambda):

 

  • The posterior fontanelle is located at the junction of the occipital and parietal bones of the skull. Unlike the anterior fontanelle, the posterior fontanelle is smaller and less noticeable.
  • The posterior fontanelle usually closes within the first few months of life.

 

Option C. Occipital Fontanelle (Sphenoidal):

 

  • The term "occipital fontanelle" is less commonly used, and it may refer to a small soft spot located at the back of the head, near the occipital bone. This area is generally less significant than the anterior and posterior fontanelles and closes early in infancy.

 

Option D. Mastoid Fontanelle:

 

  • The term "mastoid fontanelle" is not commonly used in the context of fontanelles on a baby's skull.
  • The mastoid region of the skull is a bony area located behind the ear, and it does not typically have a soft spot or fontanelle.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Identify the structure marked by the arrow?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Superior mesenteric vein

 

The structure shown by the arrow is SMV.

 

SMV is on the right, while SMA is on the left (Remember "SMAL").

 

They can be identified by the uncinate process at this level

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Superior Mesenteric Vein can be distinguished on a CT scan by its position to the right of the Superior Mesenteric Artery, and its relation to the uncinate process. Remembering "SMAL" (Superior Mesenteric Artery Left, Superior Mesenteric Vein Right) can aid in identification during diagnostic imaging.

choices.text: Follows autosomal dominant mode of inheritance

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding ataxia-telangiectasia? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Follows autosomal dominant mode inheritance

 

The mode of inheritance in ataxia-telangiectasia is autosomal recessive.

 

Ataxia telangiectasia:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ataxia-telangiectasia is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the ATM gene on chromosome 11, characterized by defective DNA repair, immunodeficiency, progressive neurological degeneration, and increased risk of malignancies.

choices.text: ANOVA is an example of a non-parametric test
It is used for skewed distributions
It involves the assumption that the data has a normal distribution
It cannot be used for small sample sizes

questions.text: Which of the following is true for non-parametric tests? [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) It is used for skewed distributions 

 

  • Non-parametric tests are statistical tests that do not require the data to be normally distributed or have a specific population parameter, such as the mean or variance, assumed beforehand. They are typically used when the data are not normally distributed, have outliers, or when the sample size is small.
  • Some examples of non-parametric tests include the Wilcoxon rank-sum test, Kruskal-Wallis test, and Mann-Whitney U test.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ANOVA is an example of a non-parametric test:  Is incorrect because ANOVA is a parametric test used to compare the means of two or more groups.

 

Option C. It involves the assumption that the data has a normal distribution: Is incorrect because non-parametric tests do not assume that the data has a normal distribution.

 

Option D. It cannot be used for small sample sizes: Is also incorrect because non-parametric tests can be used for small sample sizes. In fact, they are often preferred over parametric tests for small sample sizes or when the assumptions of parametric tests are violated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Non-parametric tests are valuable statistical tools when dealing with skewed distributions or when the assumptions of parametric tests (like normal distribution) are not met. They provide robustness against the distribution shape of the data and are effective in handling smaller sample sizes and outliers.

choices.text: Antibiotics are the only effective treatment for a Crohn's mass.
Symptomatic relapse following surgery is not related to the presence of disease during resection.
Crohn's disease most commonly involves the proximal ileum.
Continuous lesions observed during endoscopic examination are diagnostic of Crohn's disease.

questions.text: Which of these is a true statement about Crohn’s disease?( NEET PG 2018 )
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Symptomatic relapse following surgery is not related to the presence of disease during resection

 

Symptomatic relapse following surgery is not related to the presence of disease during resection. The course of the disease after surgery is unpredictable since surgery does not cure Crohn's disease. The recurrence of Crohn's disease after surgery is common, and the likelihood of relapse may depend on the extent of disease involvement, the type of surgery performed, and other individual factors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Antibiotics are not the only effective treatment for a Crohn's mass. Treatment options for Crohn's disease depend on the severity of the disease and may include anti-inflammatory drugs, immunosuppressants, and biologic agents, in addition to antibiotics.

 

Option C. The distal ileum is a common site of involvement in Crohn's disease, but the disease can affect any part of the digestive tract from the mouth to the anus. In addition to the ileum, other common sites of involvement include the colon, and perianal region.

 

Option D. The characteristic features of Crohn's disease on endoscopy include skip lesions, areas of inflammation, ulcers, and strictures, which may be continuous or segmental in nature.

 

Educational Objective:


Surgical resection in Crohn's disease does not cure the condition, and symptomatic relapse can occur independently of the presence of disease at the resection margins.

questions.text: What is the diagnostic test of choice for HIV in a baby born to an HIV-infected mother? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. HIV DNA PCR
 

Maternal antibodies transferred passively to the infant may persist 9-18 months and hence ELISA/antibody tests positivity would indicate possible exposure to HIV.

 

Currently NACO recommends HIV-TNA PCR (Total nucleic acid = pro-viral DNA + RNA) which has Sensitivity of 99% and Specificity of 98% in infants < 18 months of age.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. DBS (Dried blood sample) is recommended and not CORD BLOOD (as it contains maternal blood contamination).

 

Option C. Western blot is not recommended by NACO for the diagnosis of HIV.

 

Option D. ELISA based test detects antibodies, however, maternal transmission occurs in infants trans placentally and hence cannot help in diagnosis of active disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For infants born to HIV-infected mothers, HIV DNA PCR is the preferred diagnostic test because it detects viral DNA directly, avoiding the pitfalls of tests that detect antibodies, which may not distinguish between maternal antibodies and those produced by the infant itself.

 

Reference: NACO 2021 HIV Care and treatment guidelines Page 185

questions.text: Seman's squeeze technique is used for which of the following conditions?( NEET PG 2018 )
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Premature ejaculation

 

Seman's squeeze technique is a behavioral therapy method used to treat premature ejaculation. It involves the man or his partner squeezing the tip of the penis for several seconds right before ejaculation is expected. This helps in delaying ejaculation. The other options do not involve the use of this technique.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Retrograde ejaculation: Retrograde ejaculation refers to the backward flow of semen into the bladder instead of out of the penis.

 

Option B. Erectile dysfunction: Erectile dysfunction is the inability to achieve or maintain an erection suitable for intercourse. 

 

Most successful psychotherapy for erectile dysfunction is dual-sex therapy by Masters and Johnson.

 

Option D. Painful ejaculation: Painful ejaculation is pain felt during or after ejaculation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Seman's squeeze technique is a non-pharmacological method used to delay ejaculation in men with premature ejaculation. Here, when the man gets the feeling of impending ejaculation, the sex is stopped for some time and once excitement has decreased, it is restarted. Hence, it is also known as stop-start technique. Another non-pharmacological treatment includes squeeze technique, where the female partner squeezes the coronal ridge of the glans, when the man gets the feeling of impending ejaculation.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 586.

questions.text: Which of the following can grow in an acidic pH? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lactobacilli

 

Among the given options, lactobacilli is the one that can grow in an acidic pH.

 

It is a gram-positive, facultatively anaerobic, non-motile, non-spore-forming bacterium. Lactobacillus derives lactic acid from glucose, creating an acidic environment and thus can grow in an acidic medium. It is found in the vagina as part of its normal microbiota.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vibrio: Incorrect, as Vibrio species typically prefer alkaline conditions, such as those found in seawater.

 

Option C. Salmonella: Incorrect, Salmonella bacteria prefer a neutral to slightly acidic environment but do not thrive in highly acidic conditions.

 

Option D. Shigella: Incorrect, Shigella, like Salmonella, is more adapted to neutral or slightly acidic environments and does not generally grow well in highly acidic conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lactobacilli's ability to grow in acidic environments is crucial for their role in maintaining healthy microbial flora in certain parts of the human body, such as the vagina, and is also exploited in the fermentation of various food products.

questions.text: The antiviral drug having dual antiviral activity against HIV and HBV is? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Emtricitabine

 

Emtricitabine is a NRTI that has dual action against both HIV and Hepatitis B. The drugs having activity against both HIV and HBV are:

 

L: Lamivudine

 

E: Emtricitabine


T: Tenofovir
 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Enfuvirtide: Enfuvirtide is an entry inhibitor used exclusively for HIV. It works by preventing the HIV virus from entering human immune cells but does not have activity against HBV.

 

Option B. Abacavir: Abacavir is an NRTI used for HIV treatment. While it is effective against HIV, it does not have activity against HBV.

 

Option D. Ritonavir: Ritonavir is a protease inhibitor used in the treatment of HIV. It is primarily used to boost the levels of other protease inhibitors through its inhibition of the cytochrome P450 3A4 enzyme. Ritonavir does not have activity against HBV.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Emtricitabine is an antiviral drug with dual activity against both HIV and HBV, making it a valuable component in the treatment of patients co-infected with these viruses. Other drugs with dual activity include lamivudine and tenofovir.

choices.text: Occurs gradually over a period of time

questions.text: Which of the following features is more in favor of delirium? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fluctuating course

 

Delirium is characterized by an acute onset and a fluctuating course, often varying in severity throughout the day.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Occurs gradually over a period of time: This is more suggestive of dementia rather than delirium.

 

Option C. Preserved consciousness: The characteristic feature of delirium is a disturbance in consciousness and attention. Therefore, this option is incorrect.

 

Option D. Commonly associated with auditory hallucinations: While hallucinations can be present in delirium, they aren't specific to it. Schizophrenia or other psychotic disorders might also present with auditory hallucinations.

 

Therefore, a fluctuating course is the most suggestive of delirium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Delirium is the most common organic mental disorder. It has an acute onset with a fluctuating course. It is most commonly seen in elderly population. It is characterized by disturbed consciousness, and altered attention. Disturbances of sleep-wake cycle, evening worsening of symptoms (sundowning), and floccillations can be seen.

 

 

Reference: A Short Textbook osf Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 22.

questions.text: Which organ is the earliest to undergo putrefaction from the given options? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Brain

 

Among the given options, the brain is the first organ to undergo putrefaction. The process of putrefaction involves the decomposition of body tissues and follows a specific order from early to late stages.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Heart: The heart putrefies after the brain but before the kidneys.

 

Option C. Kidney: The kidneys putrefy after the heart.

 

Option D. Prostate: The prostate putrefies very late in the process, even after the kidneys.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The order of organ putrefaction (early to late) is as follows:

 

  1. Larynx and trachea
  2. Liver and lungs
  3. Brain
  4. Heart
  5. Kidney
  6. Prostate and Non Gravid uterus
  7. Skin, muscle, tendons
  8. Bones and teeth

 

Prostate and Non gravid uterus are organs which putrefy very late. The gravid uterus putrefies earlier.

 

Mnemonic: LBHK

 

L for larynx, liver, lungs, B for brain H for Heart, K for Kidney

questions.text: According to the berlin definition, moderate ARDS is characterized by all, except: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. PaO2/FiO2 ratio 200-300 mm/Hg

 

Option A:

 

The Berlin definition of Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS) classifies the severity based on the PaO2/FiO2 ratio assessed under specific conditions of oxygenation support. According to this definition, a PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 200-300 mmHg characterizes mild ARDS, not moderate ARDS. Moderate ARDS is defined by a PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 100-200 mm/Hg when assessed with at least 5 cm of water Positive End-Expiratory Pressure (PEEP).

 

Explanation:
 

Option B. Bilateral interstitial infiltrates: This is correct and consistent with all classifications of ARDS, which require bilateral opacities on imaging, either from chest radiographs or CT, indicative of pulmonary edema not fully explained by cardiac failure or fluid overload.

 

Option C. Symptom onset within a week: True for the Berlin definition, which stipulates that ARDS must occur within 7 days of a known clinical insult or new or worsening respiratory symptoms.

 

Option D. No cardiac failure on echocardiography: Also true according to the Berlin definition, as the pulmonary edema should not be fully explained by cardiac failure or fluid overload, thus necessitating the exclusion of cardiac failure through echocardiography.

 

Educational Objective:

 

2012 Berlin Definition:

 

  1. Onset within 7 days after a known clinical insult or new or worsening respiratory symptoms
  2. B/L opacities (Alveolar/Interstitial that are "consistent with pulmonary edema" on chest radiographs or chest CT)
  3. Minimum PEEP setting or CPAP, 5 cm of water.

 

PaO2: FiO2 assessed on invasive mechanical ventilation (CPAP criterion used for the diagnosis of mild ARDS).

 

Categorization of ARDS severity (on the basis of FiO2):

 

  1. Mild: 200-300
  2. Moderate: 100-200
  3. Severe: <100

 

In resource limited settings Kigali Modifications was proposed (2016):

 

  1. Bilateral opacities could be documented by either ultrasonography or chest radiograph.
  2. Oxygenation criteria: pulse oximetry oxygen saturation (SpO2)/FiO2 ratio ≤ 315 without the requirement for PEEP.

 

Reference - Harrison/Respiratory Failure/Chap 301

questions.text: Nude mice are not resistant to xenograft due to the absence of? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) T cell

 

Nude mice are not resistant to xenograft due to absence of T cell.

 

A xenograft is a tissue graft or organ transplant from a donor of a different species.

 

Nude mice lack body hair, hence the name. They lack a thymus and thus cannot generate mature T lymphocytes. The absence of T-lymphocytes makes them unable to mount adaptive immune responses requiring helper T cells and cytotoxic T cells. The absence of functioning T cells also prevents the rejection of allografts & xenografts.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. B cell: Incorrect because the primary immunodeficiency in nude mice relates to T cells, not B cells. While B cells are essential for antibody production, their presence does not compensate for the lack of T cell-mediated immunity necessary for xenograft rejection.

 

Option C. Both B and T cell: Incorrect as nude mice specifically lack T cells due to the absence of a thymus, while B cell function remains intact.

 

Option D. INK cell: Incorrect because the term should likely refer to "NK cells" (natural killer cells), which are not the primary reason for the lack of xenograft rejection in nude mice. NK cells can participate in innate immune responses but do not compensate for the lack of adaptive immune responses mediated by T cells in this context.

 

Educational Objective:


Nude mice lack a thymus, resulting in a deficiency of mature T cells, which are essential for rejecting xenografts. This highlights the crucial role of T cells in adaptive immune responses and graft rejection.

questions.text: Nuclear signaling pathways are all except:( NEET PG 2018 )
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Rat proteins

 

Explanation

 

Rat proteins are not nuclear signaling pathways. Recombinant rat IN- is a bioactive protein used in cell culture applications.

 

Other Options:

 

Nuclear signaling pathways involve a variety of molecules and proteins that are involved in transmitting signals from the cell surface to the nucleus of the cell.

 

Option A. Caveolins are integral membrane proteins that are involved in the formation of caveolae, which are small invaginations in the plasma membrane that are involved in signal transduction.

 

Option B. NF-kB is a transcription factor that is involved in the regulation of genes involved in immune response, inflammation, and cell survival.

 

Option C. Importins are proteins that are involved in the transport of proteins into the nucleus of the cell. They bind to nuclear localization signals on proteins and facilitate their transport into the nucleus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nuclear signaling pathways are complex systems involving proteins that either directly regulate gene expression or facilitate the transport of molecules into the nucleus.

questions.text: A 19-year-old youth was brought the casualty with a black eye following a fist fight. Which area of the orbit is most likely to have been fractured? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Floor

 

  • The most common site of an orbital blowout fracture is the floor of the orbit.
  • BLOW-out fractures involve LOW wall (means inferior wall or floor of orbit).
  • The floor consists of three bones: the zygomatic, maxillary, and palatine bones. The posteromedial portion of the maxillary bone is relatively weak and may be involved in a "blowout" fracture.
  • Clinical features:
  • Subconjunctival hemorrhage.
  • Subcutaneous emphysema affecting the eyelids (commoner with medial wall fractures)
  • Enophthalmus (inward displacement of eyeball) and mechanical ptosis
  • Infraorbital nerve anaesthesia
  • Double diplopia (diplopia in both upwards as well as downwards gaze)
  • Positive “forced duction test”
  • Management:
  • X ray (Waters view) and CT-Scan of orbit show tear drop sign.
  • Conservative management may be useful in a good number of patients.
  • However, surgical intervention if required should be done about 2 weeks of injury with synthetic material like supramide, teflon or silicon.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Medial wall: Less commonly involved in isolated blowout fractures; can be associated with subcutaneous emphysema.

 

Option B. Lateral wall: The strongest wall of the orbit and less likely to fracture in isolated blunt trauma.

 

Option C. Roof: More common in children due to its thinness but less common overall compared to the floor in blowout fractures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The floor of the orbit is the most likely site of fracture in cases of orbital blowout fractures resulting from blunt trauma, such as a fist fight. Key clinical features include enophthalmos, infraorbital nerve anesthesia, and diplopia. Imaging with X-rays and CT scans are crucial for diagnosis and surgical intervention may be required for severe cases.

questions.text: Cowden syndrome is associated with mutation in: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) PTEN

 

Cowden syndrome is a genetic disorder characterized by multiple tumor-like growths and an increased risk of certain cancers. It is associated with mutations in the PTEN gene, a tumor suppressor gene. This mutation leads to dysregulated cell growth and survival, contributing to the development of benign and malignant tumors, particularly in the breast, thyroid, and endometrium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. WT1: Associated with Wilms' tumor.

 

Option C. p53: Commonly mutated in various cancers but not specifically associated with Cowden syndrome.

 

Option D. Ras: Linked to a variety of cancers through different mechanisms but not directly to Cowden syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with a reddish, firm nodule on her chest that has not increased in size. The patient is concerned about the possibility of malignancy and undergoes a biopsy of the lesion. Histopathological examination of the biopsy specimen shows certain features that aid in the diagnosis. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Hemangioma

 

A hemangioma is a benign tumor formed by a collection of excess blood vessels.

 

The histopathological features of hemangioma include:

 

  • A well-circumscribed lesion composed of dilated, thin-walled blood vessels.
  • The endothelial cells lining the vessels are flattened and uniform, with minimal mitotic activity.
  • The vessels are often arranged in lobules, with stromal cells separating the lobules.
  • The stromal cells are composed of fibroblasts, myofibroblasts, and/or pericytes.

 

In cases of cavernous hemangiomas, the vessels are larger and more dilated than those in capillary hemangiomas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lipoma: A lipoma is a benign tumor of adipose (fat) tissue and typically presents as a soft, rubbery lump that can be moved with slight finger pressure. On histopathology, a lipoma will show mature fat cells that are uniform in size. They don't exhibit much cellular variability, and there are no vascular proliferations like those seen in a hemangioma.

 

Option B. Fibroadenoma: Fibroadenoma is a benign breast tumor. It's composed of glandular and fibrous tissue. On physical examination, it often feels like a small, rubbery lump that moves around easily within the breast tissue. Histologically, fibroadenomas show a combination of glandular breast tissue and stromal tissue. They are not typically found on the chest but rather within the breast tissue itself, and their histological appearance would not match the vascular features of a hemangioma.

 

Option C. Nevus: A nevus, commonly referred to as a mole, is a benign skin lesion that contains nevomelanocytes. Nevus cells can be found in the epidermis, dermis, or both. Histologically, it would show nests of melanocytes at the epidermal-dermal junction, and/or in the dermis, depending on the type of nevus. It wouldn't have the vascular structures seen in a hemangioma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hemangioma is a benign tumor formed by a collection of excess blood vessels, characterized histologically by well-circumscribed lesions composed of dilated, thin-walled blood vessels arranged in lobules.

choices.text: Pupils react but do not accommodate
Pupils accommodate but do not react

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient came with a history of unprotected sexual intercourse around 20 years ago following which he had developed genital ulcers. Now, he complains of neurological symptoms and visual disturbances. Which of the following will be seen on exposure of his pupils to light? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Pupils accommodate but do not react

 

  • The patient most likely contracted syphilis through unprotected sexual intercourse and later developed neurosyphilis as a consequence (neurological and visual disturbances).
  • Argyll-Robertson pupil, which is a condition characterized by intact accommodation reflex, but absent light reflex in the affected eye. (ARP-PRA)
  • Features of Argyll Robertson pupil (ARP) are bilateral small pupils with the following characteristics:
  1. Accommodation Reflex Present (ARP):  Pupillary constriction when looking at near objects.
  2. Light Reflex absent: Do not constrict when exposed to bright light (i.e., they do not react to light).
  • This is an example of light near dissociation.
  • Neurosyphilis is a manifestation of syphilis infection that affects the central nervous system, which occurs due to the invasion of the central nervous system by T. pallidum and can occur in any stage of syphilis.
  • Clinical features of neurosyphilis include:
    • Fleeting and repetitive lancinating pains, primarily in the legs.
    • Ataxia and gait disturbances due to loss of position sense.
    • Loss of reflexes in the legs.
    • Paraesthesia’s.
    • Bladder disturbances.
    • Acute abdominal pain with vomiting (visceral crisis).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pupils react but do not accommodate: This is not characteristic of any specific condition and does not describe Argyll Robertson pupil.

 

Option C. Pupils neither react nor accommodate: This indicates more widespread dysfunction of the pupillary muscles and is not specific for neurosyphilis.

 

Option D. Pupils react and accommodate: This describes normal pupillary function, which would not be expected in the context of the described symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Argyll Robertson pupil, characterized by pupils that accommodate but do not react to light, is a hallmark of neurosyphilis. This condition reflects damage to the central nervous system by Treponema pallidum, which affects both the neurological and visual systems.

questions.text: Congenital adrenal hyperplasia most commonly presents as: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Female pseudohermaphroditism

 

The most frequent enzyme deficiency leading to Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (CAH) is a 21-hydroxylase deficiency, which typically manifests as female pseudohermaphroditism. Female pseudohermaphroditism refers to the presentation of a genotypically normal female (46, XX) who has external genitalia that resembles those of a male. The female is virilized, which means there is a masculinization of the body, and this virilization is usually evident at birth in females and within the first 2 to 3 years of life in males.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Male pseudohermaphroditism: Male pseudohermaphroditism is seen in CAH due to 17a-hydroxylase deficiency due to incomplete virilization.

 

Option C. True hermaphroditism: True hermaphroditism is presently referred to as an ovotesticular disorder of sex development (DSD). Here, both ovarian and testicular tissue is present. It is not due to CAH.

 

Option D. 46 XY intersex: 46 XY intersex (now called 46 XY DSD) has under virilization of genitalia. Adrenal causes include lipoid adrenal hyperplasia, 33-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase deficiency, 17-Hydroxylase/17,20-Lyase deficiency, and not 21 hydroxylase deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congenital adrenal hyperplasia, most commonly due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency, typically presents as female pseudohermaphroditism, characterized by virilized genitalia in genotypic females (46, XX) at birth.

questions.text: What is 'mental retardation' now called according to the American Psychiatric Association in its revision of DSM-5? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Intellectual disability

 

The term "mental retardation" has historically been used in clinical and diagnostic settings, but it has now been largely replaced due to its potential for stigmatization and pejorative connotations. In the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, Fifth Edition (DSM-5) by the American Psychiatric Association, the term "mental retardation" has been updated to: Intellectual disability (intellectual developmental disorder). This term is more respectful and emphasizes the abilities of the individual, rather than just their limitations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Feeble mindedness and option B. Mental subnormality are outdated and non-specific terms that were used in the past.

 

Option D. Intellectually challenged is a non-clinical term that may be used colloquially to describe someone with intellectual disabilities in a more respectful manner.

 

Educational Objective:

 

It's essential to understand that the term "mental retardation" is now outdated and has been replaced with "intellectual disability" in clinical settings, especially according to DSM-5, to ensure respectful and non-stigmatizing communication.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 1118-1119.

questions.text: What is your diagnosis? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Becker's naevus

 

The given image shows Becker's naevus.

 

  • The condition in question is an epidermal melanocytic nevus, characterized by the clustering of melanocytes in the epidermis.
  • It is commonly hairy and tends to appear during adolescence when there is heightened sensitivity to androgens, especially in areas like the outer arms, scapular region, and chest.

 

A triad of features can be seen:

 

  1. Hypertrichosis
  2. Acne
  3. Brownish Hyperpigmentation

 

Other Options:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Becker's naevus is a patchy, hyperpigmented lesion that often develops during adolescence and may include hypertrichosis, distinguishing it from congenital conditions such as Mongolian spots, Naevus of Ito, and congenital melanocytic naevi.

 

 

Reference: Bolognia 4th edition, chapter 112, page no 2232

Question Level – EASY 

Question Id-7443 Unique Key-Q6167342

questions.text: Which of the following conditions can be treated with pirenzepine? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Peptic ulcer disease

 

The M1 muscarinic receptors in the stomach increase the acid secretion. Pirenzepine is an M1 blocker, which can help in reducing the acid secretion and thereby was used in the treatment of peptic ulcer disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Asthma: Asthma is typically treated with bronchodilators (e.g., beta-agonists) and anti-inflammatory drugs (e.g., corticosteroids). Pirenzepine is not used in the treatment of asthma.

 

Option C. Glaucoma: Glaucoma is often treated with medications that reduce intraocular pressure, such as beta-blockers, prostaglandin analogs, or carbonic anhydrase inhibitors. Pirenzepine is not indicated for the treatment of glaucoma.

 

Option D. Hypertension: Hypertension is treated with a variety of medications including diuretics, ACE inhibitors, beta-blockers, calcium channel blockers, and others. Pirenzepine is not used in the management of hypertension.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pirenzepine is an M1 muscarinic receptor antagonist that reduces gastric acid secretion and is used in the treatment of peptic ulcer disease. It is not indicated for conditions such as asthma, glaucoma, or hypertension.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presented with a noticeable swelling in his scrotum. After careful evaluation, a decision was made to perform an orchidectomy. The histopathological examination of the tissue reveals the following findings. Based on these findings which of the following diagnoses best describes the patient's condition? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Seminoma

 

  • Morphological - well-circumscribed, pale, gray-white, fleshy, homogenous mass, with a lobulated cut surface, usually devoid of hemorrhage or necrosis.
  • Sheets of large, uniform, round or polygonal cells with clear cytoplasm and distinct cell borders.
  • Large central nuclei with prominent nucleoli.
  • Minimal mitotic activity and no or few infiltrating lymphocytes or Syncytiotrophoblast.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Yolk-sac tumor:

  • Morphological - Yolk-sac tumor has a yellowish-white, mucinous appearance.
  • Microscopic features include Schiller-Duval bodies (central vessel surrounded by tumor cells), which resemble a yolk sac.
  • Tumor cells have clear to eosinophilic cytoplasm with small round nuclei and frequent mitotic figures.

 

Option C. Embryonal cell carcinoma:

  • Morphological - Embryonal cell carcinoma appears variegated with foci of hemorrhage or necrosis.
  • Composed of solid sheets or nests of primitive, undifferentiated cells.
  • Cells are variable in size and shape, with a high nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio and frequent mitotic figures.

 

Option D. Teratoma:

  • Morphological - Teratomas also have a variegated appearance but have cysts reflecting the multiplicity of tissue types.
  • Composed of multiple germ layers, including ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm.
  • May contain a variety of tissues, including skin, hair, bone, cartilage, and neural tissue.
  • Immature teratomas may have undifferentiated, primitive neural or mesenchymal tissue.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Seminoma is a type of germ cell tumor characterized by large, uniform, polygonal cells with clear cytoplasm, distinct cell borders, and prominent central nucleoli, often presenting as a well-circumscribed, gray-white, fleshy mass without hemorrhage or necrosis.

choices.text: Dysplasia of the sphenoidal and tibial bone

questions.text: Which one of the following is not included in the criteria for neurofibromatosis 1? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acoustic neuromas 

 

In neurofibromatosis 1 (NF1), two or more of the following clinical manifestations are present:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acoustic neuromas are not a diagnostic criterion for Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF1); they are typically associated with Neurofibromatosis Type 2 (NF2). The diagnostic criteria for NF1 include the presence of café-au-lait macules, axillary or inguinal freckling, Lisch nodules, neurofibromas, sphenoid dysplasia, optic gliomas, and a first-degree relative with NF1.

questions.text: Which of the following is the predominant pathogen to infect the renal transplant recipients in the period around 1 to 4 months following the transplantation? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cytomegalovirus

 

The predominant pathogen to infect the renal transplant recipients in the period around 1 to 4 months following the transplantation is cytomegalovirus (CMV).

 

The most common CMV presentation in kidney transplant patients is fever (most common), leukopenia, hepatosplenomegaly, myalgia, and arthralgia.

 

JC virus, BK virus, and Epstein-Barr virus also have the propensity to cause infections during this period, but in lesser frequencies than CMV.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. JC virus: Incorrect, while JC virus can cause infections in transplant recipients, its occurrence is less frequent compared to CMV during this specific post-transplant period.

 

Option C. BK virus: Incorrect, although BK virus is a concern in renal transplant patients, particularly for its role in causing nephropathy, it is not as predominant as CMV in the early months following transplantation.

 

Option D. Epstein-Barr virus: Incorrect, Epstein-Barr virus also poses a risk for post-transplant lymphoproliferative disorders in transplant recipients, but it is less commonly the primary pathogen within the first few months post-transplant compared to CMV.

 

Educational Objective:


Cytomegalovirus is the leading cause of infection in renal transplant recipients during the first four months post-transplantation, showcasing the importance of monitoring and managing CMV to prevent its common presentations and complications in this vulnerable period.

choices.text: Ubiquitination of proteins
Protein modification
Protein folding
Protein cleavage

questions.text: What do chaperones assist in?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Protein folding

 

Option C. Protein folding

 

  • True. Chaperones play a crucial role in assisting proteins in achieving their correct three-dimensional folded structure. They help prevent misfolding, aggregation, or denaturation of proteins, ensuring their functional conformation.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Ubiquitination of proteins

 

  • False. Chaperones do not assist in ubiquitination of proteins. Ubiquitination is a process by which a small protein called ubiquitin is added to target proteins to mark them for degradation. Chaperones have a different role in protein biology.

 

Option B. Protein modification

 

  • Partially true. Chaperones are primarily involved in protein folding rather than direct protein modification. However, proper protein folding is essential for their biological function, and chaperones help ensure proteins achieve their correct three-dimensional structure during or after synthesis.

 

Option D. Protein cleavage

 

  • False. Chaperones are not involved in protein cleavage. Protein cleavage typically refers to the enzymatic process of cutting proteins into smaller fragments, which is different from the role of chaperones in facilitating proper folding.

 

Educational objective:

 

Chaperones help to produce the correct spatial arrangement. Chaperones attach to nascent polypeptide chains and prevent wrong folding; so that folding is allowed only in the correct direction. They help in the assembly of tertiary and quaternary structure of proteins.

 

Examples of chaperones are a large family of proteins called heat shock proteins (HSPs). Any stress to the cell including heat, toxins, heavy metals, free radicals, radiation, bacteria, etc. will cause increased production of HSPs, and hence they are more correctly termed as stress proteins.

 

Improper protein folding may lead to prion diseases.

questions.text: Broca's area is located in which part of the cerebral cortex? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Inferior frontal gyrus

 

Broca's area is primarily located in the posterior part of the frontal lobe, specifically within the left hemisphere. It is divided into two regions: Brodmann area 44 (Broca's area proper) and Brodmann area 45 (Pars triangularis). This region is crucial for language production, including the ability to form grammatically correct sentences and articulate speech.

 

 

Broca's area is situated in the inferior frontal gyrus of the dominant cerebral hemisphere, which is typically the left hemisphere in right-handed individuals and a significant portion of left-handed individuals.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Superior Temporal Gyrus: While the superior temporal gyrus is involved in language processing, it is not the primary site for speech production or Broca's area. Instead, the superior temporal gyrus is associated with auditory processing and speech comprehension.

 

Areas present in superior temporal gyrus: 

 

Brodmann Area 41 (Primary Auditory Cortex) is primarily responsible for the initial processing of auditory information. It receives and processes auditory signals from the ears and is involved in basic sound perception.

 

Brodmann Area 42 (Auditory Association Cortex) is involved in higher-level auditory processing. It helps in recognizing complex auditory stimuli, such as speech, music, and environmental sounds

 

Option C. Angular Gyrus: The angular gyrus, located in the parietal lobe, is involved in various functions, including reading, writing, and language comprehension. It plays a role in translating visual information into language.

 

Areas present in angular gyrus is Brodmann Area 39. It is associated with processes like reading, writing, and language comprehension. It also plays a role in the integration of visual, auditory, and somatosensory information, contributing to our ability to understand and interpret the world around us.

 

Option D. Postcentral Gyrus: The postcentral gyrus is located in the parietal lobe and is primarily associated with sensory functions, particularly somatosensory processing. It is not directly involved in speech production or language processing. Brodmann Area 3, 1, and 2 (Primary Somatosensory Cortex): These areas together make up the primary somatosensory cortex, which is located in the postcentral gyrus. It is responsible for our ability to perceive sensations such as touch, pressure, temperature, and proprioception (awareness of body position).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Broca's area is situated in the inferior frontal gyrus.

 

  • Broca's motor speech area - (44,45) is located in the inferior frontal gyrus.
  • Wernicke's area - (22) is located in the superior temporal gyrus.

questions.text: What is the term for the probability of infection occurring in susceptible individuals after they come into contact with an infectious person during the incubation period? [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Secondary attack rate

 

Secondary Attack Rate (SAR): Is no. of exposed persons developing the disease within range of incubation period (IP), following exposure to the primary case

 

It is calculated by the following formula:

 

 

Primary case is excluded from both numerator & denominator

 

Secondary attack rate measures the communicability of the disease / Infectivity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Case fatality rate: This rate measures the proportion of individuals diagnosed with a particular disease who die from that disease within a specific period. It is a measure of the severity of the disease.

 

Option C. Primary attack rate: This rate refers to the proportion of the population that becomes ill after being exposed to an infectious agent for the first time. It does not specifically account for subsequent spread among contacts.

 

Option D. Tertiary attack rate: This term is not commonly used in epidemiology. It would imply further transmission beyond secondary contacts, but this is not a standard measure

 

Educational Objective:

 

The secondary attack rate is a crucial epidemiological measure for understanding the spread of infectious diseases among contacts of an initial case. It helps determine the infectivity and potential for outbreaks within a population.

questions.text: A patient presents with recurrent kidney stones. The microscopic examination of the urine specimen is shown below. Which of the following is not seen in the urine of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cysteine

 

  • Cystine is the oxidized dimer form of cysteine (two cysteine molecules joined by a disulfide bond).
  • Cystine, not cysteine, is excreted in urine and precipitates to form stones.
  • Therefore, cysteine is not typically found in the urine of cystinuric patients in significant amounts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Arginine: Arginine is an amino acid and is not typically associated with kidney stone formation. It is usually found in the urine.

 

Option B. Lysine: Lysine is another amino acid and is not commonly linked to kidney stone formation. It is typically present in the urine.

 

Option C. Cystine: Cystine is an amino acid that is known to form cystine stones, a type of kidney stone. Therefore, cystine can be found in the urine of patients with cystine stones.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cystinuria: Cystinuria is one of the inborn errors of metabolism included in the Garrod’s tetrad. It is an autosomal recessive condition.

 

The disorder is attributed to the deficiency in transport of amino acids Signs and symptoms include:

 

  1. Abnormal excretion of cystine and to a lesser extent lysine, ornithine and arginine. Hence the condition is also called Cystine-lysinuria.
  2. Crystalluria and calculi formation. In acidic pH, cystine crystals are formed in urine
  3. Obstructive uropathy, which may lead to renal insufficiency
  4. Cyanide-Nitroprusside Test is a screening test. Urine is made alkaline with ammonium hydroxide and sodium cyanide is added. Cystine, if present, is reduced to cysteine. Then add sodium nitroprusside to get a magenta-red colored complex. Specific aminoaciduria may be confirmed by chromatography.
  5. Treatment is to increase urinary volume by increasing fluid intake. Solubility of cystine is increased by alkalinization of urine by giving sodium bicarbonate.

questions.text: Which of the following is a primary skin lesion? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Purpura

 

Purpura is a primary skin lesion. It is a disorder that causes red or purple areas on the skin that do not blanch when pressure is applied. RBC extravasation into the skin is the reason for these red patches.

 

It occurs under the following circumstances:

 

  • Vasculitis
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Vitamin C deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Crust: A secondary lesion that forms when serum, blood, or other exudates dry on the skin surface.

 

Option B: Atrophy: A secondary lesion characterized by a thinning of any part of the skin due to loss of collagen, elastin, or fat.

 

Option D: Induration: A secondary change resulting in the hardening of the skin, often due to an inflammatory response or chronic disease affecting deeper layers like the dermis and subcutaneous tissue.

 

Additional Information

 

Primary lesions of the skin include:

 

  • Papule Plaque Nodule
  • Vesicle Bulla
  • Macule Patch
  • Pustule Abscess
  • Petechiae Purpura Ecchymosis
  • Wheal

 

Primary Lesion:

 

1. Flat Lesions (Neither raised Nor Depressed)

 

 

2. Circumscribed solid raised lesions

 

 

3. Clear fluid filled lesions

 

 

4. Pus filled lesions

 

 

5.  Wheal

 

 

6.  Extravasation of RBC→ Skin/Mucosa

 

 

Secondary lesions of the skin include:

 

  • Lichenification 
  • Atrophy
  • Ulcer
  • Erosion
  • Excoriation
  • Crust
  • Induration
  • Scar 
  • Fissure
  • Scale

 

Educational Objective:

 

Purpura is a primary skin lesion indicative of an underlying vascular or coagulation disorder, differentiating it from secondary skin lesions such as crusts, atrophy, and induration, which result from external factors or the progression of skin diseases is also crucial.

 

 

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 4 page no 4.10

Question Level – Intermediate

Question Id-7437 Unique Key-Q1311505

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of secondary PPH? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Placenta previa

 

Explanation:

 

Placenta previa is not a cause of secondary postpartum hemorrhage (PPH). It is primarily associated with antepartum hemorrhage (bleeding before delivery) and is a risk factor for primary PPH (occurring within the first 24 hours after childbirth).

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Retained cotyledon: Retained cotyledon can lead to secondary PPH due to retained placental fragments, causing continued uterine bleeding.

 

Option B. Endometritis: Endometritis, an infection of the uterine lining, can cause secondary PPH by leading to inflammation and impaired uterine contraction.

 

Option C. Placental polyp: A placental polyp, which is retained placental tissue that forms a growth, can cause secondary PPH through persistent bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Placenta previa is a cause of antepartum hemorrhage and primary postpartum hemorrhage but not secondary postpartum hemorrhage.

 

Ref: Page no 804, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition

questions.text: Fever occurs during inflammation due to all except: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Histamine 

 

Histamine is involved in the mediation of inflammatory vascular events rather than fever.

 

Fever is defined by an increase in body temperature of 1° to 4°C. It is a prominent manifestation of the acute-phase response, particularly when associated with infection.

 

Pyrogens are substances that cause fever. They can be either exogenous or endogenous.

 

  • Endogenous progens include IL-1, TNF, and prostaglandins.
  • Exogenous pyrogens are bacterial lipopolysaccharides that stimulate leukocytes to release endogenous progens (IL-1 and TNF)

 

Cytokines increase the activity of cyclooxygenases, which convert arachidonic acid into prostaglandins. These prostaglandins are produced in the hypothalamic vascular and perivascular cells. They stimulate the production of neurotransmitters in the hypothalamus, which raises the temperature setpoint. This is especially true of PGE2.

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. IL-1, B. Prostaglandins and C. TNF: These are all endogenous pyrogens that directly contribute to the fever response by influencing the temperature regulation in the hypothalamus and stimulating the production of prostaglandins that raise the body’s temperature setpoint.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Histamine is involved in mediating the local vascular effects of inflammation and not in the fever response, which is primarily driven by IL-1, TNF, and prostaglandins.

questions.text: Which drug is used for mass chemoprophylaxis for meningococcal meningitis? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ciprofloxacin

 

Ciprofloxacin is commonly used for mass chemoprophylaxis in cases of meningococcal meningitis, particularly among close contacts of an infected individual. It is effective in preventing the spread of Neisseria meningitidis, the bacterium responsible for meningococcal disease. Ciprofloxacin is preferred due to its broad-spectrum activity, ease of administration as a single-dose regimen, and good penetration into the cerebrospinal fluid.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Chloramphenicol: While used for treatment of meningococcal meningitis, it is not used for chemoprophylaxis.

 

Option C. Tetracycline: Not used in the prophylaxis or treatment of meningococcal meningitis.

 

Option D. Penicillin: Although used for treatment, penicillin is not typically used for prophylaxis against meningococcal meningitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ciprofloxacin, Rifampicin, Ceftriaxone is indicated in the chemoprophylaxis of meningococcal meningitis for close contacts to prevent secondary cases.

 

Ceftriaxone is preferred in children < 18 years and pregnancy.

questions.text: Which of the following antiretroviral drugs is not used in HIV & hepatitis B co-infection? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Abacavir

 

HLA B 57:01 mutation is associated with hypersensitivity to abacavir.

 

Abacavir is used in PLHIV with renal failure however is not effective against HBV.

 

Other options:
