Option A, C, D inhibit both HIV reverse transcriptase and HBV DNA polymerase, thereby, inhibiting their replication.

 

M184V mutation results in resistance to Lamivudine, emtricitabine. However, increases susceptibility to tenofovir, zidovudine and also reduces rate of viral replication (Beneficial). Hence addition of boosted protease inhibitor + lamivudine is continued in such cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the treatment of patients with HIV and hepatitis B co-infection, abacavir is not used due to its lack of efficacy against HBV. Instead, drugs like tenofovir, lamivudine, and emtricitabine, which have dual activity against both viruses, are preferred.

 

Reference: NACO 2021 HIV Care and treatment guidelines

questions.text: Which type of hypersensitivity reaction is involved in the hyperacute rejection of renal transplants? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Type II

 

Hyperacute graft rejection is an example of type II hypersensitivity reaction.

 

It is mediated by preformed antibodies. It is a rare event that occurs in kidney transplantation.

 

This results in rapid, severe, and often irreversible damage to the transplanted kidney, leading to graft failure. The preformed antibodies are usually directed against specific antigens on the endothelial cells of the donor organ.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type IV: Incorrect, Type IV hypersensitivity is a delayed reaction mediated by T cells, not antibodies, and is not responsible for hyperacute rejection.

 

Option B. Type III: Incorrect, Type III hypersensitivity involves immune complexes (antigen-antibody complexes) that can deposit in tissues and cause inflammation but is not the mechanism behind hyperacute rejection.

 

Option D. Type I: Incorrect, Type I hypersensitivity is an immediate allergic reaction (like asthma or anaphylaxis) mediated by IgE antibodies, which is different from the antibody-mediated attack on transplanted organs seen in hyperacute rejection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Type II hypersensitivity is crucial in the context of hyperacute rejection of renal transplants, highlighting the importance of thorough pre-transplant screening for donor-specific antibodies to avoid this rapid and destructive immune response.

choices.text: It is the intestinal metaplasia of esophagus
Mucus secreting foveolar cells are characteristic
Alcian blue is used in the staining of biopsy specimen
It is a reversible cell adaptation

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about Barrett's esophagus?(NEET  PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Mucus-secreting foveolar cells are characteristic

 

Mucus-secreting foveolar cells are characteristic: This statement is not true. Foveolar cells are a feature of the normal gastric mucosa, and their presence in biopsy specimens from the esophagus is not characteristic of Barrett's esophagus. Mucus-secreting goblet cells (not foveolar cells) are characteristic of Barrett's esophagus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is the intestinal metaplasia of the esophagus: This statement is true. Barrett's esophagus is a condition in which the normal squamous epithelium of the lower esophagus is replaced by columnar epithelium with intestinal features.

 

Option C. Alcian blue is used in the staining of biopsy specimens: This statement is true. Alcian blue is a stain used to detect the presence of acid mucins in tissue samples, which are a feature of the columnar epithelium seen in Barrett's esophagus.

 

Option D. It is a reversible cell adaptation: This statement is true. As all metaplasia are reversible, Barrett's esophagus is also reversible.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Barrett's esophagus is characterized by intestinal metaplasia of the esophageal epithelium, specifically with goblet cells, and is diagnosed using Alcian blue staining.

questions.text: Isosorbide dinitrate is indicated for congestive heart failure in combination with which of the following vasodilators? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hydralazine

 

Combining hydralazine and isosorbide dinitrate (ISDN) is recommended for CHF.

 

The mechanism of action of hydralazine, a direct vasodilator, remains unknown. Moreover, it lowers nitrate tolerance. The combination of ISDN and hydralazine has been shown to have reduced mortality in patients of CHF.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Minoxidil: Minoxidil is a potent vasodilator used primarily for severe hypertension and not typically combined with ISDN for CHF.

 

Option C. Nimodipine: Nimodipine is a calcium channel blocker used primarily to treat subarachnoid hemorrhage and is not indicated for CHF.

 

Option D. Nitrendipine: Nitrendipine is a dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker used to treat hypertension but is not commonly used in combination with ISDN for CHF.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The combination of hydralazine and isosorbide dinitrate is indicated for the treatment of congestive heart failure, as it effectively reduces both preload and afterload, improving cardiac function and reducing symptoms and mortality in CHF patients.

choices.text: Binds to tubulin and inhibits granulocyte migration

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of colchicine? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Binds to tubulin and inhibits granulocyte migration

 

Colchicine is used in acute gout to control the inflammation. It acts by blocking the microtubules and thereby blocking the chemotaxis or migration of leucocytes. It leads to severe diarrhea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inhibits synthesis of uric acid: Drugs that inhibit the synthesis of uric acid include allopurinol and febuxostat, which inhibit the xanthine oxidase enzyme. Colchicine does not work by this mechanism.

 

Option B. Promotes excretion of uric acid: Uricosuric agents such as probenecid and sulfinpyrazone promote the excretion of uric acid. Colchicine does not promote the excretion of uric acid.

 

Option C. Inhibits xanthine oxidase enzyme: Allopurinol and febuxostat are drugs that inhibit xanthine oxidase, reducing the production of uric acid. Colchicine does not inhibit xanthine oxidase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Colchicine treats acute gout by binding to tubulin, inhibiting the polymerization of microtubules, and preventing the migration and chemotaxis of granulocytes. This reduces the inflammatory response associated with gout attacks.

choices.text: Recurrent hematomas
Recurrent hemarthrosis

questions.text: What is the most common bleeding manifestation observed in severe hemophilia patients?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Recurrent hemarthrosis

 

Recurrent hemarthrosis is the most common bleeding manifestation seen in patients with severe hemophilia. Hemophilia, particularly severe cases where the activity of clotting factor VIII or IX is less than 1%, leads to frequent episodes of joint bleeding, primarily affecting the knees. These episodes are characterized by acute symptoms such as pain, swelling, and erythema, which can lead to chronic issues like synovial thickening and synovitis if not properly managed.

 

Clinical Features of Hemophilia:

 

  • Acute Hemarthrosis: Sudden onset of joint pain, swelling, and redness are typical. Repeated episodes can lead to more severe joint damage and disability.
  • Chronic Hemarthrosis: Long-term joint bleeding results in synovial changes and arthropathy, emphasizing the importance of effective management strategies.
  • Treatment: Management primarily involves replacement therapy with clotting factors, tailored to maintain adequate levels to prevent spontaneous bleeds. The dosing frequency differs based on the specific clotting factor's half-life, with more frequent administration needed for Factor VIII compared to Factor IX.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Recurrent hematomas: While hematomas are a common feature in hemophilia, the most characteristic and frequent bleeding events are joint-related (hemarthroses).

 

Option C. Hematuria: Common but typically self-limited in hemophilia, not as frequent or clinically significant as joint bleeding.

 

Option D. Intracranial hemorrhage: Although potentially life-threatening, intracranial hemorrhages are less common compared to recurrent hemarthrosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding the manifestations of hemophilia, particularly the common occurrence of recurrent hemarthrosis, is crucial for timely and effective treatment. Early intervention and regular prophylactic treatment with clotting factors can significantly improve quality of life and prevent the progression of joint disease in individuals with hemophilia.

choices.text: Patient with recurrent shoulder dislocation
Patient with a fractured arm with capillary refill time of less than 3 seconds in his fingers
Patient with a fractured arm and a 10 cm long incision over the arm
Patient with a fractured arm with capillary refill time of 5 seconds in his fingers

questions.text: You are an intern on duty and have received multiple patients following a road traffic accident. Which of the following patients will require you to urgently call the orthopedic resident on call?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Patient with a fractured arm with capillary refill time of 5 seconds in his fingers

 

A capillary refill time of more than 3 seconds indicates inadequate limb perfusion, suggesting possible vascular injury or compartment syndrome. Both conditions are surgical emergencies, as delayed blood flow to the extremity can lead to tissue necrosis and irreversible damage. The patient with a capillary refill time of 5 seconds requires immediate evaluation and intervention to restore adequate circulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Patient with recurrent shoulder dislocation: While this is an urgent condition, it is not as critical as the vascular compromise seen in option D.

 

Option B. Patient with a fractured arm with capillary refill time of less than 3 seconds in his fingers: A capillary refill time of less than 3 seconds is normal and suggests adequate perfusion, so this patient does not require immediate orthopedic intervention.

 

Option C. Patient with a fractured arm and a 10 cm long incision over the arm: Although the fracture and incision may require urgent attention, there is no immediate indication of vascular compromise or critical limb ischemia based on the provided information.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A delayed capillary refill time, especially beyond 3 seconds, in the setting of a fracture can indicate vascular injury or compartment syndrome, both of which are surgical emergencies. Immediate intervention is crucial to prevent long-term complications such as tissue death or permanent loss of function.

questions.text: A patient presents with wrist pain after a fall on an outstretched hand. Based on the anatomy of the carpal bones, which bone is most likely fractured?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Scaphoid

 

The scaphoid is the most commonly fractured carpal bone, particularly after a fall on an outstretched hand. Its location, spanning both rows of carpal bones and being in the line of force transmission from the forearm to the thumb, makes it susceptible to fractures. Additionally, the scaphoid's blood supply is mainly from the distal portion, leaving the proximal part with poor vascularization. This limited blood flow often results in delayed healing or non-union of scaphoid fractures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lunate: While the lunate can be dislocated or injured in similar trauma, it is less commonly fractured compared to the scaphoid.

 

Option C. Pisiform: This is a small, sesamoid bone that is rarely fractured.

 

Option D. Hamate: Fractures of the hamate are less frequent and typically occur due to direct trauma or force to the hand, not commonly from a fall on an outstretched hand.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A scaphoid fracture should always be suspected in patients with wrist pain after a fall on an outstretched hand, especially when tenderness is noted in the anatomical snuffbox. Early diagnosis and treatment are crucial to prevent complications such as non-union or avascular necrosis due to the bone's limited blood supply.

choices.text: 10 per HWY
5 per HWY
15 per HWY
20 per HWY

questions.text: Out of 100 women who used oral contraceptive pills for 24 months, 10 women became pregnant. What is the Pearl index for this group?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 5 per HWY

 

The Pearl Index is a statistical measure used to evaluate the effectiveness of contraceptive methods. It is calculated as the number of unintended pregnancies per 100 woman-years (HWY) of exposure to the contraceptive method. In this case, 10 pregnancies occurred in 100 women over 2 years (or 200 woman-years).

 

The formula for the Pearl Index is:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Pearl Index is a widely used measure of contraceptive effectiveness. A lower Pearl Index indicates a more effective method. In this case, a Pearl Index of 5 per HWY means that 5 unintended pregnancies are expected per 100 women using the contraceptive method over the course of one year.

choices.text: Korsakoff psychosis
Wernicke’s encephalopathy
Delirium tremens

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic who hasn’t consumed alcohol for the past 3 days is brought to the emergency department with disorientation, poor attention span, and agitation. On examination, he has fever, tachycardia, and diaphoresis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Delirium tremens

 

Delirium tremens is the most severe form of alcohol withdrawal and typically occurs within 3-4 days after alcohol cessation. This condition is characterized by disorientation, clouding of consciousness, autonomic hyperactivity (such as fever, tachycardia, diaphoresis), agitation, and vivid hallucinations or illusions. The autonomic disturbances and altered mental status seen in this patient strongly suggest delirium tremens.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Korsakoff psychosis: Korsakoff syndrome primarily involves significant memory deficits, especially anterograde amnesia, often accompanied by confabulation. It typically lacks the autonomic disturbances and disorientation seen in delirium tremens.

 

Option B. Wernicke’s encephalopathy: This condition presents with confusion, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia, often seen in patients with chronic alcohol use, but it does not typically involve the severe autonomic hyperactivity seen in delirium tremens.

 

Option D. Alcohol-induced dementia: This involves chronic cognitive deficits, including memory and executive function impairments, which persist beyond the acute phase of alcohol withdrawal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Delirium tremens is a life-threatening emergency seen in severe alcohol withdrawal, characterized by disorientation, autonomic instability (fever, tachycardia, diaphoresis), and agitation. Early recognition and treatment with benzodiazepines are essential to prevent complications and reduce mortality.

questions.text: Extramammary Paget's disease (EMPD) most commonly affects which anatomical site?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Vulva

 

Extramammary Paget's disease (EMPD) is most frequently seen on the vulva. It is a rare form of intraepithelial adenocarcinoma, and it may arise primarily from the epidermis or secondarily due to the spread of underlying malignancies. In addition to the vulva, EMPD can also occur on other areas such as the perineum, scrotum, perianal skin, and penis.

 

Primary EMPD arises without an underlying malignancy, typically originating from intraepidermal portions of apocrine glands. Secondary EMPD is associated with an underlying adnexal carcinoma or internal malignancy, where malignant cells spread to the epidermis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vagina: Though close anatomically to the vulva, EMPD is much rarer in the vagina.

 

Option C. Uterus & Option D. Cervix: These locations are not commonly affected by EMPD, though malignancies of the cervix can be associated with the disease in cases of secondary EMPD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Extramammary Paget's disease is most commonly seen on the vulva and requires prompt diagnosis via skin biopsy. Treatment options include surgical excision, radiation therapy, and topical treatments, but systemic workup is important to rule out any associated malignancy, especially in cases of secondary EMPD.
